You are a requirements analyst auditing discussion forum posts for potential feature requests.
You will be provided with a Moodle discussion forum post that includes the post title and post description. Moodle is a free and open-source learning management system (LMS) used by schools, universities, and workplaces to create online courses and manage learning activities.
Your task is to classify if the provided discussion forum post is a feature request or not for Moodle. A feature request is a post where the user asks for new functionality, missing functionality (e.g., features available in other apps), new content, or changes/improvements to existing features in future releases. Posts that are not feature requests include: bug reports, troubleshooting questions, usage questions, configuration issues, announcements, or general discussions. 
Respond strictly with one of the following labels: FEATURE_REQUEST or NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is a feature request, return FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is not a feature request, return NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. Use the title of the post and the description of the post to make the assessment.

Forum Post: 
Post title: New setup of Moodle Courses using Sub Categories
Post description: Hi, I am trying to make sure that we are setting our new system up correctly and part of this is making sure that the course structure is correct. If I can describe what it is I exactly want to do and if someone could explain if it is possible and if so maybe where I can get information on setting it up.. I have spent an hour or so looking for info on this. OK:  I want to do the following.  Setup different types of course, based upon the different subject areas:  EG:  We have Islamic Studies and ICT piloting the software.  Underneath each subject there is different courses:  EG:  GNVQ, Applied ICT, ECDL.  Then underneath each course there is a sub category, which is basically the different Units for each course.  This is the part that actually has the topic information that we are currently seeing each time. Is this possible?  I thing it is so important to get this right.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Repeat - Using Moodle as a Game Platform
Post description: I am repeating this post as the link to YouTube in my previous post seems to have created a problem in the post. I would like to inform you about, what we believe is a worlds first in the use of Moodle for motivating language learning. I will add our standard descriptions first: ARGuing European Union Project - Games in Education ARGuing will help teachers use the Internet  within language education. The project is funded by the European Union within the Lifelong Learning programme. The ARGuing project created 'The Tower of Babel' Alternate Reality Game, using Moodle as the platform, to motivate secondary school students across Europe to learn languages with great success. Project website at http://www.arg-education.eu You can see a presentation on YouTube at (I have taken out the direct link as it caused problems in my previous post): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vd4rKnRSZY8 that includes some statistics and comments from teachers. The link to the Moodle platform is: http://ictthatworks.net:8080/moodle/ We will be presenting academic papers on the project at the forthcoming European Association for Games in Education conference in October, Graz, Austria and will be placing documentation on the project website as well later. Joel Josephson Kindersite Project http://www.kindersite.org Dissemination Partner ARGuing

Post title: is this possible?
Post description: Hi, I received a request from a teacher to create a database inside moodle, if there is resource like that. She want to create a form that the students can fill, later when they submit the form, that information will be stored and displayed to all the course members when they require it. for example, she is doing an Inventions Patent office topic. she needs a way that allows the students to enter their invention to the "patents system", later other inventors (students)  will check beforehand if their invention already exists, if not, they will proceed. Another reques that will use that feature, is that they want to get information from teachers about conferences, so other teachers later can browse for an specific conference and turn in their feedback ; both actions via the form and the display feature. Such a thing is possible under moodle? I suggest them to use the forum, but the information will be all over the forum. Thanks.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Moot in San Francisco
Post description: Good Afternoon, The 2008 Moodle Moot in San Francisco is coming up quickly. We have only 10 more days to register with the early bird discount. In addition, there are a few other conferences happening in San Francisco during the same days as the Moot, the most notable being the Apple WWDC conference. The folks that I've spoken with at the hotels near the conference center have said that they have space now, but that they expect it to fill up soon. I recommend that if you are planning to join us, you get registered soon and secure a hotel room. We are quite familiar with the restrictions that purchasing departments put on registering and attending conferences. If you have any special needs, you can contact me directly at: jonallen@theelearninghub.com +1 202-329-5023 We will be able to accommodate any special needs that you may have. Thanks, and we hope to see you in June, jon

Post title: IRS challenge to virtual space - lawyers alert!
Post description: I'm shocked. The IRS advance ruling on tax exemption for Beach College, a nonprofit corporation in California, is that it can't be a school because it doesn't have a "place." Specifically, a place where a regular faculty teaches a regular student body. We have the faculty (still waiting for the students), and Moodle. Has anyone else run into this problem? The IRS lady wants "court cases or revenue rulings" that would change her mind, and she needs me to respond ASAP. Please tell me if you have any experience here. Were any of you denied 501(c)3 educational status for not having a "place" of business?

Post title: Teenagers & Website Usability
Post description: FYI Usability of Websites for Teenagers Jakob Nielsen's Alertbox, January 31, 2005 http://www.useit.com/alertbox/20050131.html Summary When
using websites, teenagers have a lower success rate than adults and
they're also easily bored. To work for teens, websites must be simple
-- but not childish -- and supply plenty of interactive features. WP1

Forum Post: 
Post title: 5 reasons I LOVE moodle
Post description: Design Simply add big headers to show today's theme and objectives. I love this way of easily convey a visual sense of information hierarchy. You can create nice lists To articulate instructions To remind important points To list resources To define priorities Narrower lists are possible To show the plan To tell where we are Show what's coming next and the end point Adding buttons Use buttons instead of simple links. Especially to reuse older resources or activities .
And students love them. Read Review Test Show plan and icons Show the plan and give student rhythm for the activities . Student are much more aware of their progression. And it is even responsive on mobile! What's the problem Identify the points where you could improve the course design. File Now you try it yourself Go and get a few code snippets from bootstrap and try them on your Moodle. Submit Go a step beyond Watch how you can also add "calls to actions" and play with colors and icons. Learn All the tutorials I have created for my teachers are freely available on github with a Creative Commons licence . Moodle Design (github) You can even download a moodle course page with all the examples. I hope this will help the community using moodle to its limits 😀 Cheers

Forum Post: 
Post title: Help proofread public domain sources
Post description: I just came across the following post today on another site. I actually logged in and proofed a few pages. It was kind of fun to see the variety of books available. Note there are many languages available, especially on the European site, so there is something for everyone to do. Here's the original message I found: Some of you may know the wonders of Project Gutenberg
( http://www.gutenberg.org ), which has thousands and thousands of public domain texts digitized in several languages, primarily english, french,
and german, with a fair number of spanish as well. However, these
projects don't just appear - they have to be proofread, since software
and whatnot simply can't match the power of a human. Please volunteer
your time - completely at your leisure, from your desk, how much you
want when you want - in proofreading these projects. Countless
historically important (and admittedly not so important) works are
waiting to be shared with the world that the internet truly makes
possible. Please register at Distributed Proofreaders
( http://www.pgdp.net ) and proof a couple of pages. If you have a real
skill in other languages such as Russian or other slavic languages,
Greek, and languages with alternative alphabets, please also take a
look at Distributed Proofreaders Europe at ( http://dp.rastko.net ). One
of the incredibly fascinating and groundbreaking projects is an
English/Spanish/Tagalog dictionary, which will serve for at least 6
other dictionaries when finished. Encyclopedia Brittanica is underway
as well - truly massive (it's in the early C's right now). Please
please help in any way you can. Very much appreciated!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Watch Moodle development grow over the years
Post description: Since 2002 when Martin Dougiamas first released Moodle, it has been enhanced by the contributions of hundreds of developers and translators around the world. This stunning animation (created by Eloy Lafuente using the open source software Gource ) represents Moodle development as tree, with the root directory at the very centre and other directories as branches. You can clearly see how, in the early days Martin is developing almost entirely alone and gradually more contributors get involved. In addition to developers, in the early years, translators are also shown (up until the language packs were moved to a separate repository). Many thanks to all our developers , without whom this Moodle ‘tree’ could not have grown and flourished as it has.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Here we go again
Post description: On the receiving end of this bit: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=103424&parent=457079 I felt my response needed to be public but that there was no need for it to further clutter that thread so I thought it best to move any reply here.... First off, Chardelle, as one of the people who sent you info about your site being hacked, I suppose I should say "your welcome....." As to my post here: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=103424&parent=456943 which you suggest indicates that I am intent on "belaboring...", I was actually responding to points Howard made and I included URLs for the material I referenced as I always try to do, because that way everyone understands what everyone else is talking about...... I think on review you will note that I agreed with a number of the points Howard made, but was concerned when talk moved to further exchanges of aspersions. If you want to attack me for what I think was a reasoned review of the details and my expression of my dismay that the source of the discussion was no longer within moodle.org, please me a bit more specific and I will be more than happy to address any of your concerns. I am not sure who is "getting off on attacking Moodle". Nor am I sure who "people" or "someone" are as usede in your post. I tend to agree with Mauno's perspective that ad hominem (invective directed at a person for the purpose of obscuring the underlying argument) is not an appropriate tool for rational discourse, but that does not equate with confusing or refusing to use proper nouns. "An eye for an eye" was abandoned by its authors two millennia ago. Sometimes the willingness to see another's actions as incendiary keeps fires burning for as many years. Sometimes its just because humans are venal. There are way too many examples available to prove either theory. I think Mauno argues that without fuel a fire will die, and I second that notion. So I try to focus on facts, and I try to inject a bit of humor where I can......

Forum Post: 
Post title: Other LMS's
Post description: I got an email today which referred to "Brightspace" the D2L product.  Some interesting claims. Led me to some more comments on the D2L home page.  [warning: extreme marketing hype following] Brightspace: # 1 for Innovation # 1 for Student Performance and Retention # 1 for Customer Engagement # 1 for Accessibility # 1 for Ongoing Training and Support Services Interesting.  They refer to an Ovum report on OLP's as being the source of this data, released several days ago.  (being an ex-science teacher this term has other meanings for me) I then have two choices.  from http://www.brightspace.com/ Read the D2L summary of the report.  (For which I have to sign up for) Go to Ovum page and get it (for which I have to sign up for) http://www.ovum.com/research/ovum-decision-matrix-selecting-an-online-learning-platform-for-higher-education-2015-16/ I don't need another signup. I do not know the CC BY or otherwise status of the report, but if it was available elsewhere online I'd be interested. I think this is one of the Laws of "How To Promote an OLP": 
```text
Find some research (any 'research') that supports your cause.  Promote it heavily on your website.
```
 -Derek

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scavenger Hunt, Easter Egg, Wild Goose Chase?
Post description: This might sound a bit silly but I'm looking for a name for a classroom activity that I would like to do with some of my students. Once in a while, I'd like to send some of them (those who want to do the exercise) on a miniature quest for information that I know is readily available online. I'd drop in a few clues in class and interested students would have to do their own queries. For instance, to get some students (in an introductory class in cultural anthropology) to look at Tuckman's model of team development, I could give the terms "storming" and "performing" as clues for their searches. It may sound a bit silly but I think the strategy could work out. I wouldn't be grading these "mini-quests" or giving extra credit to those who go on them. The content of these "queries" wouldn't be on quizzes or exams. But I'm guessing that it could be fun to do and it might have some positive effects on student engagement and participation. One thing I like about this simple strategy is that it's not too directive (no hand-holding) but it still gives some signposts so people don't get lost... Now, what could I call these activities ? "Wild goose chase" has negative connotations but the concept that they're a bit erratic does capture something of what I want to do. "Scavenger hunt" isn't appropriate because the structure of the task isn't as complex or team-oriented as a scavenger hunt. I quite like the concept of an "Easter egg," but that might be an imprecise analogy for what I want to do (the information wasn't deliberately hidden). I don't necessarily need a name to try this strategy out with students, but it could be easier to explain the process if I did have a cool name for it. As English isn't my native language, this is the kind of thing about which I'm not really sure. Of course, some of you might tell me that what I'm trying to do is pedagogically unsound or that my methodology is faulty. If so, I will fully respect your opinion but I'll try it out for myself, at least on a couple of occasions. If you have tried a similar strategy, I'd be happy to learn about it. And if you think of ways to integrate these queries with Moodle (I have my own ideas), it could be very helpful. Thanks a lot for any help you can give me.

Thanking you all for your collaboration.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Use of variables when changing time settings in resources?
Post description: Each term I have to go in and
change hundreds of settings only because the time slot of my courses change.  You can only imagine how many clicks it takes
per resource to update  "Allow
Submissions", "Due Time", and "Cut-off Time" for each
one.  Let's not forget making mistakes
and forgetting which one I just edited when the screen finally refreshes.  I could spend hours on this for every course
and for every semester. Could we not have user-defined variables to leave
in place and then update only one set of entries? For me, a set of variables would be a time setting
for: CS110A-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS110A-DueTime, [HH] [MM] CS110A-Cut-OffTime, [HH] [MM] CS110B-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS110B-DueTime, [HH] [MM] CS110B-Cut-OffTime, [HH] [MM] CS113A-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS113A-DueTime, [HH] [MM]v CS113A-Cut-OffTi, [HH] [MM]e, CS113B-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS113B-DueTime, [HH] [MM] CS113B-Cut-OffTime, [HH] [MM] Make them select-able from within the resource. Another method would be to use Group assignments. This way, I change the appropriate variable
setting and it reflects into hundreds of resource entries immesiately.  This came to light when one of my courses
changed to a new time slot one day before classes started. ):

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is 'Learning 3.0'?
Post description: We have all heard of Web 2.0 (internet with collaborative interaction), which implies that a Web 3.0 is coming.  What is that?  In the corporate education world, a conference is opening called " Learning 3.0 ".  I am wondering what that is.  The conference organizers define it as: Make mobile learning "The Enabler" for performance improvement in your organization. Apply gamification to learning. Use social media to centralize knowledge and create valuable communities of practice. Reach game-savvy, socially-networked workers and create a learning model that truly delivers just-in-time learning and performance support. How about for Moodle?  What is Moodle 3.0 going to be?  Presumably a qualitative leap like Moodle 1.x changing to Moodle 2.x. At the iMoot conference, I attended Lasic's presentation on the Moodle Hub. I said teachers doing mass collaboration globally to create great courses in specific fields is the next quantum leap. Even bigger than Moodle itself. Some people agreed. That may be different from what the Training Magazine people think. What do you think is 'Learning 3.0'?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Assistive Technology Module Online
Post description: Hello Moodlers, A couple of years ago, I received a grant to develop online modules in support of an educational technology endorsement program. I hired college faculty and public school teachers to develop a series of self-study online modules based on a format that I developed. In order to make it easy for the developers, I had them create all their content in MS Word for me to reformat to the web once complete. I've just finished getting one of the modules on the web. It covers Technology for Special Populations (Assistive Technology). It is open to the public on my site and will remain that way. It is created so that everything can be seen/done with guest access with the exception of the quizzes...anyone can create an account, and enroll to do the quizzes if they like. The course is located here: http://www.kentuckyclassroom.com/teacher/course/view.php?id=145 I have eight other modules on various educational technology topics I will be making available to the public as I get them formatted and posted to on my Moodle site. On a side note, I'm no expert in assistive technology, so if anyone is really interested in this area and would like to help improve and keep this module updated, please reply here or PM me and we can discuss making you a teacher in the course to help maintain and keep it updated. Steve

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle talk
Post description: On Friday local Moodler Dales Jones and I met up to talk Moodle. We managed to effortlessly maintain a non-stop Moodle centred dialogue
for around five (yes, five!) hours. The scope of our conversation was
wide ranging - Dale has some top ideas on the use of Moodle in the UK educational
arena. The flow was only broken by Dale's need to join his family for their
evening meal and my need get to the local computer shop to buy an
external hard drive - such is life. I reckon there was easily another five hours discussion left. At least. Conclusion: If you're able to do team up with some others to talk Moodle, do so. Recommended! Ray

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle-liveCD available, add you own content (moodle system) using windows
Post description: Hi, We are a small group of germans working with moodle. One of our products may be useful for people in other countries either. With our LiveCD you can: get in touch with moodle offline burn your own moodle to the cd as add-on for publications etc. teach your students offline at home (no reintegration in internet systems possible yet) present your courses without having internet access .... Further international development depends on your support. E.g. I found a way to reintegrate offline test results to an existing online moodle, but there is still some work to do to get it work. If there is no need for this or that feature there will be no need for development. Of course the cd is free of any charge... It is a join-up between lamppix und koppix 3.8.1. For further details just feel invited to visit http://www.moodleschule.de

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Security and working with management
Post description: Hello fellow moodle users, For the last five months or so I have been learning how to use moodle. (thanks for all the support at this site!) I am an English Teacher at a technical high school in Japan. Currently, I now am serving my moodle on my Mac Desktop Pro, as a production server . Unfortunately, I cannot register or access my moodle from home because it is stuck inside our school network. This week I have a meeting with the Computer Dept. to explain to them why I need to have the moodle outside the school network. The Computer Dept., traditionally doesn`t allow anything outside their network for security reasons. Let me list a few items of information that are important. 1. My server is my own personal computer, not the schools. 2. I did a step by step install of Moodle 1.7.2 so as to secure the site better. 3. I changed the default passwords, as said in the moodle installation info. 4. I want to use my moodle as a platform for other students studying English to communicate in English with my students, via, posted discussion, chat, blogging, and posted video and audio. I would know the total number of students and set all passwords and user names. My understanding is that Moodle is pretty secure as long at you take necessary precautions. (backup, hard passwords, update). BUT, I am not sure what the computer people think over at the computer dept. I suppose they view by moodle as another potential access point for crackers. My big question is, can anyone point me to a discussion or thread that outlines moodle security in a detailed manner? I would like to be prepared for what ever questions the Computer Dept. puts to me. Ps. My understanding is that if a cracker uses packet snifers to intercept the encrypted data between my server and the users computer that they eventually could *crack* my moodle after they beat the encryption. Is this correct? One, I dont think that any cracker would be that interested in my Moodle. There is no sensitive data (pictures of students, full names, addresses) Two, a cracker would have to intercept a lot of packets before that could get enough info for a password and user name and that is after they cracked the encryption. What is the moodle encryption rate? And is this premise correct or incorrect?

Post title: The Complete eLearning System
Post description: I have been slowly putting together a (what I think) complete eLearning system for our k-12 staff and students. We use a variety of tools for a variety of purposes, but here is what I am narrowing down my focus to: Learning -> Moodle Reflection, Social, & Publishing/Views -> Mahara Communication & Video Tutorials -> DimDim Moodle is the core of it all and everything is based on your login to moodle. From moodle ( LDAP LOGIN) every staff and student can gain access to these three add-on resources. Teachers already have instant access via ldap permissions to publish a course at anytime in Moodle. I have the first 2 done, I am waiting for Version 4 of DimDim which will allow a teacher to upload a PPT and record the webcam and presentation for viewing later. DimDim can also be utilized for collaboration and communication on class/group projects or study sessions. These three systems work well and integrate nicely to provide everything from social bookmarking & Blogs to web conferencing and whiteboards. I like that students can now be publishers of content via Mahara as well. What are your thoughts?

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is a Derivative work with regards to a Creative Commons License?
Post description: I've just wasted about an hour trying to find something online that gives some clear examples of what a derivative work is in terms of the creative commons license. I'm wondering particularly about images. There are some definitions of a derivative work that are quite clear-like a painting or collage based on an image. The creative commons license variations cannot include a "no derivatives" and a "share alike" clause in the same license, which makes it more confusing. But what is a use of an image that is not a derivative other than just posting the image by itself? The share alike clause seems to apply only to "derivative" works. But if one uses an unmodified creative commons licensed image as an illustration of a newly composed text on a Web page, is that Web page considered a derivative work? If it is not considered a derivative work in that case, then is there any different functionally in the terms of the license if it is either a no derivatives or share alike license? If a share alike image is used in a non-derivative way, then is the user obligated to publish the entire work in which it is included as share alike, since share alike only seems to apply to derivative works? I hope this makes sense. I really wish someone would take someone to court over these creative commons licenses as they seem to me to be full of ambiguities. At least that way there would be some clarity to the matter.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How would you rate Moodle against Drupal or WordPress?
Post description: I am considering Moodle for a paid online training site. I am also considering WordPress and Drupal. From what little I have seen, Moodle seems to be the best choice. But I have some concerns. 1) I am iffy about being able to monatize a Moodle site. I know there is a paypal plugin for Moodle. But what about subscriptions? What about credit cards? 2) Is this site made with Moodle? If not, why not? 3) I am reading some harsh stuff about Moodle. Is it any cause for concern? 80% of people on this site hate Moodle: http://amplicate.com/hate/moodle I am also reading a lot about performance issues, especially with recent releases of Moodle. 4) A lot of people post that: "anything you can do with Moodle can be done with WordPress, or Drupal." I think that is probably true. But, from my experience so far, getting WP to act like an LMS is huge PITA. WP seems to be very centered around blogging. Using WP for an LMS feels like trying to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. Maybe I'm too impatient with WP? Also, worthwhile plugins in WP cost money, and sometimes even those are not worthwhile. 5) Mobile is important to me. WP does have decent some decent mobile themes. How would you rate Moodle for mobiles? 6) Does the Moodle flashcard plugin work with newer versions of Moodle? 7) One of my great frustrations with Drupal was: this module does not work with that version of Drupal and that module does not work with this version of Drupal. Sadly, Moodle seems to have the same problem. Or maybe I have misunderstood? That's all I can think of for now. Thanks for reading. 3)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Looking to hire Moodle/Content Developer
Post description: Hello everyone... I am looking to hire a Moodle/Content Developer to assist us in a Moodle transition. Due to the fact that we currently have a LMS contract that I inherited from my predecessor that carries us through to end of 2010, this position will have the time necessary to create a one-of-a-kind and exciting Moodle offering that will support our company eLearning efforts. Truly carte blanche, but with plenty of internal resources to use to get the job done. When we have it set, we will end our relationship with our current LMS provider and move forward. In addition, this position will add creativity and excitement to existing eLearning content and manage it on our existing LMS and then on to Moodle. We use a combination of Articulate, Captivate, and PPT for these courses. Knowledge of these tools is less important than Moodle experience as they are pretty easy to learn. Ultimately, we are looking for a creative, unique, and enthusiastic individual who will do some 'fun' and cutting-edge work. Flash/HTML and/or any multimedia experience a plus. The company is a $100mil. corporation based out of Philadelphia, PA. We are open to making this a remote position for the right person. Person has to be US-based though. If anyone is interested or if anyone of you know a good place for me to turn to find this unique skillset, please let me know. If interested, reply to this message and I will send you the official job description. Tom

Post title: Info on free/cheap web hosting for a good cause? (not Moodle)
Post description: I would really appreciate any info people could give me on cheap/reliable web hosting. I've checked prices at Godaddy.com and they are too expensive for my needs. I just came back from Africa. During my stay there I met a number of people that I would like to help and having access to cheap and reliable web hosting would be essential. These are people who have just started with little businesses such as hostels or craft shops in areas that are not far from areas that foreign travelers visit but because they have not made it into travel guides and do not have web presence, they don't receive as many visitors as they might receive otherwise. I volunteered to create simple web pages for them and I'm even willing pay for the hosting for a while in some cases. I checked web hosting services such as Godaddy.com but I find them too expensive for what I need. In some cases these are people who are barely surviving with their businesses and $4 a month is quite a lot in a place where $120 a month is considered a pretty decent salary and very few can actually get jobs that would earn it. The web sites I want to put together with the pictures and info I collected are very simple and hence require very little space. Does anybody know of cheap (or free if possible) web hosting services that could help me with this initiative? Any advice, tips I should consider besides info on the hosting itself? Thanks a lot in advance. Josep M.

to consider: A Chelyabinsk professor
faces up to six years in prison for conducting a series of lectures via Skype,
according to Russian media reports. Marina Zagidullina, a
mass communications professor at Chelyabinsk State University, is suspected of
having used her position to embezzle university funds, Rossiiskaya Gazeta
reported Saturday. Zagidullina said in
comments to the newspaper that the charge was based on seven missed days of
work in 2011. "During that time I
read 11 lectures in a videoconference format, including via Skype,"
Zagidullina was cited as saying, adding that "students received the full
volume of information, and more than that, they were able to pose questions [on
the material] and receive answers. So these were just like ordinary
lessons." (continued) http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/russian-professor-faces-6-years-behind-bars-for-skype-lectures/504111.html Not my post title, or my discovery.  From Ivan, one of my friends in Christchurch. -Derek

Forum Post: 
Post title: On the criteria to accept new Certified Integrations
Post description: Dear Moodlers, Carles here, technology partner manager at Moodle HQ. My role is to support tools that integrate or want to integrate better with Moodle. On this chapter, I run the Certified Integrations program, where we vet potential Moodle partners on the usability of their integration with us, on their business consistency and, if there is code, on the code quality. The result is a small set of tools that we have reviewed and labelled Certified Integrations: https://moodle.com/certified-integrations Obviously, Moodle is used together with both open source and commercial programs, so the program is happy to promote other open source tools, like BigBlueButton and Myddleware, but accepts commercial partners as well. My question would be the following: Which should be in your opinion the criteria of acceptance of products to the program? Should we limit tools, for example, produced by competitors? Should we ban the big names that tend to use their market position and have very aggressive user terms? Or should we stick to the code quality and leave other matters to you, users? In general, as this post bears as title, which should be the criteria of acceptability for Certified Intergrations? Thanks for your interest and insights, I'll love to read any comments on this. 🤓 Best, Carles

Post title: Exploring the Educational Digital Divide
Post description: Following on from the recent ALT Conference, the EXTEND project team would like to invite you to participate in an online asynchronous discussion in which we will explore the Educational Digital Divide. Funded by JISC-Emerge Benefits Realisation, the discussion begins on Monday 29 September 2008, with topics and questions including: · What does the digital Divide mean to you? · Who has the hardware, software and bandwidth? · Digital Divide as a duality - link to Perpetual Divide · Gender as a lens on the Digital Divide · Silver surfers and Digital Natives However, you’re not restricted to the above topics - with multimedia resources to inspire you and plenty of opportunity to explore your ideas, we are expecting this to be a lively and interesting discussion. The event will be hosted on the HELP (Higher Education Learning Professionals) network, which you can join by visiting http://www.cabweb.net/portal/course/view.php?id=7 - this will take you to a login page where you can create an account in 2 easy steps and enter the discussion. Please do join us for what we expect to be a lively and thought-provoking event! Helen Keegan, Frances Bell and Cristina Costa

Forum Post: 
Post title: The evolution of edx, xMOOC and cMOOC-a coming together
Post description: Hi found this paper today (ref & ab below).  I asked about the hybridity of x/c MOOCs sometime ago (Feb-2014) and got no answer...I thought it made sense at the time to think along those lines. So it seems....it did make sense-the formula sounds like it will be (my interpretation): edx accomodates x & c MOOCs-(cMOOCs-developed by grads) so both will run under the one roof-interesting times. Sanders et al., (2014) 'A new approach to developing interactive software modules through graduate education' Journal of Science Education & Technology 23, 3, pp431-440. Abstract Educational technology has attained significant importance as a
mechanism for supporting experiential learning of science concepts.
However, the growth of this mechanism is limited by the significant time
and technical expertise needed to develop such products, particularly
in specialized fields of science. We sought to test whether interactive,
educational, online software modules can be developed effectively by
students as a curriculum component of an advanced science course. We
discuss a set of 15 such modules developed by Harvard University
graduate students to demonstrate various concepts related to astronomy
and physics. Their successful development of these modules demonstrates
that online software tools for education and outreach on specialized
topics can be produced while simultaneously fulfilling project-based
learning objectives. We describe a set of technologies suitable for
module development and present in detail four examples of modules
developed by the students. We offer recommendations for incorporating
educational software development within a graduate curriculum and
conclude by discussing the relevance of this novel approach to new
online learning environments like edX. D

Post title: Quiz Scores, Feedback, Etc not Available to Students 1.8
Post description: We recently upgraded from 1.6 to the latest stable version of 1.8 (on Jan. 09) and are having the following problem with our quiz module. Post title: Fwd: Call for Proposals: Illinois Online Virtual Conference
Post description: (forwarded text follows) The Curriculum, Technology, and Education Reform (CTER) program in the Department of Educational Psychology will be hosting a hybrid online/on-campus conference in conjunction with the 5th annual Illinois Online Conference (IOC) for Teaching and Learning ( http://www.ilonlineconf.org/ ). This conference will be held February 14-16, 2007. Live presentations will be held from 5pm to 8pm on campus at the College of Education, and broadcast live via Elluminate . We encourage you to submit proposals for this conference. This will be an excellent opportunity for you to share your best practices in using technology for teaching and learning in front of an international audience, and you can choose to do it here at the College of Education or from your workplace/home via Elluminate. You may submit your proposals here . The deadline for the proposals is December 6, 2006. This will also be an opportunity for instructors who would like to participate in a live (in person or online) presentation session with their class. If you'd like to take advantage of this opportunity, please contact us for more information at scagnoli@uiuc.edu .

Forum Post: 
Post title: Financing a project
Post description: A very good afternoon to you all and thank you for all your interesting posts to date and the work you do to make Moodle the wonderful tool it is. I posted about this to the "Forum" forum but received only one reply. I apologize in advance for cross posting, but I wonder if anyone here might have ideas / comments on what I believe is a very important aspect of Moodle. I've had a look but couldn't seem to find anything. My question is: Is there a way to have the forum display changed? My students inevitably click the person's name who started the forum post - it's in the middle of the screen, and it kind of makes sense to click that. No matter how often I tell students, it is the one thing that continually sends students on the wrong path. They click the person's name, then try and send messages rather than post replies. This, to me, is a major design fault and I wonder is there any way I can change it. I know forum has been around for a long time. I've only had smaller classes in the past (have used Moodle since 1.2) but have always had troubles. I now have a course with over a thousand students from 6 different countries and we are having the same problem in all 6 countries so it doesn't seem to be limited to one culture (as I initially thought it might be.) I'd be very interested in others thoughts on this and if there is a way to change the layout. I wonder if others think the same way as I do regarding the design of the forum? Should I start a tracker item? Do others think it is a fundamental design flaw? My ideal forum interface would look something like this Your post (or something else, but not "Discussion") Follow button Group Replies Last post made by An example title (click anywhere in this section and it will take you to that forum discussion) started by Joe Bloggs on (date) (institution name here?) (NO link to student profile) Click here to follow this topic only 3 6 Marla Doe – see it here (clickable) Another cool title Started by Minnie Do on (date) (institution name here?) (no link to student profile) Following (eg only) 2 2 Joe Bloggs– see it here (clickable) Forum has been in Moodle from the beginning and it is a crucial part thereof but I really feel it, of all things, is in a dire need of a facelift. Would be interested in others' ideas. I have some money that I could put toward making this happen if a programmer is out there. I'd also love to have a report along the lines of a page that shows the following and can be separated into groups and be both course wide and per forum: Student name Country Number of posts (if possible, set dates here – between ~ & ~) Number of replies Total forum views Total number of words First post Last post Send reminder Link to complete report Joe Bloggs Japan 1 7 18 542 Oct 1 Nov 12 (click to send) link Marla Doe Colombia 2 8 21 625 Oct 1 Nov 14 (click to send) link Minnie Do Japan 1 1 8 35 Oct 10 Oct 27 Sent (date here) (click to resend) link Many thanks again to everyone that puts so much time into Moodle - wish I had the tools to do this myself! Hope to hear others' thoughts on this.

Post title: We need your views: plugins directory workshop on 09 Jan 2023
Post description: Dear Moodlers, At Moodle HQ, we are trying to improve the Community Sites . One of the sections that we feel has the most room for improvement is the plugins directory , so we are doing some specific work on it. In order to understand the needs and desires of users as we make these improvements, we would like to invite you to a virtual chat about the plugin directory in the form of a workshop. The workshop will be held on 9 January 2023 at 19:00 UTC . Other workshops are being held in other time zones and languages as well to try to capture as much information as possible. We imagine that most of the attendees will be Moodle administrators or course creators, but everyone is welcome. The aim is to understand what you would like us to improve in the directory from the point of view of the user looking for and installing plugins. There will be other sessions dedicated to the plugin creators/ developers experience, at a later date. Please contact me at aurelie.soulier@moodle.com so I can invite you to the event or if you need further information. Best regards, Aurelie and the Community Sites team

Post title: EduGeek Journal: New Educational Technology blog built on Moodle
Post description: I just wanted to invite everyone to check out a new blog built on Moodle: EduGeek Journal . It's a group blog run by several professionals in the EdTech field that are blogging on tools, news, and issues from the world of Educational Technology. There is also a discussion forum to talk about the blog posts. Some of the recent posts include: Higher Ed Failing to Use Popular Media to Reach Prospects Is Blackboard the Galactus of Learning Management Systems? Learning Management Systems Go 3-D With Sloodle Information Literacy - From K-12 to Higher Ed It's still new, and some of the bugs are getting worked out, but the discussions are interesting and humorous. Since the discussions are built on Moodle, you do have to have an account on the site to post comments, but it is free and easy (as most Moodle users know).

Forum Post: 
Post title: CK-ERP (Open Source ERP / CRM / MRP) v.0.22.1 released (with Moodle connector)
Post description: Hi, folks, I have posted a new release, v.0.22.1, of CK-ERP, at SourceForge.Net, http://sourceforge.net/projects/ck-erp . This release features connectors for Moodle, Atutor, vTiger, XRMS, WordPress, b2evolution and e107. Nine modules have Spanish screen translations added. Special thank is due to Guillermo Patterer from Fiberair for providing the Spanish translation. CK-ERP is an open source accounting/MRP/ERP/CRM system that runs on top of multiple middlewares. It comprises 22 modules - Administration, i18n, Contact Management, Customer Relationship, Customer Self Service, Vendor Relationship, Ledger, Bank Reconciliation, MRP, Warehouse, Inventory, Service, AP, AR, PO, SO, Quotation, POS for Cashier, POS for Manager, HR, Staff Self Service and Payroll. Operating platform can either be LAMP or LAPP. It provides accounting and back office functionalities to SMEs and utilizes the underlying middleware to administer accounts/groups. Please report error and suggestion to the discussion group / mailing list, CK-ERP-en(at)googlegroups.com or CK-ERP-zh_CN(at)googlegroups.com . General history and expected development is available at the discussion group's Archive. Supported MiddleWares: eGroupWare, Horde-GroupWare; Zencart, CRELoaded, osCommerce; Drupal, Joomla, Mambo, e107, XOOPS, Xaraya; Moodle, Atutor; vTiger, XRMS; WordPress, b2evolution; TikiWiki; phpBB. Information/Demo Websites: http://ck-erp.org http://ck-erp.net

Post title: Embedding video presentations in Moodle
Post description: Have you been thinking in embedding real PowerPoint-based video presentations in Moodel. PresentationTube provides a desktop presentation recorder and video sharing network to help instructors, students, virtual presenters, and business professionals record, upload and share quality, accessible, and interactive video presentations. PresentationTube Recorder integrates a variety of presentation aids and synchronizes presenter's audio and video, PowerPoint slides, whiteboard, drawing board, and Web content. PresentationTube presentations provide a scrollable slide thumbnail allowing the user to move to the respective video content and control both the time and progress of video presentation. A video presentation allows interactivity also via Facebook social plug-in and self-assessment quizzes, allowing learners to be heard and involved. PresentationTube video presentations are accessible via desktop and mobile devices and can be used in flipped classrooms, home revisions, e-learning and blended learning environments, distance education settings, virtual conferences, and business orientations. No need for developing new materials or third-party software. PresentationTube is free and videos are hosted on high-speed media streaming servers to provide a rich experience with no ads, no banners, and unlimited bandwidth and storage space.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Please answer ONE question??  Project for a college course on online program implementation
Post description: Hi All, I am looking for someone in K-12 Moodling that can talk about program implementation, converting courses from face-to-face to online, accessibility issues, etc. I promise that it will be very short and can be via email. this interview is an assignment for the Master's program in Online Teaching and Learning at California State University-East Bay. They use Blackboard, but I am using Moodle for special needs students for my capstone project. So . . . I'm turning to my fellow K-12 Moodlers for help! So is anybody out there, with all the free time they have as educators, willing to answer some questions for me? I have been using Moodle for almost eight years. Let me know by reply, as I need to have this done in the next week and a half. Here are some of the questions I would ask: 1. How long has your online program used Moodle, did you switch from another CMS? If so, why did you switch to Moodle? 2. Is your program a major transfer of classes from facd-to-face to online? If so, how did you train traditional classroom teachers to transfer their classes to online. 3. Do you have official professional development courses to train teachers on how to use Moodle, transfer courses, give tech support? If so, do you hold face-to-face workshops or do you use Moodle? 4. What kind of tech support is available at your institution? In your opinion, is it effective for the teachers? For the students? 5. How involved are your parents involved in your online learning program? Do you have parent accounts? 6. How do you ensure that your courses are as accessible as possible for disabled students? Do you follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)? 7. How do you host your online program? If hosted locally, do you have proper server space, memory, and broadband access for your online program? Who is in charge of the server? 8. How do you assess the effectiveness of a particular course? The entire program? 9. What is the workload of an online instructor vs. a traditional face-to-face instructor? Do they receive more or less compensation? Is tenure affected by whether an instructor teaches online or not? 10. Do you have a blended or online only program? 11. Are your courses using media-rich content? If not, why? If so, do you have problems with compatibility? 12. Do you integrate third party Web 2.0 tools in your program? If not, why? 13. Who owns the course content in your program, the institution or the instructor? 14. How does your institution monitor fair-use, plagiarism and copyright infringement. 15. What provisions/accommodations do you make for LD students? Sincerely, Jamey Barber jbarbercsueb@gmail.com

Forum Post: 
Post title: MoodleMoot UK-Ireland 2018
Post description: Just bought my ticket and reserved my hotel room, I managed to find somewhere really close this time with private parking. I'm hoping to do a few days Skiing at Glencoe the preceding weekend, so will have my car with me. Who else is going? Really pleased to see that the change in location to Glasgow has also resulted in a drop in the ticket price and my hotel is cheaper. I'm also happy to see that we're university based this year. I much prefer that to the soulless conference centre/hotel used for the London events. I'm hoping this means a return to lecture hall tiered seating for the conference sessions, which is so much better than the "dining room" arrangement. Note to the organisers (Gavin etc), the huge (2.7MB) image of Strathclyde Uni on the booking page means that (a) When you PDF the booking page the PDF is very large and (b) when you click through each page of the booking process you get landed on the image with nothing else visible, so you have to scroll right down a lot to get to the actual form you need to deal with. One request for 2019! Can you please try and get the dates confirmed much earlier, March/April is a really busy period for me and while MoodleMoot is normally the week before Easter, that hasn't always been the case and there are other things going on around then which I would like to do, but can't commit to until the MoodleMoot dates are out. Unfortunately, the announcement usually comes too late, so I miss out on other activities . I appreciate that there is a lot to organise, but as a committee member for another large software conference, we usually managed to confirm a lot further in advance, one year we managed 12 months notice!

Post title: Moodle adaptation
Post description: Not sure if this is the right place to post this but here goes... My client would like to use Moodle but has some extra requests that maybe some of you developers out there could help with. They want an assessment system where they can create questions and group them i.e. Question Group 1 = Questions on Linux, Question Group 2 = Questions on Moodle etc...  Then For each project that comes along, they can create a New Test for the project that consists of any number of 'Question Groups' plus some one-off questions.   This project could be serving groups of 10 to 200 people and we need these people to be able to logon, take the test and the system to output a Spreadsheet with the results of the project - i.e. all the students results. It's quite a specific way fo working and we'd love to hear from you if you can help us get a system working for the client. Many thanks, Graham (Vocale Ltd) vocale@vocale.it

Post title: Will a robot take your job?

Post description: I am looking for bands to play at an OXJAM (part of oxfam) event in West London - Ealing below are the details. It will be on the 16th Oct in The Lodge Tavern . Conference on eLearning and eResearch in the Arab World,
Part of
The 5th Congress of
Scientific Research Outlook and Technology Development in the Arab
 World (SRO5),
Organized by
Arab Science and Technology Foundation (ASTF)

26-30 October 2008
Fez-Morocco

Conference Objectives
The conference will feature speakers, papers and posters from the
 international eLearning eResearch community, which focus on:
• Raising awareness for eLearning and eResearch 
activities
 in Arab
 countries,
• Information sharing and networking among those engaged in eLearning
 and eResearch activities,
• Discussion of issues related to eLearning and eResearch, e.g.

• Providing information about International and Regional eLearning
 and eResearch initiatives,
• Prospects, trends and challenges of eLearning and eResearch in the
 Arab world,
• Presenting success stories of eLearning and eResearch in the Arab
 world.

Conference Scopes
• eLearning and eResearch Applications in Life Sciences, Materials,
 Chemical Sciences, Energy, Earth Sciences and Cosmology, Social Sciences,
 Arts, and Humanities,
• Grid Services and Applications, eInfrastructure and Computer Grids
 for Science and Industry,
• Tools, Infrastructure, Policies and Services to Enable and Support
 eLearning and eResearch in Arab World,
• Access and Data Management,
• Collaboration Environments and Research Networking,
• eLearning and eResearch Applications.

Post title: Thoughts on activity and course completion
Post description: Maybe this is the wrong place to ask this...but I'm curious and don't really see a better place. With Moodle 2.0, we got activity and course completion.  And they rock.  My (work) life is so much simpler now (and by simpler, I mean my external reports no longer take hours to run and my core-hack student transcript that took 15 minutes per student is no longer necessary). But here's my question...why don't we have a forum to specifically post questions about course completion and activity completion?  Okay, so activity completion could be covered by the specific activity...but course completion questions don't really fit anywhere.  Courses and course formats doesn't seem to be right place.  Maybe I'm the only one with questions/concerns?

Post title: courseware on moodle development
Post description: Hi Moodle gurus, We at Kenfuse.com are looking to set up compelling courseware for tech students following MIT's opencourseware guidelines. PHP application development of course is one of the key topics. You can find some details at http://www.kenfuse.com/course/php-programming-101 Our focus is to organize a good set of courseware that can be used across universities and hence this note to this forum of Moodle stars. The idea is to first introduce PHP programming and then run students through some popular PHP based applications such that students get a first hand feel of real apps besides picking up skills on design, coding style, organization and eventually pick projects to develop some handson skills. To kick start the process, we are planning to have a session material on moodle as well. Looking for advice on content and resources particularly on the session moodle development and more than welcome thoughts / suggestions on others. Here is a quick link to the first session on the topic "Essential PHP" http://www.kenfuse.com/content/essential-php . This is just a reference . Also would be interested in if the moodle community has project ideas that can be offered to students the coming session. These are going to be administered by faculty and therefore would have serious participants only Thanks in advance - Sandy

Post title: Proposal for an Answer Zone for Moodle
Post description: I'm creating a proposal for a StackOverflow-like Q&A website for Moodle users, administrators and developers. As you could imagine, I'm not suggesting to replace the existing Moodle.org, but to provide a new free tool to the Moodle community which could help in obtaining more focused and structured support and in growing the community itself. If you've ever used stackoverflow.com you know what I'm talking about. If you've never used it, you're probably wondering how a new tool could be better than the existing Moodle.org. In the second case, here's an explanation for you: http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/99434/ If you'd like to support this proposal, please follow it and add your sample Moodle questions here: http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/33861/moodle-answers We need 51 more followers to jump to the next phase.

Post title: Shouldn't Moodle be a Topic in Meetup.com?
Post description: Hi, I would love the opportunity to hang out with other Moodlers from time-to-time. I have found Meetup.com a great way to find local meetings of niche groups. I currently attend a Meetup organized webmaster group and always learn something new. I could never find a Moodle meetup group on Meetup.com; therefore, I was considering sponsoring a meetup. While looking over the new group setup form I noticed that Moodle is not an available topic. I find this odd due to the huge Moodle user base. Do you guys think that Meetup.com organized local Moodle meetings would be something worth pursuing. I don't see why it wouldn't work, as long as there is a significant local user base. I think we need to start by getting Meetup.com to add Moodle as an available topic. I could pursue this but Moodle Headquarters may yield more clout than I do. Once they are aware of the popularity of Moodle I suspect this would be a "no-brainer". What do you guys think?

Post title: You're Invited to a free Moodle forum!
Post description: Our free, one-hour Moodle Users' Forums are back! In these online sessions we bring you a speaker or Moodle topic, and offer you a chance to ask Moodle questions, share ideas with fellow teachers, and pick up tips and tricks that will have you teaching online with the best of 'em. Join us for the December session: December 8, 2010 | 3:30-4:30PM ET Special guest Dr. Ray Pastore, Assistant Professor of Instructional Technology at Watson School of Education, University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW) shares: Mobile Learning: How to use and develop mobile apps for the classroom Are you interested in developing mobile apps or having your students develop mobile apps in the classroom? If so, then this presentation is for you! During this presentation we will discuss cases of mobile learning use and demonstrate how to develop mobile apps using Google’s easy-to-use App Inventor tool. This free tool requires no programming and allows you to publish real mobile apps. The presentation will be followed, as always, by an open Q&A time for Moodle questions. Free! No pre-registration, just mark your calendar! Get the details and see our archives >

Post title: Jog Your Memory, Remember Everything, JogLab
Post description: Dear Moodle using, technology loving educators/learners, I hope this is OK for this forum, if it's not please feel free to remove it. I’ve just finished creating www.JogLab.com , a completely free web-based teaching and learning tool that makes remembering stuff quick, simple and fun ( quick video tutorial on main page ). I’d LOVE any advice/ volunteers to help spread the word about this tool; JogLab needs thousands of daily ‘hits’ to cover running costs but I believe many learners/ teachers will find it useful once they know of its existence. I don’t have a great deal of time so I’d be really grateful for any advice or help you might give on any aspect of JogLab/ promotion suggestions etc. These are my ideas so far: · Emailing teachers and asking them to forward a poster (this one: http://www.joglab.com/resources/JogYourMemory.RememberEverything.JogLab.doc ) to their learning/ teaching contacts. Are there any email lists that are appropriate? · Asking teachers who like JogLab to post a link to JogLab on newsgroups they use ( on site functionality exists to do this on Facebook etc.) · Asking all educators/ learners to give feedback, propose areas of collaboration, contacts or ideas for promotion ( danTHECAT@joglab.com (put THECAT out)). · Asking (and please consider this an ask!) for volunteers (special skill or time) to help spread the word or help out (please email volunteersTHECAT@joglab.com (put THECAT out)) Hopefully JogLab.com will have a lasting impact for many types of learner and make teaching even more fun. Please email me if you can be of any help or would like a colour printed poster sent to you or are interested in a JogLab t-shirt. Any constructive comments/ support/ help very gratefully received. Thanks a million, Dan Weaver Email danTHECAT@joglab.com (put THECAT out) Web: www.JogLab.com , http://danofweaver.googlepages.com

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz moderation
Post description: I am getting repeated requests from teachers asking about how to send quizzes for pre-moderation, and quiz results for post moderation, so they can use quiz for online exams. I am wondering which forum is best to discuss this as I think it is probably something needed by many higher education institutes and it might be that a tool could be developed to assist with the proccess of moderation of exams. If we can get a discussion going, then we might be able to scope what is required. The request seems to be that for pre-exam moderation you need to export a view of the quiz that shows all the questions with the right and wrong answers, as well as all the feedback and score related to each question. For post-exam moderation there needs to be a way to pick out three participants results (top, middle, bottom) and export them to give to the moderator. It might be that the best export method is to .pdf into pre-exam moderation file and a post-exam moderation file. Is anyone else interested in a tool like this? What would be important to your learning institute? I have discussed with someone from another institute, they call the "moderator" the "examiner" so the terms might need some further thought. Also she suggests it would be good for the person receiving the file to be able to pretend to take the exam so they see it as the student would (particularly if questions and/or answers are randomised). Looking forward to hearing from others.

Post title: Apple being sued under French law for poor HTML5 support in iOS
Post description: In my email today, this link: http://www.recode.net/2016/10/7/13201832/apple-sued-ios-browser-limits "A Frenc h maker of open-source software said Friday it is suing Apple in an effort to get the company to make iOS more supportive of Web standards. At least Apple no longer requires third-party browsers to use a slower engine than the one used by its own Safari, something it did until iOS 8. But Nexedi says the mobile version of Safari lags behind Apple’s desktop version as well as other browsers in adhering to HTML5 and other standards. Apple did not i mmediately respond to a request for comment" -Derek

Post title: Supermemo | Spaced repetition
Post description: Just curious is anyone has looked at implementing anything like spaced repetition ( which is AKA distributed practice) etc in Moodle. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SuperMemo https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_practice https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spaced_repetition A quote: Spaced repetition is a learning technique that incorporates increasing intervals of time between subsequent review of previously learned material in order to exploit the psychological spacing effect . Alternative names include spaced rehearsal , expanding rehearsal , graduated intervals , repetition spacing , repetition scheduling , spaced retrieval and expanded retrieval . [1] http://digitalpromise.org/2015/01/22/ask-the-cognitive-scientist-distributed-practice/ -Derek

Post title: Moodle Moot Albuquerque Materials
Post description: Many thanks to everyone who attended, worked, helped, presented and in any other way was invovled with the Moot in Albquerque. I will send out an email message to all of the attendees with a link, as well as post a message to the Moodle Moot Albuquerque forum , the general forum and anywhere else someone requests that I post the link. I recently posted a very similar message to the Moodle Moot Albuquerque Discussion forum, and thought that this would be useful to be posted here. I apologize to those who are enrol(l)ed to both forums. Thanks again to everyone, I will post the finished files as soon as they are ready. jon

Post title: Hot potatoes

I suppose the real question is - is there a purest camp that sticks with moodle and nothing else, and a camp that use anything (and everything) ? I am asking for some advice here - Would the best way for me to really learn Moodle be by having a trest site set up and then work with it to understand  - then i will probably have some questions , comments, postings etc to add to discussions. Would really appreciate some advice (Incidently Moodle is my e-immersion site for my assignments and i am expected to be here IMMERSING!!) Cheers - Osman Sadeck (Ossie)

Forum Post: 
Post title: First International Conference on Information and Communication Technologies for Education and Training
Post description: TICET 2012 Call for papers Papers can be written in Arabic , French , or English . Information and Communications Technology (ICT) is increasing becoming an important means for education and training due to its ability and flexibility to enrich the education and training. It has become an important topic for adoption and development from officials and decision-makers. The purpose of TICET 2012 conference is to bring together many leading experts and researchers specialized in the Education and Training Technologies (ETT) from worldwide/global/international, to present their researches, studies, expertise and experiences, in order to: 1) Gain awareness of the latest developments and challenges related to ETT. 2) Case studies of the use of ETT in academia and Industry. TICET 2012 conference focuses on the following aspects related to ETT: Studying the past international experiences (in the past), Exploring the current outstanding issues and associated developments (at present), Exploring the prospects and associated initiatives and international projects (in future), Studying the use of ETT in the Arab world (between past, present and future). TICET 2012 conference intends to study the relationship between ETT ( as a means and as a subject ) and the following issues: The development of scientific research, The development of educational curricula and training, Planning and implementation of operational, educational and training policies. More >>> https://sites.google.com/site/errakmia28/1-11

Forum Post: 
Post title: Emotional Intelligence Training on Moodle
Post description: We would like to take this opportunity to inform our fellow Moodlers about our new public online course in Emotional Intelligence training. This course (of course) runs on Moodle. This course has now been under development since July 2004. Our selection of Moodle as the LMS for all our courses has turned out to be a huge bonus to the project. While this is a commercial project we are doing it more from our hearts than from any financial incentive. We hope however that the project will at least pay its own way. We have managed to integrate Moodle as our e-campus into a conventional HTML web site, near seamlessly and with very few problems. At this stage we are using 100% standard Moodle but the plan is to customise certain parts of the program to better suit our needs. We are therefore hoping to be able to offer some code snippets and maybe even some complete modules back to the Moodle community . Since Dan Golemans best selling book on Emotional Intelligence appeared about 10 years ago, the subject has intrigued and frustrated people. Most of the frustration results from the lack of any reliable method for developing Emotional Intelligence. We believe our training courses will address this issue. Also, as far as we are aware, we are the first to ever attempt this type of practical training on line. Our first course will be available from Wed 16 th March and other more advanced courses will be available latter in 2005. We are probably biased but we happen to think that our Introduction To Emotional Intelligence training course at $69.00 USD is very good value for money. The site address is www.fifthstate.com

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle in the Chemistry Classroom
Post description: This summer the DivChed Committee on Computers in Chemical Education (CCCE) is hosting a ConfChem (online conference) on using Moodle in the Chemistry Classroom. We're seeking teachers or IT personel from all levels and areas that would like to share their Moodle expereience with our chem ed community by "authoring" a digital paper on their topic. Check out the announcement below and contact me if you have any questions or would like to submit a "paper" to conference. Authors and participants do not need to be members of ACS nor is there a fee to participate (you will need to create a free account with CCCE to participate). Announcing the Summer 2013 ConfChem Teaching and Learning Chemistry with Moodle Moodle (Modular Object-Oriented Dynamic Learning Environment) is an open-source Course  Management System (CMS) that can be used to create effective online learning sites. This conference will highlight how instructors at all levels have successfully used Moodle to teach chemistry and in turn made an impact on their students' learning. Papers will highlight the following topics: Innovative ways to use Moodle in the chemistry classroom. Ways to integrate Moodle into your existing curriculum Simple modifications or add-ons to Moodle which add exceptional value to teaching chemistry. Conference participants will also have a chance to demo the resources discussed and set up their own free courses using ChemEd DL’s Moodle server Anyone interested in submitting a paper should contact Linda Fanis (by replying to this post), or Janice Tomasik. Relevant Dates: May 3rd 2013- Deadline for papers May 31st  2013- Beginning of conference

Forum Post: 
Post title: Unique way to help Hurricane Katrina victims
Post description: I wanted to come up with a way to personally reach out and touch the victims of Hurricane Katrina.  My solution:  get as many people as possible to write personal but anonymous letters of encouragement and support to give to those in shelters.  Many tens of thousands are housed within 200 miles of my home. The result: www.letterofhope.com .  The site has a pdf file containing everything you need to write a letter, send it to "Letter of Hope," and, hopefully get a personal reply from the storm victim who receives it.  I can produce a group package with an organization's name and city on the letterhead. Within 3 days of operation, I have received commitments for over 2,000 letters from individuals, companies, churches, and schools.  I have also received commitments from social and religious organizations to deliver letters that will cover over 38,000 evacuees. I need the MOODLE community's help.  Please consider writing a "Letter of Hope."  If you represent a business, school, church, social club or other organization, go to "How Can I Help!" on the main menu to see how to request a customized group package.  Also, please email everyone you know and tell them about this project.  "Word of email" is the best and most effective way for me to get the word out. MOODLErs in outside the US can participate!  I have a physician in London who is organizing a letter writing campaign! Thank you for anything that you can do to assist these people who have lost so much. Please feel free to contact me either by replying to this post, or by email:  help@letterofhope.com.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can we have a "My Forum" , "Favorites Forum" or Personal Forum?
Post description: What I mean is that frequently we come across that Forum posting that just solves the problem that has kept you up for two nights -- like how to activate the main menu in a new 1.5 installation, or just something you think you would like to keep and read later -- and so I think it would be great if I could just click on a save button. The save button would bring me to a page where I could create a new category or save it in an old category. Let's say I'm mainly interested in two forums or just a couple of threads, I could re-create those and save it in the appropriate one. The Forums are awfully big and having some way to "edit" them individually seems like a good idea. Having the messages come to you as e-mails (in order to save them) is possible but a little overwhelming -- I've tried it. Also, we can make these personal forums public, so that if I know someone is interested in flash, for example, and I haven't been following the forums for awhile, I might check to see what he has collected. Perhaps we could also great smaller, more intimate groups. Got the idea from photo sites that let you create your own album. You spend a lot of time looking for the right picture but you are not ready to buy, so you save the picture (just the link obviously) in your own album for future reference. An idea?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Free 2GB "moodler.com" Email Accounts for moodlers
Post description: Hi Everyone, In the spirit of giving back to the moodle community, I would like to share free moodler.com email accounts as a unique and fun way for us to show our moodler spirit. These 2GB email accounts are powered by Google. I had signed up with Google for their offering of hosted email for domains and now am able to offer a limited number of accounts to any moodler that may be interested. The email interface is very similar to Google's regular GMail web pages and has GMAIL features like Chat and searching. You can also access your moodler.com email through email clients like Outlook. Your email address would be chosen_name@moodler.com . There is no commercial intent, by me, with this offering. Like GMail, Google does place some text ads on the web interface of your email web pages. I do not receive any revenue whatsoever even if you happen to click any of the Google text ads. This is how Google is able to offer this free service to domains. I hope that this can be a fun tool for those that sign up. I currently have a limited amount of available slots, as determined by Google, so please limit your requests to one account. To sign up, please go to: http://moodler.com . Thanks. Rich

Forum Post: 
Post title: A few thoughts on e-portfolio with reference to emerging new UK ICT qualifications.
Post description: I've been working at introducing e-portfolio to our Key Stage 3
students, and am now taking in only work handed in through our Moodle
from these pupils. The rationale for not doing this with KS4 is that they are taking the
Applied GCSE course, so their evidence still needs to printed, fairly
obvious... Anyway, e-portfolio through Moodle or other online CMS or V/MLE for me has several advantages: 1.  Reduction in printing costs 2.  A reduction in working time for teacher when marking.  I'm much more efficient working onscreen than with bundles of paper. 3.  Integration with other methods of communication.  Our kids now
communicate via text, chat room and message board as much as they do in
any other fashion.  It makes sense for work (not just ICT work) to be
submitted and edited in the same fashion. 4.  Ease of storage and retrieval for the student.  Granted there are
limitations in terms of learning where file and folder structure is
concerned to a degree if the students work mainly through the Journal
(now assignment in 1.5) system as my pupils do, but it saves valuable
time for less able students when the teacher knows exactly where to find the previous lesson 's work for continuation. 5.  As above, ease of access to work in progress for the teacher. 6.  Access to work and lesson content from home. 7.  Easy moderation for the department, without the need for face-to-face meeting time.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Response to "Research on Ecstasy Clouded by Errors" by Belladonna Dioszegi
Post description: Response by Belladonna Dioszegi on "Research on Ecstasy is Clouded by Errors" by Donald G. McNeil Jr. New York Times writer Donald G. McNeil responds to Dr. Ricaurte 's scientific studies on Ecstasy. According to Mr. McNeil's sources, these studies were highly inadequate and inaccurate, where a particular study was even retracted due to a mix up in labels. Many of Dr Ricaurte's mentors, fellow scientists, and examinees are quoted throughout the article, all admitting Dr. Ricaurte's methods and results to be not quite up to par. From postcards showing holes in brains of excessive users to claiming Ecstasy causes the tremors of Parkinsonism, Dr. Ricaurte is proven wrong on every front. The very first paragraph draws the readers in by identifying a well known, costly study preformed on primates to be completely invalid, stating the labels on methamphetamines and Ecstasy were mixed up. “What a comical mistake”, I thought, and continued reading. Mr. McNeil backs up his first statement by proceeding to give examples of other work the Dr. has published and the comments of other professionals and scientists familiar with Ricaurte. All of which either make claims against the Dr.'s results or his sloppy methods. It would seem that everything Dr. Ricaurte has done or said is in some way comical and hard to take seriously. The article concludes with a study on two male patients who took a large amount of Ecstasy, among other drugs. The patients stated they were jet lagged and sedated as the tests were preformed, and that it was a biased exam that seemed bent on proving they had some sort of brain damage. Despite the 4 years of heavy drug use, one man is a graduate in Chemistry at “a leading university”, and the other works at a law firm and “is in line for a federal job”. With not a single sense of praise or credibility included, I am left to wonder how a man supposedly so incompetent could be taken seriously; or is this portrayal of Dr. Ricaurte unfair and more belittling than he deserves? Based on my own lack of knowledge on Dr. Ricaurte, and Mr. McNeil's known credibility, I am immediately enticed to take McNeil's word for it, at first. Then the five pages of Dr. Ricaurte's petty claims and quotes of others down talking him, it starts to feel like just a negative buildup against Dr. Ricaurte, and becomes hard to take seriously. For the man to be a ranking scientist, how can all of his methods be less than desirable? Mr. McNeil makes no effort to a counterargument, giving Dr. Ricaurte no saving grace. The information provided seems accurate, but I would have preferred it to include some positive aspects in the Dr.'s research, so I could better form my own opinion on him. Despite the one-sided opinions portrayed, the article is well written and an intriguing read. I particularly found the short paragraph explaining the medical use of Ecstasy to be interesting. It was often used to help patients with trauma or anxiety talk about the event or their upsetting experience with ease, without the sleep inducing effects a sedative would create. In 1985, when Ecstasy was outlawed, this productive use for the drug ceased to be practiced for fear of prosecution.
