Forum Post: 
Post title: New Curriculum Mapping Block in development
Post description: Greetings, The purpose of this post is to inform the Moodle community that we are close to completing a new Moodle block that is designed to facilitate the design of competency based curricula. This work has been funded through a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation grant and is about two years in the making. The tools will support several functions: * Design of curriculums maps relating Competencies (a.k.a. educational goals), Professional Abilities (a.k.a. learning objectives), Learning Activities , and Assessments. * Submission of learning activities (a.k.a. lesson plans) by educators with associated searchable metadata . * Review of submitted materials by an editorial team, with support for revision cycles. * Searching and browsing of curriculum maps and their related learning object repositories. * Rating of learning objects by editorial staff and/or public browsers via a star rating system. * Checking out materials from the learning object repositories via a shopping cart model. * Packaging of selected curricula items, with a dynamically created curriculum description including links to learning activities and assessments. * Tracking of downloads and follow up surveying of users.

Post title: Moodle presentation materials
Post description: Hi fellow moodlers, I've been asked to give a presentation about Moodle for a group of university professors from different European universities which are members of a research group I'm involved in. As I'm preparing the slides and the structure of my presentation I thought I would ask for the help of other members of the community with more experience than me. I know many of you have participated in events to promote Moodle or to talk about specific aspects of Moodle. Are there any helpful tips that you can offer? I would be very grateful for any materials that you could share with me. I know there are some official Moodle slides that I can use (and I will probably make use of them), but if you have created additional slides that can be useful to make certain points about Moodle or that provide other important information, I would really appreciate it if you could share them with me. Of course, I'm going to use my own Moodle courses to illustrate the specific uses I make of the different modules, but if you have any other materials besides slides that can show original and creative uses of Moodle (some interesting use of a module or activity such as a glossary, for instance), I would also welcome them in my presentation. Thanks in advance. Josep M.

Forum Post: 
Post title: More questions about Blackboard patent
Post description: I guess I seem to keep bringing this up, but I have to work with Blackboard, so I get to read their communications every week.  It's starting to resemble what I imagine a plastered and stoned lawyer would sound like.  Anyway, now they have a FAQ up: http://www.blackboard.com/patent/FAQ2 This part doesn't sit right with me: "For example, claim 1 in the Blackboard patent describes a course based-system
with user computers where each user is “capable of having predefined
characteristics indicative of multiple predetermined roles in the system.” 
Consequently, a system must provide for “multiple predetermined roles” for each
user according to the claim and, likewise, every other element (or its
equivalent) of claim 1 must be embodied in the system in question for claim 1 to
be infringed.  This detailed element-by-element analysis is necessary to
evaluate the scope of the patent. Be wary of any analysis of this or any other
patent which does not involve an element-by-element discussion of the claims as
each element is a limitation on the scope of a patent. " So, in order for someone to infringe on this patent, they have to meet the 34 elements (if I read correctly) that are dependent on claim 1 to be in violation?  So, Blackboard wrote a patent that someone amazingly fits their top competitors?  Seems a little scarey to me. Or how about this: "The inherent complexity of patent law is no doubt a leading cause of confusion
about the Blackboard patent. "

Forum Post: 
Post title: moodle forum allowing yahoo etc email?
Post description: This moodle forum does not allow Yahoo email addresses when registering. So I had to use my company email. I can see a reason for this, to avoid ' spam ', but because I subscribe to forum discussions my company email inbox is flooded with forum messages, which is a problem when I travel and check email on a mobile phone or other mobile device. For this reason I use my Yahoo email when subscribing to foirums and discussion groups - it lets me deal with direct work issues that require immediate attention on my company email, and look at discussions that are interesting but not urgent using the Yahoo email. Unfortunately the decision in this forum to not allow Yahoo addresses means I am stuck with a flooded email inbox or have to unsubscrbe (which I don't really want to do, but will have to). Wouldn't it be reasonable to allow Yahoo email addresses? I subscribe to a lot of specialised discussion groups and none disallow Yahoo addresses. Chris

Forum Post: 
Post title: Network manager / learning technologist
Post description: Whilst I'm looking after the strategic side of ICT at whole school (ie
prep and senior) level in my new job as head of Alton Convent Prep , there's no way that I have time
to do the fun, hands-on stuff anymore (except perhaps for a
webserver...), and so Senior + Prep schools are now looking for a network manager now to take care of the day to day management and maintenance stuff, and contribute
to some of the strategic decision making. Here's the blurb: Alton Convent
School is seeking to appoint a network manager,
to take responsibility for the day to day management and maintenance of the
school’s computer networks, to provide technical support to staff and pupils,
assist with hands-on training, and contribute to decisions on the development
of ICT within the school. Applicants must be committed to prioritizing the
needs of learning, teaching, administration and management over technological
aspects, and seeking the best possible return on investment. Some experience
with SIMS and/or Open Source applications and approaches would be additional
recommendations, as would recent experience of the education sector. For
candidates with vision and creativity this post offers considerable scope to
explore innovative ways of delivering cutting-edge provision for ICT. Now, this isn't a Moodle job per se , but when we start looking at setting up a VLE, I think I know which one we'll pick... That said, I'm sure there are folks around here who could do this, or might know someone who could. Anyhow, I've uploaded the details and would be happy to chat with anyone interested in applying. Salary is 'dependant on qualifications and experience' but we're thinking about £20K+. The school has c460 on roll, and around 70-80 computers at the moment. Alton is a (rather nice) market town in Hampshire, SE England.

Post title: Moodle and iSAMS
Post description: Hi all, I work at an Independent school here in the UK and we use a system called iSAMS for our student and course administration. I have spent the past few months developing a system to synchronise all courses and course enrolments from this system to Moodle. I thought that people using iSAMS may well find it useful, but there is no real reason why it could not be adapted fairly easily for any other Student Management System which runs on a Microsoft SQL Server . It is a three part blog post, and you can read each one here: Part 1 - http://bit.ly/U4ACdo Part 2 - http://bit.ly/1rFbVDl Part 3 - http://bit.ly/14WUsgD Happy reading! Jon

Forum Post: 
Post title: CK-ERP v.0.31.1 released with Moodle 2.2.2 connector
Post description: Hi, folks, I have posted a new release, v.0.31.1, of CK-ERP, at SourceForge.Net, http://sourceforge.net/projects/ck-erp . New features include, Support for My sql i, Support for Sqlite3 Portuguese, Korean, Japanese, Hindi, Indonesian, Vietnamese, Russian translation Updated Chinese, Spanish, French, German translation Relaxation of restriction on display language must be the same as installation language As far as I can determine, a Moodle+CK-ERP environment is most useful to teachers, school administrators and other educational professionals. While Moodle supports the front-end elearning process, CK-ERP provides facilities to manage backoffice routines of a school, eg, procurement of supplies and ledger bookkeeping. All these happen within the familiar Moodle environment. CK-ERP is an open source educational / accounting / MRP / ERP / CRM system that runs on top of multiple middlewares. It comprises 32 modules - Contact Management, Customer Relationship Management, Customer Self Service, Vendor Relationship Management, Material Requirement Planning, Warehouse, Inventory, Service, Accounting Ledger, Bank Reconciliation, Accounts Payable, Accounts Receivable, Purchase Order, Sales Order, Quotation, POS for Cashier, POS for Manager, Human Resources, Staff Self Service, Payroll, Administration, Internationalization, Access Control, Data Import, Teacher, Counsellor, Student, Applicant, Family, Registrar, Edu Administration and Volunteer Management. Please report error and suggestion to the discussion group / mailing list, CK-ERP-en(at)googlegroups.com or CK-ERP-zh_CN(at)googlegroups.com . General history and expected development is available at the discussion group's Archive. Demo and info site: http://ck-erp.org Download site: http://sourceforge.net/projects/ck-erp Cheers, Wu Chiu Kay, aka CK Wu, aka CK (CK is the preferred alias) Hong Kong

Forum Post: 
Post title: GED and equivalency testing in the 3rd world
Post description: I just came back from two weeks in Belize. Mostly pleasure. But some business too. I spoke with the headmaster of a four room k-8 school deep in the rainforest, 180 miles from the coast. In Belize, students who want to finish high school have to travel to a boarding school. Because--for the most part--there are no local high schools. That headmaster wants to expand his constituency to adult education. Few Belizeians finish high school. And many now wish they had. But they want an accredited diploma of some sort. They aren't interested in education for its own sake. They want better jobs. Employers want certified credentials of some sort. And that's a problem. Because well-regarded programs with good curricula and teachers who interact with the students can cost as much as $2000 per student per year. And the Belizeians who need better education don't have that kind of money.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Australia 2020 Summit; Promoting Moodle
Post description: I know advertising isn't allowed but I'm sure you won't mind if I mention this Moodle promotion. It's an email to the Aussie PM's office (and a few others), after reading the interim report for the Australia 2020 Summit . I'd be interested in whether anyone thinks it's worth giving it a big(ger) push. (and if I've got my facts right). Well the Summit is over and we have ideas about WHAT needs to be done. Now the challenge is HOW to go about it. Most of the pieces are in place, but scattered all around. So let me point at the two of the most obvious pieces. The first is the initiative by edna - education network Australia. It’s called me.edu.au. http://me.edu.au/ This IS the basis of a citizen’s learning account. It’s still in beta and edna will probably not have considered its wider application. But with a little encouragement it could provide a way for every citizen to have a log in to many interactive .edu.au and gov.au services. It just starts as a log in to edna's network. The second is a piece of software that could, with a little work, act as a good learning environment- i.e. the online forums. This Aussie invention is used as a courseware host in many .edu institutions around the world. With a little tweaking it could provide a good introduction to a citizen’s online learning. More importantly it will encourage teachers and students to get involved and learn it while communicating. It’s called a Moodle. http://moodle.org/sites/ Most of the things we would all like to see For Australia in 2020, and the infrastructure that it will demand, are now down to how fast people government departments might pick up the interactive and open culture. Wikipedia is the best example. 15 people are responsible for a network of information, which is contributed to, and demanded by, around 40 million people per month (take all numbers with a pound of salt). Progress needn’t be as daunting as you might think. Australia has a lot of very bright people here who would like to contribute, if we could just get conversations like this onto a well organised group of forums and help them find one another. This can be done very quickly, as many of them would like to get involved but have never been given the means or opportunity. Thank you for the Summit ; you’ve set the old media stage. Now the new interactive one must be set. So could I ask you to respond to this little message as though I, like many others, have been working for years on understanding how lots of the pieces and people could come together ? (once we had a government with the right attitudes). Thankfully, now we have a government with the right attitudes.

Post title: Community Moodle Feedback
Post description: Hello Moodle Users, My name is Mark, I am currently in my final year studying for a computer sciences degree. I have chosen to do my final year dissertation on VLE's (Virtual Learning Environments). To begin my project I want to critically analyse what is already out there (moodle being one of the main VLE's), so what I ask for is general feedback from Moodle users. This can be disadvantages you have stumbled across, advantages and even your views on how 'you' would make the system better as a whole. I would normally have done this as a questionnaire, however I do not know of any institutions round my area dealing with moodle. It is important I can gather this information from users who have currently used this system day out and in and have had many experience with it. As it is also important to gather it from first time users, as they may have more critique to add. So please add any feedback and views on moodle, I have already got a few views however lacking the real community voice. Remember this is just general feedback so just bullet point whatever you think is good, bad or what you think you could do to make it better. From this information I can further assess Moodle with reliable and honest information and not just my opinion. Many thanks, Mark

Post title: Forbidden Fruit (funny, totally off-topic)
Post description: A couple of months ago we had a 48 hs film competition in NZ. In Wellington, 70 teams registered, and Penny and I were in one of them, doing some production/editing. The rules are that you are given a character, line, prop and genre on Friday 7pm, and have to hand in a 7 minute film (video actually) at 7pm Sunday. Sharp (this year, 2 teams missed the deadline by mere seconds). All the teams get the same character, line and prop. There's a random draw for genre. We got: - a character named Bodil de Rezney, animal lover - a banana for prop - the line: "please don't do that" - and mockumentary for genre The result is here and I think it's really funny, if a bit irreverent -- (warning, may contain tasteless humour):

Forum Post: 
Post title: Good news from the EFF.org - Privacy Badger plugin for Firefox and Chrome
Post description: EFF has just announced a new privacy protecting plugin for Firefox and Chrome. What is Privacy Badger? Privacy Badger is a browser add-on that stops advertisers and other third-party trackers from secretly tracking where you go and what pages you look at on the web.  If an advertiser seems to be tracking you across multiple websites without your permission , Privacy Badger automatically blocks that advertiser from loading any more content in your browser.  To the advertiser, it's like you suddenly disappeared. Install it now at: https://www.eff.org/privacybadger Why should you care? Here's an excerpt from a news story in the UK publication Private-Eye: Besides safekeeping, such an intrusive industry raises another question: is sensitive personal information now mere merchandise? Most UK data brokers have sense enough to hide their creepier practices, but there are exceptions. Clear Data Ltd, based in Herefordshire, advertises lists of old people ("over 65 and mostly female") waiting to be targeted by quack doctors, boiler room conmen, telephone raffle operators, and pyramid schemers in need of credulous targets. Data Broker Limited, from Cheshire, caters to predatory lenders — "[if you're] offering new loans to people With poor credit history and [county court Judgements against them], Databroker have the largest list related to loans for postal, telephone, mobile, SMS, email and social media campaigns". You can read the rest here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=258810#p1122926 Seems worthwhile to at least try to reduce how much your learners', teachers', and admins' personal information and browsing habits are exposed to such dubious practices.

Post title: Course in elementary statistics for psychology
Post description: Pardon me if I am posting this in the wrong place, but I have to risk it. I have been looking at Moodle for some months, and have used in a very primitive manner in one short courses and like it very much.  Now, I am planning to use Moodle in a series of courses on statistics, data analysis, and methodology at the faculty of psychology at my university.  Therefore, I am trying to locate useful material on the net, especially in respect to sets of questions or item banks that might be useful.  Google is not very useful, at least not in respect to the search terms I have used so far. The textbook I am using at the moment is Howitt & Cramer, "An Introduction to Statistics in Psychology", and it seems that the publisher does not have anything useful to contribute in this respect. So: Does anybody have any useful suggestions or pointers? Tom

Forum Post: 
Post title: The most important thing I have ever learnt in my life
Post description: The most important think I have ever learnt in my life is just to " listen ". Most people think they already do, so did I, but most of the time we are just " hearing ". To listen is to think about what others say, being able to change our own thinking. That is really important. The most important thing to succeed in business is to listen to the customer. They are realising nowadays that this is the best way to manage a company and the best marketing strategy, also. The best pedagogical theories in education , such as constructivism , just say that we have to listen to what the student knows, and then help him to improve his knowledge. The less bad political organization today, called democracy, is based on listening to the people and leting them choose who is going to rule the government . The most important method for acting , proposed by Stanislavsky, is a whole process that starts just by listening to everything. It is used by all the actors from the Actor's Studio, many of them being Hollywood stars. Psychology is the art of solving problems by listening to the people and understanding them. To feel happy it is important to listen to ourselves, to our feelings and thinkings and also to listen to others.

Post title: National seminar on Open Source: Opportunities in entrepreneurship Ver 2.0
Post description: Open Source software is catching fancy of millions of technocrats around the world. A lot of emphasis is being laid on developing applications based on Open Source, which are either free or are available at nominal costs. This is coming out as a big opportunity to developers and users alike. It is estimated that by 2015, Open Source Market will assume 37% market share of overall development scenario. This needs for deep introspe ction both at micro and macro level so that the true potential of Open Source can be explored and entrepreneurs are prepared with right mindsets. INMANTEC had successfully organized first seminar on “Open Source: Opportunities in Entrepreneurship” on March 13, 2010. This seminar was a huge attraction among open source professionals and budding entrepreneurs. The glimpse of the same can be accessed from here. Keeping the same fervor, INMANTEC is organizing second seminar in this series entitled “Open Source: Opportunities in Entrepreneurship Ver 2.0” on February 15, 2012 at INMANTEC, Ghaziabad. Through this seminar, we wish to address following issues impeding growth of entrepreneurs in Open Source: Entrepreneurship through open source Capital for entrepreneurship venture on open source Marketing of open source products & services Customization of open source software To provide hands on experience in different technologies, we will be conducting workshops on different open source technologies:- Spoken Tutorial [ Free Workshop ]. Open Source OS: Ubuntu ( A Separate session on Ubuntu for Schools. ) Game development using Open Source. Content management using Wordpress Open Source ERP. Moodle 2.0: A Course Management System Android Apps Development. Open Java [ Free Workshop ] Library Automation using NewGenLib For more information please connect to http://inmantec.edu/os2012

Forum Post: 
Post title: anonymized Moodle student usage data
Post description: Hello, I am a student at RWTH Aachen, Germany, and I am working on my diploma thesis with the title: ReST: A recommender system for teachers based on educational data mining. I develop a stand alone recommender system for teachers which can be applied to any learning management system like Moodle or L2P (L2P is a LMS based on MS Sharepoint and is used at the RWTH Aachen). The recommender system shall use different data mining techniques on LMS usage data like regression to give teachers some information how their own LMS usage impacts the usage behaviour of the students. Clustering algorithms shall give teachers an overview about different student groups based on their LMS usage. The recommender system uses tools like WEKA and KEEL. Unfortunately my university can only give me usage data of the courses but no marks - without this very important attribute I cannot use (for example subgroup discovery) algorithms to give teachers feedback about their students LMS usage and the students learning success. Therfore I am asking for students' Moodle usage datasets I can analyze in my thesis. The data may not be randomized because I need plausible data. Does anyone know where I can get such data?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Microsoft meter patent
Post description: Another really innovative idea appears to have come out of Microsoft, according to a patent application revealed around Christmas. Their "pay-per-use" PC scheme would presumably have you feeding currency into a computers bill acceptor mechanism so that you can continue to use YOUR computer. Isn't that innovative (as MS understands the term)? This may sound alarmist but I'm betting some version of this hair-brained idea will see the light of day, along with an Internet that is no longer packet neutral, possibly in 2009. Linux on the desktop and the Mac OS are great ways to avoid a Microsoft taxation scheme that may be foisted on consumers soon.

Post title: Looking for feedback on a new shopping cart solution
Post description: First off, if this is not an appropriate topic for this forum, I apologize. I'm just looking for some feedback and was hoping to find some folks that may want to check this out. We are looking for folks to give us feedback and then potentially be beta users of a new platform we are launching shortly called LMSCheckout. It is a shopping cart solution that will include full integration for Moodle that has a workflow similar to using Shopify, only we automate the enrollment process between the systems. It has features like coupons, tax management, course reviews and ratings and a self-service theming tool. We are doing a couple sneak peak events next week so we can start gathering feedback and attempt to line up beta users. We are even doing a drawing for a couple of attendees to win a free subscription to the service once it launches. If you have any interest, we'd love to invite you out to take a look. You can register here: https://cysalesteam.com/envisiontel/category/connect-your-salesteam-live-webinars We would appreciate any feedback that anyone cares to share. Hope to see you there. Thanks

Forum Post: 
Post title: Video Codec's again
Post description: I don't know a lot, I'm basically just an end user, but this question does affect us regularly. Mozilla's blog , two comments: "To that end, we are developing Daala , a fully open next generation codec." "Cisco has announced today that they are going to release a gratis , high quality, open source H.264 implementation — along with gratis binary modules compiled from that source and hosted by Cisco for download . This move enables any open source project to incorporate Cisco’s H.264 module without paying MPEG LA license fees. From https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2013/10/30/video-interoperability-on-the-web-gets-a-boost-from-ciscos-h-264-codec/ And the Daala site: http://www.xiph.org/daala/ "Daala is the code-name for a new video compression technology. The effort is a collaboration between Mozilla Foundation, Xiph.Org Foundation and other contributors." Not sure at all what this means in practical or real terms, but I was interested. I did think of titling this post "More on the video codec wars" -Derek

Post title: IMS Learning Impact 2009

Post title: The complexities of video
Post description: There is lots happening in the video world (and some good work here with plug-gable players: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-38158 )  I hope people who know can keep us up with the play as far as Moodle is concerned, maybe provide some clarity about some of the options. Some random mes that arrived last week, from the JSPlayer blog on Flash going away in Chrome on December 6th: https://www.jwplayer.com/blog/deprecation-flash/ ) I quote: In December 6th, Google will release Chrome 55, giving more power to visitors of your site, allowing them to make a choice if they want to enable Flash or not by clicking the Flash object in the page. Previously, Flash became click-to-play when it was below a size threshold ; in Chrome 55, Flash objects will not load if the user dismisses them. Chrome tracks the user’s decision per domain . Chrome is also adding three settings that will make it even easier for users to disable Flash: [Default] Ask before allowing sites to run Flash Allow sites to run Flash without prompting HTML5 by Default – Block sites from running Flash without prompting There are similar settings available in Apple’s Safari 10 for Mac OS, with their default being HTML5 . With regards -Derek

Forum Post: 
Post title: Random Wishlist: Grade Sliders and Word Viewer
Post description: Well, my "crazy end of semester" (and upcoming move to a strange land, 2,000 miles away from my current location) are preventing me from engaging more fully into Moodle's greatness. But, as I'm grading assignments, I've been taking headnotes about Moodle features. It might be useful for me to just throw them out of my head, even though they're not fully fleshed out (or intelligible). Some things I'd like to have in Moodle, which would make my life much easier. A viewer for Word files. And/or other file types used in assignments. This way, there wouldn't be much of a difference between "online text" and file- upload assignments. (Maybe students could elect to submit either an online text or a file upload!) It'd make things easier for students while allowing teachers to grade assignments in one simple interface. Sounds relatively easy to implement, and there might already be an add-on for this. A system to assign grades using sliders. Think rubrics, but less compartmentalised. My categories are put in decreasing order of importance (from insight to concision). And I do grade by giving relative weight to many of these (not all of them are relevant for every student's assignment). At this point, I basically "see" a series of sliders in my head as I grade. Assignments which are very insightful can easily get a full grade if everything else is at least decent. Assignments which have few other redeeming qualities may still be evaluated for concision. Altogether, my grading scheme is rather algorithmic, but the algorithm is quite difficult for me to explain (and I do realise I'm doing a rather bad job of explaining it now). So, having sliders would be very useful. I know some of the same effects could be achieved with drop-down menus for numeric values but the slider interface would, in itself, make things easier (direct feedback while grading). While I'm at it... A way for graders to separate grading and "releasing" (publishing) grades. You mark and grade an assignment but you only make the grades and feedback available at the end of the grading session. That way, you can "play around" with grading scenarios or simply compare assignments with one another. These are all very clear in my head but I'm having a hard time verbalising them. They would all make my life much easier and I'm sure some colleagues would find value in them. So, I'll surely revisit these issues later on but instead of writing them down as notes and procrastinating about fleshing them out, I decided to RERO . Cheers!

The ARGuing project created 'The Tower of Babel' Alternate Reality Game, using Moodle as the platform, to motivate secondary school students across Europe to learn languages with great success. Project website at http://www.arg-education.eu You can see a presentation on YouTube at (I have taken out the direct link as it caused problems in my previous post): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vd4rKnRSZY8 that includes some statistics and comments from teachers. The link to the Moodle platform is: http://ictthatworks.net:8080/moodle/ We will be presenting academic papers on the project at the forthcoming European Association for Games in Education conference in October, Graz, Austria and will be placing documentation on the project website as well later. Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle or moodle?
Post description: Which is correct Moodle with uppercase M or moodle with lowercase m ? I'm working on a presentation proposal with Tim Allen and we have some inconsistency in our spelling. Looking at the moodle site, the images all seem to have moodle with lowercase m, but the text all has Moodle with uppercase M. So which is it?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It is a value judgement, depending on your relationship to Moodle. If you believe Moodle is a brand, a special type of software that competes with BB and others, use Moodle. If you believe it is something normal and generic, then call it moodle. There is Jello and jello, Kleenex and kleenex, Aspirin and aspirin, Skype and skype (as in "I skyped my friend in Bosnia"). If your whole world of LMS is moodle, moodling is the act of creating and dialoguing with this world.
Comment 2: I have often used moodle with a small m, seeing as more of a generic thing. I was inclinded to forget that Martin Dougiamas holds copyright of the name "Moodle," which is registered as a trade mark in several countries. So as well as the belief there is also the legal aspect. Only approved Moodle partners can use the name in their domain name or in headlines on their web site. Timothy
Comment 3: Only approved Moodle partners can use the name in their domain name or in headlines on their web site. I didn't know that. What if a non-partner were to offer services such as installing and upgrading moodle ( with a lowercase m )? What about a teacher using moodle in thier domain name just for the students such as michealsmoodle dot com? I guess I'll talk with Tim Allen before making the final decision. Thanks for the info guys.
Comment 4: Dear Sean, the Linguist

Forum Post: 
Post title: what is sessiontimeout?
Post description: In the setup file of moodle it sets session life like this if (!empty($CFG->sessiontimeout)) { $ADODB_SESS_LIFE = $CFG->sessiontimeout; } But I can not find where is the $CFG->sessiontimeout. Whether this is defined somewhere? Please tell me.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: But in the php.ini it says session.gc_maxlifetime = 1440, means 24 minutes. What's the connection with that setup file?
Comment 2: It's stored in the database . You can set it through Site Administration/ Server /Session Handling It basically determines how long a person can be logged in and do nothing (no page loading) before they get automatically logged out. If you set this to low, it can cause students/teachers to lose work if they spend to long typing in a window (forum, assignment, providing feedback, etc.) before they submit their work. I have most of my sites set at 1 hour. Steve

Post title: IRS challenge to virtual space - lawyers alert!
Post description: I'm shocked. The IRS advance ruling on tax exemption for Beach College, a nonprofit corporation in California, is that it can't be a school because it doesn't have a "place." Specifically, a place where a regular faculty teaches a regular student body. We have the faculty (still waiting for the students), and Moodle. Has anyone else run into this problem? The IRS lady wants "court cases or revenue rulings" that would change her mind, and she needs me to respond ASAP. Please tell me if you have any experience here. Were any of you denied 501(c)3 educational status for not having a "place" of business?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Perhaps she should have looked the US DOE Technology plans in reference to the Florida Virtual High School. http://www.nationaledtechplan.org/stories.asp http://www.flvs.net/ or perhaps have her read this governement document on Virtual schools: http://www.nationaledtechplan.org/documents/Hassel-Terrell-VirtualSchools.pdf Isn't it funny how one branch of Government is so out of touch with another?
Comment 2: Those are good tips, Mark. They establish the right for public secondary schools. A college may be another proposition, but surely some Moodlers have gone through this process -- easily, I hope. Did I just get a new agent who isn't aware of the virtual worlds?

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to copyright a Lesson Plan??
Post description: Hello All! I have a few Lesson Plans I would like to copyright, but, not all the
material in the lesson plans is mine. The articles used in the lesson
plan are from newspapers and the internet. I use them in a classroom
exercise on "Science Reading". I
really want to just copyright the layout of the lesson plan and how I
used the articles in the lesson. I cannot figure out how to do this at
the bottom of the lesson plan so it is clear that I am not trying to
copyright all the contents of the Lesson Plan, just the layout and use
of the articles. Anyone have any suggestions as to how this should be written so the above is clear. My initial write for this was something like, © 2004 WP1. All rights and privileges retained by the creators of the Articles included in this lesson plan. This somehow does not " feel " right or look that good. All help and input about this will be appreciated. WP1
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Why bother - one only has to change one ot two aspects of the lession plan and there is a new copyright.  Your heading down the same pathway as Patents.  Hell I would be choofed if someone copied my lesson plan layout - that demonstrates you are onto somthing that is worthwhile in this educational marketplace. All I can say is that if you want to copyright your lesson plan - get a life.....  there are far more important things to worry about.
Comment 2: Hello Chris! QUOTE: "...Your heading down the same pathway as Patents.  Hell I would be choofed if someone copied my lesson plan layout - that demonstrates you are onto something that is worthwhile in this educational marketplace. All I can say is that if you want to copyright your lesson plan - get a life.....  there are far more important things to worry about." Chris Ainsworth I think I understand the reason for your comments about this, however, you do not know the reason why I need to do this.  I do not feel that I need to delineate the reasons in a public forum at Moodle .  Just the need or desire to do so.  I placed this post in the " Social Forum " to ask for for help not a judgement call about my life. I again request help from any Moodler who may have some experience with this. WP1
Comment 3: I am not sure you can copyright a lesson plan.  After all you would just be copying the layout of the plan.  There are tons of lesson plan formats.  Perhaps you should be focusing on copyrighting your lessons rather than the plan itself. Just thinkin...
Comment 4: Hi Rhonda! That is one of the reasons I asked for help with this.  When one copyrights a lesson plan, just what is one copyrighting?  Also, how does one indicate that the use of others' information is for example purposes and that one does not what to take any credit or responsibility for it? WP1
Comment 5: It is my understanding that you must give credit for the item that you are using, like a url where the item was used. That is only if you are an educator in a classroom and not in a public venue. If you are putting it on the internet or even showing it in an auditorium, it then is another issue.  Then if your lesson plan contains materials created by others you enter into the copyright infringement area.  Then the only way is with the author's permission . If you create a course and you have all original material, then you can copyright.  If you take stuff out of a textbook, then you are using someone else's works. Hope this helps.
Comment 6: Credit stealing can be a pain in the bum - and worse, however I think that copyrighting lesson plans is contra-moodle! You should probably be talking to a lawyer.
Comment 7: Here is a basic principle to go by... All writings are automatically copyrighted to the authors.  You do not need to do anything to establish a copyright. In other words, this posting is automatically copyrighted to me.  And the moodle code is copyright to Martin and colleagues.  Even if you do not write, "Copyright to author", it is still your copyright.  You can sell your copyright to a publisher if you wish (the Beatles sold their songs) or you can keep it.  Now besides copyright, licensing is another issue.  You can choose to release a writing, a lesson plan, or programming code into the public domain or to commercialize it. Assuming that you want to commercialize a lesson plan, I would do the following:  look at a textbook and copy the phrase they use to discourage photocopying.  For example,  " All rights reserved.  Please do not copy.  Support the author by purchasing this book/lesson plan."    How does that sound? Absolutely, this is an important discussion and one that Moodle is urgently dealing with as a new "Exchange" system is being created.  There will be room for both Moodle GPL content and Moodle commercial content to be exchanged.  Personally, I hope most content will be released as GPL, but I realize some teachers are not on a salary as I am, and need paid publications to support themselves.
Comment 8: You are absolutely correct about copyrights not having to be stated or legally put in place to be binding.  However, if you are serious about copyrighting material, then taking the legal steps will reduce your headaches quickly if you find someone using your materials. As long as the material you write on a forum or anywhere else is original, it can be copyrighted, but if you quote someone or use someone elses work, then it can't be because it is no longer original. Don't know if this is 100% accurate, but it is my two cents!
Comment 9: Just to add to Don' statement. Any work you create is automatically copyrighted. This will allow you some civil protection in case someone makes an unauthorized copy. There are some cases (stock photographers come in mind) in which you can register your work at the copyright office, at least in the U.S., as far as I recall. Registration allows you to seek punitive damaged in a civil suit. This will, using the example of photography, allow the creator to claim from the infringer more than just the time and materials for creating the content. If you have a novel way of presenting material or "method", you can trademark it. One example that comes to mind is a decision making process called "PrOACT" (TM) by Dr. Howard Raiffa. Nothing new in the actual content or process, it is just a package with a name. However, just putting a copyright notice on your homepage should be enough to let others know that you have decided not release it to the public domain.
Comment 10: Hello All! Thank you for your responses.  Plenty to think about. WP1
Comment 11: Except in terms of fair use. And you don't need to type out a copyright so long as the file was posted on a server (logged in). If the file is deleted,then you would likely have to print out the lesson plan along with the file path on the server enought to locate the server log entry. Hope that helps.
Comment 12: As I recollect, Don H., you are right. I was working for an intellectual property lawyer while studying technical writing in college. I recall some of the things he said about copyright that follow the same line of thought you seem to have above. I recall a few others things, one in particular that might shed some light on the controversy over copyrighting a lesson plan as distinguished from the lesson content. According to Tom Freiburg, a patent and trademark attorney here in San Francisco, any sequence of 6 or more words is copyrightable, which means to my understanding that the lesson plan, in the sense that the words/graphics are arranged in a certain order, is part of the copyright. One concern! I also read within this thread about using someone else's work. From my readings on various copyright websites http://www.utsystem.edu/ogc/intellectualproperty/present.htm#fucopies http://www.nolo.com/lawcenter/index.cfm/catID/804B85E3-9224-47A9-A7E6B5BD92AACD48/subcatid/2EB060FE-5A4B-4D81-883B0E540CC4CB1E you can quote another's works and attribute those works providing they fall within fair use rules. These rules contain a lot of grey areas, so it is always best to get written permission to use the quoted content within the lesson plan. Good luck.
Comment 13: As I recollect, Don H., you are right. I was working for an intellectual property lawyer while studying technical writing in college. I recall some of the things he said about copyright that follow the same line of thought you seem to have above. I recall a few others things, one in particular that might shed some light on the controversy over copyrighting a lesson plan as distinguished from the lesson content. According to Tom Freiburg, a patent and trademark attorney here in San Francisco, any sequence of 6 or more words is copyrightable, which means to my understanding that the lesson plan, in the sense that the words/graphics are arranged in a certain order, is part of the copyright. One concern! I also read within this thread about using someone else's work. From my readings on various copyright websites http://www.utsystem.edu/ogc/intellectualproperty/present.htm#fucopies http://www.nolo.com/lawcenter/index.cfm/catID/804B85E3-9224-47A9-A7E6B5BD92AACD48/subcatid/2EB060FE-5A4B-4D81-883B0E540CC4CB1E you can quote another's works and attribute those works providing they fall within fair use rules. These rules contain a lot of grey areas, so it is always best to get written permission to use the quoted content within the lesson plan. Lastly, as you say, once you publish the lesson plan on the web, it automatically is copyrighted; however, few systems that I know of log more than the mere fact that you published something on a certain day at a certain time. As such, formally copyrighting the material (lesson plan) has its merits. Unless the file (lesson plan) somehow gets deleted from your server , that file is labeled in the log. So as long as you can open the lesson plan from the server, it's copyrighted (i.e. you have a way of showing that you are the originator of that content on that day and time as shown by the file and the log. Only someone who can show that they originated the lesson plan before that can claim copyright ownership, but they can do that even if you file a copyright. So... I once liked a poem so much that I rewrote it with completely different content. I used the rhyme but I changed the content of the poem to express the thoughts I loved then, editing. I made sure that no sequence of original content existed beyond 5 words. So, I could copyright the poem. In other words, I think your lesson plan is safe so long as the file is logged onto the server. Good luck.

Comment 16: Hi, I would suggest going to Educause's website, http://www.educause.edu and look through their Resources area on copyright. Lot's of good information on copyright as it relates to education. Cheers, Bob
Comment 17: I have read that you obtain copyright on an original work at the moment it achieves physical manifestation. Thus it is not sufficient to have throught of your creation, you must actually create it, write it, paint it etc. If you are considering putting energy into copyrighting your work, consider your motives. Are you actually intendeing to make mondey directly out of it. What you will really do if you find out someone has breached your rights. Say (for example) you discover your creation hosted on a website on the other side of the world, pehaps with surrounding adverts and there is no attribution to you. (A situation that has happened to me). Are you actually going to be able or willing to enforce your rights across the globe and multiple juristictions? Consider an alternative plan, you clearly mark yourself as the author and creator and claim the copyright but you release it under some kind of license that allows reproduction (e.g. creative commons). Your work gets picked up, reproduced but you still get the credit. If you are fortunate your reputation spreads and your career opportunities  are increased.  I have written stuff and placed it on web sites with a licence for reproduction unchanged and as a result received a very nice trickle of revenue from the reputation that has built.

Post title: 5 reasons I LOVE moodle
Post description: Design Simply add big headers to show today's theme and objectives. I love this way of easily convey a visual sense of information hierarchy. You can create nice lists To articulate instructions To remind important points To list resources To define priorities Narrower lists are possible To show the plan To tell where we are Show what's coming next and the end point Adding buttons Use buttons instead of simple links. Especially to reuse older resources or activities .
And students love them. Read Review Test Show plan and icons Show the plan and give student rhythm for the activities . Student are much more aware of their progression. And it is even responsive on mobile! What's the problem Identify the points where you could improve the course design. File Now you try it yourself Go and get a few code snippets from bootstrap and try them on your Moodle. Submit Go a step beyond Watch how you can also add "calls to actions" and play with colors and icons. Learn All the tutorials I have created for my teachers are freely available on github with a Creative Commons licence . Moodle Design (github) You can even download a moodle course page with all the examples. I hope this will help the community using moodle to its limits 😀 Cheers

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to get my students to use my help forum without a crowbar?
Post description: I've been slowly experimenting with Moodle features over the past couple of years. So far, so good. Lessons, web pages, quizzes, grades, wikis, all pretty successful. I want to get some action on a forum or 2 between me and the students and between the students. I'm trying this in a web design class. So far no takers. I know there are students who do not ask questions in class that need to. And I would like to see some + interaction between them and my more skilled students. This seems like a natural vehicle. any suggestions on how to get this going appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Create a discussion topic question that is graded based on two criteria. The Q/A format works well for this. The student's personal response being 50% Require each student to comment on 2 other students responses with the quality or analysis and writing comments as the other %50 perhaps specific You will have to add activity to grade book manually but there is nothing like being graded on something to make a student do it. The other thing that helps is if you start the threads with instructions for example- Please post questions about week 1 assignments in this thread. All students are encouraged to respond to these questions with whatever solution to a problem they used. It is also useful to have a class policy that encourages or enforces use of forums as opposed to email. IE - Email to the instructor is only to be used where the issue to be discussed is a private matter like a family emergency or the wish to contest a grade you received,
Comment 2: Another important to technique is to make it very clear you your students what you expect from them. Or, to put it another way, ask good questions. I think the example forums throughout the Moodle developers course , once you get past the introductory ones, are good examples of this. (Don't worry if you don't understand the subject matter.) Note that the questions refer to things from the main body of each unit, which is why they may appear a bit terse in isolation. A related approach is to start with a provocative statement, rather than a question.
Comment 3: Hi - just a suggestion to get the more timid to engage: create a forum for just them (ie one-to-one only) to converse with you (or whichever tutor is most appropriate). That way they may just open up more knowing they're not being eavesdropped on or will be pointed out in class later. As for a more general discussion - I agree with the other post: start off with something contentious that you know will provoke a discussion (even if it's as daft and unrelated as 'all pop music sucks - discuss'). The trick is to get them using it first, then they may stick at it!

Post title: Handbook with user-selectable chapters
Post description: Is there a way to do this? I'm trying to offer a printable or downloadable handbook for use offline, but allowing learners to select the chapters to be included. In Blackboard, a learner selects documents from a list of course content, then choose the Printable view. The result looks horrible, so badly formatted that it is truly hard to follow. Is there a better way?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Sounds like a natural use of the book module.
Comment 2: Thanks, I thought that too. I just can't think of a way to let each user have a personalised selection of chapters to print. The concept behind this is that users will devise a three-year learning plan comprising dozens of activities , amend it as they progress, but see only the handbook content that is relevant to their plan. Unfortunately, the learners are mobile and often rural with poor or non-existent connections, so they need to be able to compile and download or print their learning materials. The closest I have been able to get to this is to create each activity as a separate course in which the participants may choose to enrol. This seems very fragmented and I'm not sure how well the learners can be tracked by their mentors.
Comment 3: How about using the new Page theme and setting up a separate page for each section... then users can pick and chose which they need... you could even have survey form using a quiz to make a survey type instrument that students answer and it gives them recommendations on which pages they need to go to?  You could use the feedback section of the quiz to put in which area they need to look at... Paula C

Forum Post: 
Post title: Drop box
Post description: Has anyone found a way to create a drop box in moodle 1.9?  Currently I am using a discussion forum where the students are uploading their files for grading - the problem is that other students can see all the attachments. Suggestions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The assignment module keeps the attachments or online texts hidden from other students.
Comment 2: My assignments are created in word, the students are required to download them, type their answers and then upload them.  Will the assignment forum allow for that?
Comment 3: There is an upload assignment that will do this. However, if you want the students to edit an existing Word document you may want to post the word document for downloading so they can download, edit, save and upload. The online assignment module does not present the text that you place in the window for the students to work around (initially a bit of a disappointment to me.) Looking for the kind of options I think you are wishing for I ended up deciding that using Nwiki templates for individual student wikis may be the best overall way to address having students do this.....
Comment 4: If you don't mind me asking, what are Nwiki templates?
Comment 5: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=73492
Comment 6: Greetings, Marc and Kristy! I think the best workaround that I have seen for getting the original blank word document for your students in the assignment window is to upload the file to the course files area, and then link to it as you write the description. The link shows up when the student opens the assignment and reads the instructions. Personally, I have the blank file as a resource and then the upload a single file as the assignment. They appear as a pair in my course, and the students are instructed to download the template, fill it in, save it, and then return it using the assignment. FWIW, none of my students seem to have a problem with this. atw
Comment 7: Thanks for the information. I will try it and see if it works. Thank you for your help.
Comment 8: I should clarify "blank document" above means the template file that you prepare for the students' use. Not an actual blank document! Sorry for my lack of precision! I do hope you arrive at a solution that you are happy with!
Comment 9: Have you tried the 3rd party internal email module? http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=13&rid=701 It acts like a webmail client but is completely internal to Moodle. you can create folders, and as each student "emails" you a submission, you can move it into a separate folder. Emails can have attachments. It will notify you each time you receive a message. You can also set it for specific courses. Jeff

Forum Post: 
Post title: Help proofread public domain sources
Post description: I just came across the following post today on another site. I actually logged in and proofed a few pages. It was kind of fun to see the variety of books available. Note there are many languages available, especially on the European site, so there is something for everyone to do. Here's the original message I found: Some of you may know the wonders of Project Gutenberg
( http://www.gutenberg.org ), which has thousands and thousands of public domain texts digitized in several languages, primarily english, french,
and german, with a fair number of spanish as well. However, these
projects don't just appear - they have to be proofread, since software
and whatnot simply can't match the power of a human. Please volunteer
your time - completely at your leisure, from your desk, how much you
want when you want - in proofreading these projects. Countless
historically important (and admittedly not so important) works are
waiting to be shared with the world that the internet truly makes
possible. Please register at Distributed Proofreaders
( http://www.pgdp.net ) and proof a couple of pages. If you have a real
skill in other languages such as Russian or other slavic languages,
Greek, and languages with alternative alphabets, please also take a
look at Distributed Proofreaders Europe at ( http://dp.rastko.net ). One
of the incredibly fascinating and groundbreaking projects is an
English/Spanish/Tagalog dictionary, which will serve for at least 6
other dictionaries when finished. Encyclopedia Brittanica is underway
as well - truly massive (it's in the early C's right now). Please
please help in any way you can. Very much appreciated!

Forum Post: 
Post title: NTLM SSO Cannot Get it Working
Post description: Hi im having a problem with getting Single Sign Logon to work in 1.9 in the Ldap Settings. Ldap Is working fine and we have about 4000 staff and students who all use ldap and i have no problems with how that is set up. The only manual accounts i have a 4 external staff that dont have accounts in house and a backup manual admin account. Now we used to use the onld NTLM folder on our old version 1.8 but i deleted this before we upgraded to 1.9 as it was not working. Now we are on 1.9.2 i though it would work stright away but if i enable the sso option and leave the subnet blank, or enter the subnet details it does nothing. Nothing happend at logon and i dont get any info like attempting to auto logon. Now if i browse to the /moodle/auth/ldap/ntlmsso_magic.php i get the following error "A required parameter (sesskey) was missing" and thats it. Also i have done all the iis setting on the server and it is running on server 2003 with mysql 5.0.27 and php version 5.2 build 3790. Using ie 6 and 7 for testing. I can provide a copy of my Ldap settings but they must be correct as they have always been tha same and are working 100% If anyone can advise anything i can try would be very helpful. as im a bit stuck now as it would be nice to have single log on. Many thanks David Hallam
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: http://i58.photobucket.com/albums/g259/dhallam/work/image1.jpg http://i58.photobucket.com/albums/g259/dhallam/work/image2.jpg http://i58.photobucket.com/albums/g259/dhallam/work/image3.jpg A copy of my Ldap Settings
Comment 2: Hi David, first you need to fill in the subnet field. Otherwise Moodle won't attempt the SSO. Second, if your system has IPv6 enabled, it might happen that the web server is returning the client's IP address as an IPv6 address, which the current code can't handle, so the check will fail. To make sure this isn't happening, could you please add a line like this to auth/ldap/auth.php, at the begining of the loginpage_hook() function, just right after the 'global $CFG;' line: `error_log('[AUTH_LDAP] Client address: '.$_SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR']);` and see see what you get? Saludos. Iñaki.
Comment 3: Im having the same problem did you find a solution?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Watch Moodle development grow over the years
Post description: Since 2002 when Martin Dougiamas first released Moodle, it has been enhanced by the contributions of hundreds of developers and translators around the world. This stunning animation (created by Eloy Lafuente using the open source software Gource ) represents Moodle development as tree, with the root directory at the very centre and other directories as branches. You can clearly see how, in the early days Martin is developing almost entirely alone and gradually more contributors get involved. In addition to developers, in the early years, translators are also shown (up until the language packs were moved to a separate repository). Many thanks to all our developers , without whom this Moodle ‘tree’ could not have grown and flourished as it has.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Where were you... from the class Dealing With Stress In Education
Post description: I had the flu the day the shuttle blew up. I will never forget it. I was teaching a class when the World Trade Towers blew up. It was a hard day for theclass.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The day the shuttle blew I was in Fort Lauderdale 2 blocks from home driving my (now long gone) fiat convert able and watching it in the sky. Then I saw something break off and I knew it was going to blow. I cred in fear that the space program might be canceled for my lifetime. The idea that there were people on it did not come for some minutes. When the twin towers went I was in my office working on a class in moodle with the today show on TV. As clearly as I recall those tragedies I recall setting my alarm to watch the moon landing live, hearing the news that my sister was born and much more. There is no difference in the memory quality for monumental events personal or global.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Here we go again
Post description: On the receiving end of this bit: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=103424&parent=457079 I felt my response needed to be public but that there was no need for it to further clutter that thread so I thought it best to move any reply here.... First off, Chardelle, as one of the people who sent you info about your site being hacked, I suppose I should say "your welcome....." As to my post here: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=103424&parent=456943 which you suggest indicates that I am intent on "belaboring...", I was actually responding to points Howard made and I included URLs for the material I referenced as I always try to do, because that way everyone understands what everyone else is talking about...... I think on review you will note that I agreed with a number of the points Howard made, but was concerned when talk moved to further exchanges of aspersions. If you want to attack me for what I think was a reasoned review of the details and my expression of my dismay that the source of the discussion was no longer within moodle.org, please me a bit more specific and I will be more than happy to address any of your concerns. I am not sure who is "getting off on attacking Moodle". Nor am I sure who "people" or "someone" are as usede in your post. I tend to agree with Mauno's perspective that ad hominem (invective directed at a person for the purpose of obscuring the underlying argument) is not an appropriate tool for rational discourse, but that does not equate with confusing or refusing to use proper nouns. "An eye for an eye" was abandoned by its authors two millennia ago. Sometimes the willingness to see another's actions as incendiary keeps fires burning for as many years. Sometimes its just because humans are venal. There are way too many examples available to prove either theory. I think Mauno argues that without fuel a fire will die, and I second that notion. So I try to focus on facts, and I try to inject a bit of humor where I can......
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I must admit, Marc, that I read your post (in the Developers forum) a number of times and couldn't sense the tone of it at all. I thought it prudent not to respond - no need to fan the flames as you say. I actually only made the link to Steve's original post at all because people where talking about it and, as far as I can tell, it was completely untrue. Steve's opinions about stuff (and they are just that, his opinions) are one thing but I thought it worth a mention when he had, in my opinion, just blatantly not been truthful. Of course, he simply may not have known it was a Joomla site - even Steve can make mistakes I suppose! I think his site would be more authoritative for simply admitting that, rather than digging the hole deeper. Of course he (now) says that he was just surfacing a site owned by a Core Developer with "moodle" in the URL - well, ok if you like.
Comment 2: Thanks Howard.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Differences between online and face-to-face learning
Post description: I was thinking what factors really differenciate online versus face-to-face learning environments, then I found this . Does people agree with these differences? Thoughts or comments? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Wen Hao, I'm not really impressed overall.  There are lots of complexities in this question. I think we have moved on a lot since 2001, and it could be that the classes this person looked at were of a very narrow type, maybe poorly contructed, difficult tools, weakly facilitated. I think there may be better frameworks. My 2c worth. -Derek
Comment 2: I agree with Derek. It seems to be centred around around asynchronous forum activities and doesn't take into account other modes of computer mediated communication such as conferencing and VoIP. I think it also dismisses power relationships between participants unreasonably. The social dynamics online are different but that doesn't mean that we all suddenly become egalitarian and democratic. That's quite an assumption to make. It also fails to address issues with learners' identities and feelings of commitment to online groups. As we've seen from studies more recently, there are significant issues with cultivating personal investment and productive relationships between participants.
Comment 3: Hi Matt, first thanks for your feedback.. Is there any recent studies that you can share with us that talks about cultivating personal investment and productive relationships between participants? Thanks again! Wen
Comment 4: Hi Wen, I generally keep a lookout on http://academia.edu/ and I think a good place to find some ground work is: http://communitiesofinquiry.com/ Since you worked on GlobalEnglish.com ( http://www.globalenglish.com/whoweare/aboutus/academic_advisors ), you might be interested in David Nunan's experiences of delivering post grad courses at the University of Anaheim California ( http://www.anaheim.edu/ ). They also use Moodle as their LMS.
Comment 5: Hi Derek, thanks for your comments... Is there any better framework that you have found so far? Thanks again! Wen

Forum Post: 
Post title: Other LMS's
Post description: I got an email today which referred to "Brightspace" the D2L product.  Some interesting claims. Led me to some more comments on the D2L home page.  [warning: extreme marketing hype following] Brightspace: # 1 for Innovation # 1 for Student Performance and Retention # 1 for Customer Engagement # 1 for Accessibility # 1 for Ongoing Training and Support Services Interesting.  They refer to an Ovum report on OLP's as being the source of this data, released several days ago.  (being an ex-science teacher this term has other meanings for me) I then have two choices.  from http://www.brightspace.com/ Read the D2L summary of the report.  (For which I have to sign up for) Go to Ovum page and get it (for which I have to sign up for) http://www.ovum.com/research/ovum-decision-matrix-selecting-an-online-learning-platform-for-higher-education-2015-16/ I don't need another signup. I do not know the CC BY or otherwise status of the report, but if it was available elsewhere online I'd be interested. I think this is one of the Laws of "How To Promote an OLP": 
```text
Find some research (any 'research') that supports your cause.  Promote it heavily on your website.
```
 -Derek

Post title: Developing a whiteboard module for moodle.
Post description: Hi, I am planning on developing a whiteboard utility for moodle and would like to know where I can find instructions and rules in developing software for moodle. I would also like to know what programming language I should use for developing software for moodle and how to get started. Thank you. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sangu, The place to a to learn about programming in Moodle is Moodle Docs, Developer section, programming guidelines . You will find general information there for developers. You should alos do a search in Moodle Docs for any articles on previously developed whiteboards. I know there has been at least three whiteboard modules developed for Moodle, and you may want to ask yourself, "Is a whiteboard module needed for Moodle?"  Maybe the previous ones are just fine, or maybe they are flawed and need a new person (like you) to work on it. You may want to Moodle itself is programmed in PHP, but there are some limited cases where other languages have been used partially in the process. Hope this helps, Don

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scavenger Hunt, Easter Egg, Wild Goose Chase?
Post description: This might sound a bit silly but I'm looking for a name for a classroom activity that I would like to do with some of my students. Once in a while, I'd like to send some of them (those who want to do the exercise) on a miniature quest for information that I know is readily available online. I'd drop in a few clues in class and interested students would have to do their own queries. For instance, to get some students (in an introductory class in cultural anthropology) to look at Tuckman's model of team development, I could give the terms "storming" and "performing" as clues for their searches. It may sound a bit silly but I think the strategy could work out. I wouldn't be grading these "mini-quests" or giving extra credit to those who go on them. The content of these "queries" wouldn't be on quizzes or exams. But I'm guessing that it could be fun to do and it might have some positive effects on student engagement and participation. One thing I like about this simple strategy is that it's not too directive (no hand-holding) but it still gives some signposts so people don't get lost... Now, what could I call these activities ? "Wild goose chase" has negative connotations but the concept that they're a bit erratic does capture something of what I want to do. "Scavenger hunt" isn't appropriate because the structure of the task isn't as complex or team-oriented as a scavenger hunt. I quite like the concept of an "Easter egg," but that might be an imprecise analogy for what I want to do (the information wasn't deliberately hidden). I don't necessarily need a name to try this strategy out with students, but it could be easier to explain the process if I did have a cool name for it. As English isn't my native language, this is the kind of thing about which I'm not really sure. Of course, some of you might tell me that what I'm trying to do is pedagogically unsound or that my methodology is faulty. If so, I will fully respect your opinion but I'll try it out for myself, at least on a couple of occasions. If you have tried a similar strategy, I'd be happy to learn about it. And if you think of ways to integrate these queries with Moodle (I have my own ideas), it could be very helpful. Thanks a lot for any help you can give me.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I like it! I might call it the WILD Goose Chase (emphasis on the "wild") or maybe "Off the beaten path". How shall you collect the answers? Do you want to have them available to the others? If so, should they be available right away, or when you release the answers? That would influence your choice of assignment, glossary, database , wiki, blog , or forum. I would like to hear more about this idea. atw
Comment 2: Glad you like it. Seriously. "Off the beaten path" sounds good. "WILD Goose Chase" could sound a bit too wacky for an undergraduate class. My wife was thinking of something to do with "fetch," "fish," "boomerang," or "recover." And I was thinking of something a bit more descriptive, like a "GoogleQuest" but without trademark... My intentions was to let students do what they want with the results. It's always a challenge, for me, as I really want to let students be as autonomous as possible, right away. It can well work. But still, you have an important point about collecting answers. I guess I should provide some structure. My initial idea was simply a free-form forum or blog. I don't want it to be an assignment (even ungraded) and I'm not sure glossary, database, or wiki structures would really fit, at least at early stages of the semester. I also plan to give clues during one lecture and go back to answers (asking class members if they found it) the following lecture (a week later). My not-so-secret hope is that some of these hunts would take a life of their own online and make students more likely to experiment with Moodle. So, eventually, I would very much like not to have to talk about these in class. Actually (thinking out loud, here), it's been my experience that free-form online discussions work really well when a subset of students may create a dynamic of their own. Out of 170 students in this one class, I'm thinking that I just need a few people to get started on those "fool's errands" for Moodle to become a fun place to visit, for many students. Maybe I should make it into an actual easter egg hunt. Put some "goodies" in different parts of the course's Moodle site. CMS geocaching. No idea what the goodies would be but I don't want them to relate to grades very directly. As for whether or not the answers should be available to others. I actually don't mind if they're not. Some people like to jealously keep secrets, and it's probably their right to do so. But I'm a bit wary of the clique mentality. My first lecture is this Tuesday, so I should think fast. This type of activity isn't meant to be a very integral part of the course. But it can be fun. So, maybe, I'll just open a forum with a catchy name and post clues there, mentioning in class that this forum exist and mentioning the first set of clues in class. If students start participating in the forum, we might take it from there. Path, wilderness, searching, hunting, fetching, retrieving... We're getting somewhere.
Comment 3: Treasure hunt? Gold digging? Web search?
Comment 4: Knowledge Quest ?
Comment 5: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webquest ?
Comment 6: Not sure I like the term "WebQuest" so much but I quite like this description. Thanks a lot! At this point, I'm thinking about "Wild Web Hunting" or some such.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Remove my moodle site's search engine visibility
Post description: Hello, How do I remove my site from being indexed by google? I don't it to be visible in search engines, instead just give my students a link to the moodle site. Thanks, Ray
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Ray, There is an option under site policies called "Open to Google" Site administration - security - site policies see, this should be set to "NO". thanks Nitin
Comment 2: Hello Ray, Nitin That doesn't seem to be the case. I produced a site http://gelttp.com which is totally closed. The 'open to google' has always been set to 'no', but a google search for 'gelttp' puts the site in first place. It's not a particular problem for us, though. I've come across two other ways of hiding your URL . 1. create a robot-blocking text document. See http://www.robotstxt.org/ for more details. 2. bury the moodle site at least 4 levels down. Apparently, robots often don't search below 3 levels. So if you embed your site like this it should be harder to find: http://yourdomain.com/1/2/3/4/yourmoodleinstallation.php Jeff
Comment 3: Hello Jeff, thanks for the trick, I think, if it is just related to hide the domain or sub-domain name than it is not possible as it is a WWW and any registered domain or sub-domain would definetly be searched on any search engines.. there could be an another case where i don't want google to craul my moodle site content, so in this case - will "open to google" set to "No" won't disallow google to craul my site conent? what do you think? thanks Nitin
Comment 4: Hi Nitin This is the text on moodle regarding google: If you enable this setting, then Google will be allowed to enter your site as a Guest. In addition, people coming in to your site via a Google search will automatically be logged in as a Guest. Note that this only provides transparent access to courses that already allow guest access. In other words, the setting is about entry to the moodle site, not about influence on search engine settings. Jeff
Comment 5: Hello Jeff and Nitin, Thank you for replying to my inquiry, I'll try your suggestions later, a bit busy right now. I appreciate your help. Thanks again, Ray
