Forum Post: 
Post title: Video: Web 2.0 ... The Machine is Us/ing Us
Post description: Described as " Web 2.0 in just under 5 minutes", this video by Michael Wesch (Assistant Professor of Cultural Anthropology in Kansas State University) is very well done and inspiring in it's use of web-montage in an semi-educational video.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Interestingly enough, Wesch is also a member of the "Open Access Anthropology" Google group and has been telling us a bit more about the video. He seems surprised by the success of the video but attributes part of that success to the type of community which it designates (and which pushed the video up). Wrote blog entries about that video myself...
Comment 2: This is a beautiful and useful video, but only to the sighted. This strikes me as rather ironic in that one of its key points is about the separation of form and content but it doesn't separate form and content - they are welded together. Flash videos of text HTML pages are not text. I blogged about it here . I sat with a blind colleague this morning while he used a screen reader to read my email containing a link, then went to the Youtube site and 'played' the video. Well we heard the music but that was all. He also pointed out that had there been describing text, the music would have interfered with it. There are some very brief text transcripts on the Kansas site but I am not sure how that will help users of text screen readers. I'll be blogging some more about this - it's a very interesting issue, I think.
Comment 3: Excellent points and I'm sure Wesch would be interested in discussing them in detail. (He seems somewhat busy these days, but it could make for a fascinating dialogue, once he gets his head above water.) He told us (Open Access anthropologists) that the video "is a draft for a video I was working on for a special web-based edition of Visual Anthropology Review" and that he "recently uploaded it to Mojiti where people can add their own subtitles and animations." One thing about the field of Visual Anthropology is that they do tend to emphasise the importance of visual representation even though they're well aware of the "visual bias" in some cultural contexts (including Euro-American societies).
Comment 4: To me this video wasn't about the text, or even the grand message, but more about the aesthetics, visual transitions, the music and an entertaining collage of some of the web 2.0 ideas. Would a content of a movie be best served to a blind person by reading the script out loud, accompanied by the sound maybe? Or by reading a book that the movie was based on or a book made about the story in the movie? I think that I'd take the latter to entertain me (if I was blind, obviously I can't be sure as I'm not blind). If I'd want to study the movie itself, then I'd read the script and maybe watch the sound of the movie.
Comment 5: One thing that's interesting is that the video was made less with artistic intentions than as an exercise in digital ethnography. I happen to think that Wesch did achieve the kind of insight we typically get from ethnographic research. And he now needs to respond to different needs. Since the video has already been translated in different languages, there could "easily" be a version oriented toward visually impaired people. It would, in fact, strengthen the point Wesch was making in that video (for Visual Anthropology Review). In other words, while art isn't directly translatable, this video's main points can and should be made through different channels. The draft was posted so people could add subtitles.

Post title: Use of variables when changing time settings in resources?
Post description: Each term I have to go in and
change hundreds of settings only because the time slot of my courses change.  You can only imagine how many clicks it takes
per resource to update  "Allow
Submissions", "Due Time", and "Cut-off Time" for each
one.  Let's not forget making mistakes
and forgetting which one I just edited when the screen finally refreshes.  I could spend hours on this for every course
and for every semester. Could we not have user-defined variables to leave
in place and then update only one set of entries? For me, a set of variables would be a time setting
for: CS110A-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS110A-DueTime, [HH] [MM] CS110A-Cut-OffTime, [HH] [MM] CS110B-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS110B-DueTime, [HH] [MM] CS110B-Cut-OffTime, [HH] [MM] CS113A-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS113A-DueTime, [HH] [MM]v CS113A-Cut-OffTi, [HH] [MM]e, CS113B-SubmitTime, [HH] [MM] CS113B-DueTime, [HH] [MM] CS113B-Cut-OffTime, [HH] [MM] Make them select-able from within the resource. Another method would be to use Group assignments. This way, I change the appropriate variable
setting and it reflects into hundreds of resource entries immesiately.  This came to light when one of my courses

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is 'Learning 3.0'?
Post description: We have all heard of Web 2.0 (internet with collaborative interaction), which implies that a Web 3.0 is coming.  What is that?  In the corporate education world, a conference is opening called " Learning 3.0 ".  I am wondering what that is.  The conference organizers define it as: Make mobile learning "The Enabler" for performance improvement in your organization. Apply gamification to learning. Use social media to centralize knowledge and create valuable communities of practice. Reach game-savvy, socially-networked workers and create a learning model that truly delivers just-in-time learning and performance support. How about for Moodle?  What is Moodle 3.0 going to be?  Presumably a qualitative leap like Moodle 1.x changing to Moodle 2.x. At the iMoot conference, I attended Lasic's presentation on the Moodle Hub. I said teachers doing mass collaboration globally to create great courses in specific fields is the next quantum leap. Even bigger than Moodle itself. Some people agreed. That may be different from what the Training Magazine people think. What do you think is 'Learning 3.0'?

Post title: Assistive Technology Module Online
Post description: Hello Moodlers, A couple of years ago, I received a grant to develop online modules in support of an educational technology endorsement program. I hired college faculty and public school teachers to develop a series of self-study online modules based on a format that I developed. In order to make it easy for the developers, I had them create all their content in MS Word for me to reformat to the web once complete. I've just finished getting one of the modules on the web. It covers Technology for Special Populations (Assistive Technology). It is open to the public on my site and will remain that way. It is created so that everything can be seen/done with guest access with the exception of the quizzes...anyone can create an account, and enroll to do the quizzes if they like. The course is located here: http://www.kentuckyclassroom.com/teacher/course/view.php?id=145 I have eight other modules on various educational technology topics I will be making available to the public as I get them formatted and posted to on my Moodle site. On a side note, I'm no expert in assistive technology, so if anyone is really interested in this area and would like to help improve and keep this module updated, please reply here or PM me and we can discuss making you a teacher in the course to help maintain and keep it updated. Steve

Post title: Moodle talk
Post description: On Friday local Moodler Dales Jones and I met up to talk Moodle. We managed to effortlessly maintain a non-stop Moodle centred dialogue
for around five (yes, five!) hours. The scope of our conversation was
wide ranging - Dale has some top ideas on the use of Moodle in the UK educational
arena. The flow was only broken by Dale's need to join his family for their
evening meal and my need get to the local computer shop to buy an
external hard drive - such is life. I reckon there was easily another five hours discussion left. At least. Conclusion: If you're able to do team up with some others to talk Moodle, do so. Recommended! Ray
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ray, Wish I'd been there. This might be interesting in connection with your posting. You might also like to check this out. Cheers, Anders
Comment 2: Thanks for that Anders.  I already use Skype (SkypeName dfjones) and it's a great concept, implemented well.  I also have it on the pda, so within range of a wifi node my pda is a phone!  Now THAT's cool. Recently I had a look at Teamspeak too.  It was a bit like being the first kid on the block with 2-way radio - nobody I knew was around to talk to - but for a group talk session it could be great. Obviously, the thing missing from all telephony conversations is the necessary body language.  In our meeting, the enthusiasm that Ray put out (and mine hopefully) just wouldn't have been so obvious outside a face-to-face meeting.  It's good to just talk, but there's a good case for meeting up too. It was great to talk with Ray, enlightening in many ways, and it gave me some good ideas for a direction forward with Moodle.  Now to get off my butt and spread the word!

Forum Post: 
Post title: My Courses
Post description: Hi, We have recently upgraded our server to 1.6... In 1.5 you had "My Courses" in the Middle of the page which would show you the course you have enrolled on, but in 1.6 you don't have this or do you? Any ideas on how to get it back? Thanks Mark
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1.6 has changed how the fornt page is displayed (and I must say for the better) as you can now have a variety of different things appear. To bring it back go to your Admin page then click on "Site setting"s.
Comment 2: Hi Julian, > 1.6 has changed how the fornt page is displayed (and I must say for the better) Not sure this was for the better, as a number of users of former 1.5 version are dismayed at the disparition of not the list of all courses on the site but the list of courses a student is enrolled in. I know the list of courses in which a student is enrolled (and much more) is available via the myMoodle page, but anyway here is a solution for those who cannot or do not want/need the myMoodle page enabled. To enable a student to have the list of the courses they are enrolled in displayed on the front page of a Moodle site: as Admin, on the front page, enable the Courses block. This will be displayed to Admin as Course categories and to Teacher or student as My courses . Hope that helps, Joseph
Comment 3: Hi, I prefered it when "My Courses" was in the Middle of the page, we don't wont to use the "My Moodle" page and a long list of the courses in the middle just does not look right. We only want to show the Course categories and nothing else. There is an option to show the Categories and hide the Course but this does not seem to work. Anybody else have any ideas to get "My courses" back in the Middle. The Middle is now very bare. Thanks
Comment 4: i also prefer the old mycourses in the middle without the description...

Forum Post: 
Post title: Site Ground hosting question?
Post description: Is anyone using SiteGround as a host ?  Any good?  Anyone have a site on their service that I can look at? Thanks, Rob
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Rob, If you're just looking for Moodle hosting, check out our site at www.asteio.org .  We offer free Moodle hosting to all. Milan Indru Malkani milan.malkani@asteio.org
Comment 2: Milan, While it is good to see that you/your organisation are able to offer Moodle course hosting for free, I think there is a difference between Moodle course hosting and Moodle hosting. In Moodle hosting one can do customisations, file editing etc. suiting one's requirements which is not possible in Moodle course hosting. Your offer on its own is great as it is useful for large populace. Manish.
Comment 3: SiteGround appears like a real bargain. They are cheap and offer around the clock quick service (within 10 minutes). On the other side, in the long run, if you go with them, you will pay and suffer big time. They can set you up within minutes as they have automated script that install Moodle efficiently. On the other side the servers we have used with them go down about every day, and this is a real pain. They have people getting back to you quickly, but many of the people we have dealt with have insufficient and ineffective knowledge. At some points we had so many problems with servers down and things not working that we had to place several tickets a day. This is very time consuming. We had 2 sites with them, and on one of them, they changed their policy about allowed bandwith and they CUT our service... 2 months after we had renewed for the year. They refused to reimburse saying we had violated the policy... which policy was different when we had signed up the year before. They did not send notification to tell us that the policy had changed. We had also signed up for a windows hosting server , and they stopped hosting on windows servers. They would offer us "free" downgrade to Linux, but we had all the programing of our active pages in ASP and they did not support ASP on the Linux server. So we would have had to pay thousands to reprogram all our active pages in PHP. In short, we found Siteground business practises deceitful, misleading, plain dishonest. Technical support appears impressive at first, but really, this is varnish that did not (at least for us) have any depth. They lure people with their low cost hosting, but then charge you for everything (even backups). We lost valuable info when they lost one of our databases. A nightmare. I could go on and on! They will try to get people onto expensive dedicated servers. On top of that, there servers are located in Houston, Texas, in an area very close to where Katrina hit and very likely to be hit by major violent hurricanes. There are some very good people in Texas, but this type of company has the culture of Enron and Exxon. They are driven by pure greed and will do anything to get your business and your money. Do a google search on Siteground and you'll get many other horror stories. Conclusion: I suggest you deal with anybody BUT siteground.

Post title: site teachers
Post description: I know I have seen this before but cannot seem to find it again: What are site teachers ? Thanks, Art
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Users who have teacher privileges on the site home page and thus can for example post to the site news forum and act as teachers on site activities . Usually that would be only the admins but the admin can add extra site teachers. The site home page is a bit different from an ordinary course. So for example there is no direct link for adding teachers. The admin has to type in the URL ...moodle/course/teacher.php?=1 to get there. Also site teachers can not add resources or activities to the site home page. This whole thing about treating the Moodle site home page as a course is a bit of a mess at the moment. If someone could come up with a consistent logical way of how to deal with it that would be very good.

Post title: Single Files vs Folders
Post description: Under Add a resource when I add a single file, I have the option (when I upload ) of having it appear in the same window or new window. Whereas, when the documents are in a folder, they appear in a new window, without having clicked that option. Why?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It's just a way Moodle works. If you want to make a document to be a more integral part of your course, you add it with the resources menu. If the document is clicked from the folder view, then the default action is to open it in a pop up. It's a compromise of some sort which, in my opinion, works quite well.
Comment 2: Thanks for your help. I have another question regarding the pop up. When documents are in a folder, its more difficult to print. In order to have the print icon on these new windows appear, I have to right-click the toolbar background next to the toolbar Final Showing Markup, and click "Standard".

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Security and working with management
Post description: Hello fellow moodle users, For the last five months or so I have been learning how to use moodle. (thanks for all the support at this site!) I am an English Teacher at a technical high school in Japan. Currently, I now am serving my moodle on my Mac Desktop Pro, as a production server . Unfortunately, I cannot register or access my moodle from home because it is stuck inside our school network. This week I have a meeting with the Computer Dept. to explain to them why I need to have the moodle outside the school network. The Computer Dept., traditionally doesn`t allow anything outside their network for security reasons. Let me list a few items of information that are important. 1. My server is my own personal computer, not the schools. 2. I did a step by step install of Moodle 1.7.2 so as to secure the site better. 3. I changed the default passwords, as said in the moodle installation info. 4. I want to use my moodle as a platform for other students studying English to communicate in English with my students, via, posted discussion, chat, blogging, and posted video and audio. I would know the total number of students and set all passwords and user names. My understanding is that Moodle is pretty secure as long at you take necessary precautions. (backup, hard passwords, update). BUT, I am not sure what the computer people think over at the computer dept. I suppose they view by moodle as another potential access point for crackers. My big question is, can anyone point me to a discussion or thread that outlines moodle security in a detailed manner? I would like to be prepared for what ever questions the Computer Dept. puts to me. Ps. My understanding is that if a cracker uses packet snifers to intercept the encrypted data between my server and the users computer that they eventually could *crack* my moodle after they beat the encryption. Is this correct? One, I dont think that any cracker would be that interested in my Moodle. There is no sensitive data (pictures of students, full names, addresses) Two, a cracker would have to intercept a lot of packets before that could get enough info for a password and user name and that is after they cracked the encryption. What is the moodle encryption rate? And is this premise correct or incorrect?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Going Straight to Moodle 2.x?
Post description: Our CIO would like to identify universities that plan to implement Moodle for the first time using Moodle 2.x.  U of England in Australia and Open University appear to fit this criteria, but they are very online focused.  We are a state university of about 20k that is seriously considering Moodle.  We would like to talk to others a little more like us that are going straight to 2.x. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It depends what you mean by "for the first time".  The British OU uses Moodle now.  They are shifiting to 2+ sometime. IMO The problems in going from 1.9 to 2+ are greater than starting with 2+.  You have a large staff dis-orientation problem then. Moodle 2+ has a lack of some plugins available for 1.9.  But not so big a problem with a starting off in 2+.  You don't know what you haven't got.  The book (a non core modue) is working for 2+. The basics seem to be sorted, especially with the video work currently headed for the weekly release soon. Gradebook: no experience in this. Conditional release: seems to be working.  But I have not seen this used at a large scale. Navigation: some issues around navigation can be solved by a Menu block Other things to consider: Speed.  File picker.  Repositories. Good luck.
Comment 2: Hi Terri - the decision to go with Moodle 2 is a calculated risk (like everything else). However, we consider Moodle 2 to be a beautiful, modern system; and as such is the future LMS for our Polytechnic (32,000 students). We started designing in 1.9 without incident; but soon realised that conversion to Moodle 2 can be messy. We now prefer to start with Moodle 2 and design directly in the production environment. Furthermore, we need to develop add ons for the LMS to monitor and flag participation (or rather, non-participation). This will be much easier to achieve in Moodle 2 with its built-in conditional logic. Moodle 1.9 is inadequate in this respect. Students also enjoy Moodle 2 for its file management. It is highly significant that a student can maintain a Flickr, Picasa, DropBox account as a file repository that can be easily referenced in Moodle 2 across all their Courses. We are optimistic that the release of Moodle 2.1 will demonstrate maturity and stability at the enterprise level.
Comment 3: Thank you Derek, Don and Paul. Terri
Comment 4: Are starting to use Moodle for the first time?  If so, then no question you should begin with 2.0 (or 2.1 scheduled for end of June). If you go straight to 2.0 (and LaTrobe University is doing that right now with their whole student body) you will avoid the headaches of upgrading and moving data from 1.9 to 2.0. If the Book module and Feedback module are already in Moodle 2.0, you should have little problem. Our Sharing Cart and Project Course Format plugins are due for updates in May. We are also waiting to hear about some drag-and-drop Question type plugins that should be coming soon. Martin reported at the MoodleMoot Japan that HQ is now using a "swarm" style of programming management. This means they work on major issues as a whole team until completed, then move on to another major feature. This way they can fix a release date more reliably than if they worked in parallel with each person doing separate jobs that may not get completed in time. So I feel confident you will see a 2.1 release in June/July.
Comment 5: That should be Scrum not swarm.
Comment 6: Thanks, Tim, got it, "scrum", a rugby word. More explanation here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrum_%28development%29 According to this article, the scrum roles include: - Scrum Master: that would be Martin? - Product Owner: that would be me and a million others - Team: that would be other HQ developers I like how the processes of Daily Scrum and Sprint Planning Meeting work. Gives me an image of high collaboration, and may be fitting to a social constructionist perspective.
Comment 7: Don: You say: "I like how the processes of Daily Scrum and Sprint Planning Meeting work" Who looks after the big picture and long term goals? -Derek
Comment 8: Well, it is not clear how religiously Moodle HQ are following the Scrum gospel. Anyway, I would say that Martin is product owner. It is his role to represent the voice of a million Moodle users in the planning process. I believe they are recruiting, or have recruited, someone to fill the role of scrum mater, but it has not been announced yet. The team is indeed the HQ developers. There are two added complications to the classic Scrum picture. First, not all the Moodle developers in the world work for Moodle HQ. There is lots of other development going on. Second, as well as the fortnightly spring cycle, there is also the weekly cycle of integrating and testing contributions and HQ patches to make the weekly builds. The key organising point is the Tracker . Each item in the project and sprint backlog is recorded as a tracker issue. It is also how non-HQ developers feed their changes into the system. Votes on tracker issues are one of the ways Martin listens to the millions of Moodle users. To reply to Derek, I would say that the big picture emerges over time. Particularly, I would guess, via Moodle Moots. I would guess that every time Martin has to prepare a keynote explaining what has been done recently, and what is coming soon; then present it; and then listen to the feedback; that provides a good opportunity for reflection on the big picture. The other point to make is that Moodle has been set up in such a way to de-emphasise the need for a big picture. We intentionally have modules and plugins so that lots of innovation like certificate and questionnaire and forumng can take place separately. If something gets done that is very good, the decision to then include it in Moodle core is something that can be decided later.
Comment 9: Tim you wrote this a few years ago Any thoughts on how this has evolved since then?

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is a Derivative work with regards to a Creative Commons License?
Post description: I've just wasted about an hour trying to find something online that gives some clear examples of what a derivative work is in terms of the creative commons license. I'm wondering particularly about images. There are some definitions of a derivative work that are quite clear-like a painting or collage based on an image. The creative commons license variations cannot include a "no derivatives" and a "share alike" clause in the same license, which makes it more confusing. But what is a use of an image that is not a derivative other than just posting the image by itself? The share alike clause seems to apply only to "derivative" works. But if one uses an unmodified creative commons licensed image as an illustration of a newly composed text on a Web page, is that Web page considered a derivative work? If it is not considered a derivative work in that case, then is there any different functionally in the terms of the license if it is either a no derivatives or share alike license? If a share alike image is used in a non-derivative way, then is the user obligated to publish the entire work in which it is included as share alike, since share alike only seems to apply to derivative works? I hope this makes sense. I really wish someone would take someone to court over these creative commons licenses as they seem to me to be full of ambiguities. At least that way there would be some clarity to the matter.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: But if one uses an unmodified creative commons licensed image as an illustration of a newly composed text on a Web page, is that Web page considered a derivative work? IANAL, but I'd say composition (e.g., a web page including the original image) is a derivative work in most jurisdictions. Saludos. Iñaki.
Comment 2: Well, I researched it more and just decided to go with using direct links to the photos at Flickr. I can't give the artists credit that way as easily and a lot of people would consider it bad etiquette, but that way I can link to any photo whether CC licensed or not and it is something that a court of law has said is not a breach of copyright so at least I can feel secure in doing so. I'm not so sure I would agree with the courts myself but it is to my own benefit to accept their judgment so that's what I will do. The creative commons license is just too ambiguous and untested-unless it is a strict "by" license-and even then it is kind of silly because most people on Flickr use nicknames so you have to credit the photo to some stupid nickname rather than its real photographer-and that makes little sense either because in a way, does that really fulfill the license requirements? Creative Commons is a great idea but the implementation is another thing.
Comment 3: In a way, it's kind of hard not to cringe while saying that the CC implementation doesn't work so well. On the other hand, it's in the spirit of Lessig's involvement that CC might spark yet more debate about use of other people's content. What's kind of funny is that, apart from media-related companies, most actual human beings seem to agree to a very large degree on what "the right thing to do" really is, in most contexts. With CC, the hope seems to be that we (everyone who isn't an executive in a media company) can use it to fight the media hegemony while joining forces as creative people. After the YouYear , are we finally getting in the WeYear?
Comment 4: I just checked out the Flickr.com guidelines They seem to expect you to link to your own photos not to those of others. I did see something about this on a forum but can't find it now. If you have a flickr account they might block you in some way I guess. Whose bandwidth would it count against? Might be a problem for those with free account.
Comment 5: Here's what they say: Link back to Flickr when you post your photos elsewhere The Flickr service makes it possible to post images hosted on Flickr to outside websites. However, pages on other websites that display images hosted on flickr.com must provide a link back to Flickr from each photo to its photo page on Flickr.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How would you rate Moodle against Drupal or WordPress?
Post description: I am considering Moodle for a paid online training site. I am also considering WordPress and Drupal. From what little I have seen, Moodle seems to be the best choice. But I have some concerns. 1) I am iffy about being able to monatize a Moodle site. I know there is a paypal plugin for Moodle. But what about subscriptions? What about credit cards? 2) Is this site made with Moodle? If not, why not? 3) I am reading some harsh stuff about Moodle. Is it any cause for concern? 80% of people on this site hate Moodle: http://amplicate.com/hate/moodle I am also reading a lot about performance issues, especially with recent releases of Moodle. 4) A lot of people post that: "anything you can do with Moodle can be done with WordPress, or Drupal." I think that is probably true. But, from my experience so far, getting WP to act like an LMS is huge PITA. WP seems to be very centered around blogging. Using WP for an LMS feels like trying to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. Maybe I'm too impatient with WP? Also, worthwhile plugins in WP cost money, and sometimes even those are not worthwhile. 5) Mobile is important to me. WP does have decent some decent mobile themes. How would you rate Moodle for mobiles? 6) Does the Moodle flashcard plugin work with newer versions of Moodle? 7) One of my great frustrations with Drupal was: this module does not work with that version of Drupal and that module does not work with this version of Drupal. Sadly, Moodle seems to have the same problem. Or maybe I have misunderstood? That's all I can think of for now. Thanks for reading. 3)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Mmm... I'm gonna watch this thread.
Comment 2: Matt, I had exactly the same response. Walter, from your other post: " I am finding it a little difficult to setup WP for an LMS" - that is because WP is a blog , it's like trying to use tables in a wordprocessor for a spreadsheet.  Drupal is a CMS.  Both Drupal and WP have plugins to provide a little bit of LMS functionality, but their primary function is not LMSing. You have a lot of misinformation in your post.  Don't believe random and anonymous "somebody" unless they actually know what they are talking about. -Derek
Comment 3: http://amplicate.com/ looks like an amusing site to pass the time, but I am not sure I would trust it for reliable information. You also need to calibrate against the competitors: http://amplicate.com/software/12376-top-e-learning-platforms/ On to the more serious questions: 2) This site is a mixture of Moodle (e.g. these forums) and other more specialised tools, like tracker.moodle.org and git .moodle.org. The intersting one is docs.moodle.org, which uses Mediawiki, not the Moodle wiki. The Moodle wiki is designed for a small wiki activity within a course. The Moodle docs wiki is a huge site, which needs the extra organisation tools that mediawiki provides. 3) The perforamance issues are fixable. Indeed, how we have started working on it, a lot of them have been, or are being, fixed MDL-39443 . Many sites run Moodle with good performance. 4) Anything you can do in Moodle can be done in Drupal or Wordpress. Similarly, you could do it all by starting from scratch and building your own custom system in PHP (or any other language) but that is going to be a lot of work. If you want to teach online, then using a tool that was built to support teaching online is probably going to turn out easiest in the long run. (And I don't believe there is anythign for Drupal that can do everything that Moodle's quiz module can do.) 7) The Moodle plugins directory clearly documents which add-ons work with with versions of Moodle. Of course, it takes time after a release like Moodle 2.5 for all add-on maintainers to test their plugins and update the database entry. Normally, plugins that works in Moodle 2.x just work in Moodle 2.x+1 without changes, but this needs to be tested. Sorry, I can't really help you with the other ones. I will just comment that one approach people sometimes take is to put another system in front of Moodle. For example, if you have complex payment requriements that you know how to implement in some other system, then you could use that other system as a front-end to your site. Users enrol and pay there, and then you use a single-sign-on system, and an enrolment plugin, so that when they click the link to their course, they end up in Moodle for the actual teaching and learning. Look up authentication and enrolment plugins in the docs.
Comment 4: Very informative. Thank you.
Comment 5: I have the same problem with trying to "monetize" potential training site. Setting up PayPal is easy, but many want to pay with credit or debit. I use QuickBooks Merchant Services for processing in the office, but there is no way I can accept any volume. There is a plugin, but I don't see how subscription can be processed. Besides, it is very expensive, $50/mo and $0.25 per transaction. Very costly for short $2 or $3 courses. I looked at "ZenCart" as a front end, but I an certainly not a "mega-programmer" and don't feel comfortable playing with money. One mistake and it would be a nightmare. I know that there is a nursing school in BC that uses this combination, but I can't get them to respond to my emails to let me know how it was done. By the way, I think Moodle is the best as a LMS. I just wish upgrading was easier, and there were fewer on them. I'll be following this closely. I am about to "go-live" with PayPal, but would like to ad other credit options.
Comment 6: Hi Bob, Paypal accepts credit and debit card papyments. I think all you need to do is get verified as a merchant account holder. I've heard bad things about Paypal though, that they can be tardy in crediting funds to merchants and sometimes put amounts of money "on hold" for reasons that they're unwilling to disclose detailed information about. Also, Paypal's disputes resolution service doesn't respect the corresponding trading laws where the transactions take place, leaving customers and traders in a dog-eat-dog legal no man's land.
Comment 7: My 2 cents: I think the most important aspect in comparing Drupal and Moodle is to remember that the first one is a generic CMS very close to be a web framework, the second one is a specialised learning management system. It's true you can mimic most of Moodle with Drupal, but at cost of using ton of modules (the first in my mind Organic groups, webform, some content access module, views, rules..) and personalisation.. let's say it's a ~2-3 years/man job of a proficient drupal developer. On the other hand, Moodle is a ready-to use solution BUT it doesn't have almost anything of user management other than the courses.. most (all?) large organisations that use Moodle they use it to deliver the courses but, for example, the enrolling of users to courses or the assignment of credits is done toward external back-office tools and then integrated in Moodle e.g. using LDAP . In your case, you can set paypal to pay for courses but you can't set it to pay for individual activities . So the best solution is to just use both: use the flexibility of Drupal to manage the users, if you need add a e-commerce store to deliver access to the courses rights, etc and then use Moodle to deliver the individual courses.
Comment 8: Hi Antonello, Good points; a generic CMS like Wordpress, Joomla, or Drupal is going to take a tonne of work to make it anywhere near as useful as an LMS. Also think about much re-inventing the wheel you'd have to do. With a mature LMS, you've already thousands of users trying to do all kinds of different things with it and, with a good developer team and contributors, there's more likely to be some really coherent, practical, and useful features that you're unlikely to think of if you starting from a CMS and adapting it. That said, I've been playing around with a collaborative platform built on Drupal (cue jokes about Drupal's core code), called OpenAtrium: http://openatrium.com/#!/ Once you get used to the pretentious naming (e.g. pages are called "spaces") it has some interesting and potentially useful features for collaborative learning. I like the amount of autonomy and control you can hand over to participants to form groups, start their own projects, control access, keep track of what others are doing, etc. in particular.  Of course, it's not an LMS and not what most people have in mind when they think of online courses. However, if you want to do some strongly social constructivist oriented learning and teaching, I think it's certainly worth considering.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Why buy the cow when you can get the milk for free?
Post description: How would you answer someone who uses this cliche to justify simply buying a book and teaching themselves with a study group of people at their same level of expertise (or lack thereof)? How do you demonstrate to them that buying the cow (paying for teacher-led instruction by someone who is an expert in the field in a Moodle environment)?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: my two cents as a  returning student and new moodle user.  The criteria am currently looking at is as follows: Quality of instruction  -  The instructor must know the material at a level far beyond that of the study group.  This would lessen the Learning time required for any given subject. The possibility of a marketable credential  -  A study group does not meet the requirements of accreditation boards as equally as a qualified instructor. Cost factors in remote learning -  with moodle/blackboard there is the possiblity of lowering already outrageous educational fees (i.e. gas, food, rent, books, etc) not sure if that helps to answer your question, peace and merry christmas
Comment 2: What a good question! This actually comes up in discussions with parents now and again: Why can't we just buy software to teach little Johnny German? I politely say that it is a wonderful thing for the few who can actually pull this off. Most people seem do better with a competent teacher. If it turns out that Johnny needs a good teacher, he is welcome to join my class. I am pretty sure he'll enjoy it if he does. And I don't really say much more than that, other than to answer very specific questions. -- Art
Comment 3: It was a real question I got too...I finally decided to answer it by pointing out the other benefits that a cow could provide besides milk, summarizing it with a "You get what you pay for." With regards to the course in question, I pointed out it was introducing new material/technology, which while it superficially might seem similar to things already available for free, it is actually all new material better suited for learning purposes. I also stressed that the most important thing was that the technology was simply a means to the more important end-giving the students personalized instruction by a teacher. No self-teaching program can compete with that. As for teaching oneself German, I actually did pick up a German book and taught myself a little a year or so before I really started studying German with a teacher. I became very good at German because I had great teachers (it was at UC Berkeley, which has the best German program of any US univeristy). Unfortunately, I have had little use for it besides reading it and have lost most of my ability to speak. But I can definitely say that without a teacher I wouldn't have gotten as good as I did.
Comment 4: I understand. You can get pretty far on your own, of course, but a good teacher makes life so much easier! I have a friend who more or less taught himself German in his car via cassette tapes. He is a very bright guy with a lot of language ability, so I was not at all surpised that he was able to do so. But I consider him the exception to the rule. If students want to learn German, my wife and I are very happy to have them in our classes, of course. If they prefer to teach themselves, to learn another language, not to learn any language at all... Well, we are okay with that, too. It's not that we don't care, it is just that we seem to have plenty of students who *do* want to be in our classes and we expend all the energy we have on them. -- Art

Forum Post: 
Post title: Mail to students with individual attachments
Post description: For a statistics course I have at the moment (yes, using Moodle), I would like to be able to send a mail to all the participants with a unique attachement (actually a unique a data set for an exam).  Essentially essentially a mailmerge thing but by e-mail, and the individual attachement is a must.  Suggestions anyone? And I am even unable to find how I send a simple mail to the students from Moodle! Tom
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You say "send a mail" but then you say "a unique" data set, do you mean that you wish to send all participants the same email (one email, many recipients) or do you mean that you would like to send one email to each student, each receiving a different data set (one email, one recipient)? If you are referring to the former I would think that using a discussion thread and attaching the aforementioned data set would do the trick. This would work as long as the discussion forum was set up so that everyone was subscribed by default. The course news forum may serve this purpose for you in this instance. If you are referring to the latter there are many ways to automate this task using macros built into email apps like Outlook, but in order to make any of this work you would have to first create a separate entry for each student in your contacts list in that email application. The Thea Theo
Comment 2: When I say "unique" I mean:  Same e-mail, but different attachments for each student.  The same mail, same attachment variant can be handled in any number of ways.
Comment 3: The only way to do this is with an email app that you can write a macro/script for. You will need several things set up in advance. Folder containing the email attachments, sequentially numbered, one for each student. Each student entered into a unique contacts folder in your email application. A draft email saved without a recipient. With this you can then automate the process of sending the email with the use of VBA (for Outlook) or another scripting language for different email apps that allow command line calls and you should be all set. My VBA is extremely rusty but I know I've done things similar to this in other Microsoft apps and the code can be created by recording the initial macro and then modifying the code to increment attachment number and go to the next contact, etc. If this exists in Moodle somewhere I really hope somone else chimes in to give us a clue because I don't know of any feature in Moodle or any email application that will do this without significant setup on the end users part.
Comment 4: Yes, your conclusion is essentially the same as I arrived at, and concequently I wrote a small program in Delphi that did exactly what I wanted, read a list of participants, generated the file I needed for each participant (a random subsample of a master data set for a statistics exam), and mailed it to each one.  It works.

Post title: Not understanding
Post description: Hi Everyone I am just a week old and boy am I confused with the way the student sites work.Would someone please help a newbie find her way around thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Charlene - First, be patient (especially with yourself). Moodle offers many tools for a variety of situations so there is a lot to learn. I recommend starting slowly and being very practical. You may want to start by asking questions in the general forum about how to accomplish a particular task you want to do. Feel free to describe the task in the way that makes most sense to you and I am sure someone will have some ideas about how Moodle might be used to help. Keep in mind, Moodle is more than just software. It is a whole community of educators like yourself. The Lounge is usually a place for more social interactions and thus you may get a quicker response to particular questions in the Using Moodle forums. Let us know what questions you have and welcome to the Moodle community. Peace - Anthony

Forum Post: 
Post title: Loading old CSS files
Post description: My browsers ( IE , Firefox & Netscape) are all loading older versions of a CSS file that I have updated on my webserver. I have tried deleting all browser temporary file s and cookies. I have tried rebooting my PC. I even removed the CSS files completely off the webserver. It's still loading the old version. This didn't start happening until after I integrated SMF's community board software into my website. The new software doesn't access this CSS file though. Could just be a coincidence. Any help would be much appreciated. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Only thing I can think of is that your organisation has a cache server betwen you and your Moodle server, which is storing the old version of the CSS file and serving it up to you, even though the old version has been taken off the webserver. If this is the case then as you posted the problem five days ago it should have resolved itself, as the cache server should re-check for newer versions after a day or so and so should catch up with recent events. If it's still misbehaving have a word with your IT department and ask them if there is a cache on the system and how often it should be checking for new versions of files. HTH Chris

Forum Post: 
Post title: New to Moodle
Post description: Hi, My district is going to start using moodle so I downloaded the program the other day.  I cannot add student e-mails nor can I see my moodle classes on moodle.  Can I have Moodle on my computer or does it need to be on a district server to access?  Thanks! Jason
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jason, Welcome to Moodle! The best place for help is on the Support Forums (this is a Social forum). But I can get you started, then if you have further questions, go to "Installation Problems" forum to post them: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=28 Yes, you need to put Moodle on a server--your own server or a district server. Then you publicize the URL of that server so students anywhere can access the moodle site. If you just want to try out Moodle and learn how it works, go to "Downloads" in the top menu, and download the one-click version for your personal computer (No one can access it, but you can try it out). The 1.9.9+ version is the best for now. In a few months, you might try the 2.0 version of Moodle. For example, here is one-click version for a Mac computer . To add student names and emails, you will have to put them into an Excel spreadsheet and upload them into the enrollment section of Moodle. This starts getting technical so be sure to give yourself several hours the first time. Moodle Docs has full explanations of how to do this and how to install Moodle anywhere. Hope this helps,
Comment 2: Thank you so much for your help!  I know that our system is doing a test run this year, and they are looking at linking the system to PowerSchool.  I use to teach an AP Psychology class and this is really a clean system.  Thanks for your help again! Jason

Post title: Why is brokenfile.php added to url in uploaded html files
Post description: This issue is driving me absolutely mad. I just had my server provider upgrade my Moodle site version 1.9.7 upgraded to 2.5.1 In the old version I was able to upload html files that I had created externally and which from a course page were accessible via links. I could then edit these html files directly within the Moodle file manager. Now on the new version I do not seem to be able to edit these html files so I do it on my desktop with Textedit and then upload the new file directly into 'Legacy course files' overwriting where the originals were stored. So to get around it I edit the code outside and drop the html files back in. Then for some reason the url links to images, pdfs, and videos or any new links that I have added forced to change from file.php to brokenfile.php Help would be greatly appreciated. Cheers Craig
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Seconded, the way images and links just end up brokenfile.php if I do anything slightly more technical than basic html in tinyMCE is frustrating. As is moving a picture from one topic to another by copying and pasting the html and moodle losing the picture. The pic is still there and if you go back through the file picker you can fnd and relink it but it's all very anti intuitive, click heavy and laborious. Of course now I've trained my self to do it the 2.x way, if it gets fixed I'll wont know how to do it properly anymore ;) Sam Thing.
Comment 2: Hi > I just had my server provider upgrade my Moodle site version 1.9.7 upgraded to 2.5.1 Really? That was just one single step for you? Can you disclose the provider? I'm sure that provider can save many moodlers! > In the old version I was able to upload html files that I had created externally and which from a course page were accessible via links. I could then edit these html files directly within the Moodle file manager. I doubt that you could edit them. Still I know the work flow and miss it in Moodle 2. As a work-around you can zip the HTML, upload as one file as a file resource, unzip and "set main file".

Post title: md5crypt considered unsafe
Post description: In light of passwords from LinkedIn and eHarmony being cracked and leaked, it has been announced that md5crypt is no longer considered safe ( http://phk.freebsd.dk/sagas/md5crypt_eol.html ). I noticed that the Moodle docs say that Moodle uses md5 to encrypt user passwords: http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Password_salting Is there any recommended action to take?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Password_salting says, use a good salt. That works-around most of the weaknesses in MD5.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Migrate Moodle data 1.5 to Moodle data 1.8
Post description: HI all, I wanted to migrate the Moodle data from Moodle 1.5.3+ release, Mysql 4.0.21 to Moodle 1.8+ release and My sql 5.0.1. For that I have done following steps. 1) I have configured Moodle 1.8+ version. 2) Copyed moodle database data from mysql\data\moodle. But it was not done successful. Its giving an error as follows "Sorry, but your database is not already in Unicode, and this version of Moodle is not able to migrate your database to Unicode. Please upgrade to Moodle 1.7.x first and perform the Unicode migration from the Admin page. After that is done you should be able to migrate to Moodle 2007021502"
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Up to Moodle 1.7 there was a built-in utility to convert the database to UTF-8, but this has been left out of 1.8 so it can't do it. What you need to do, as the error message says, is to upgrade to 1.7 first and let it perform the conversion to UTF-8, and then further upgrade to 1.8 after your database has been converted. HTH Chris

Forum Post: 
Post title: Info on free/cheap web hosting for a good cause? (not Moodle)
Post description: I would really appreciate any info people could give me on cheap/reliable web hosting. I've checked prices at Godaddy.com and they are too expensive for my needs. I just came back from Africa. During my stay there I met a number of people that I would like to help and having access to cheap and reliable web hosting would be essential. These are people who have just started with little businesses such as hostels or craft shops in areas that are not far from areas that foreign travelers visit but because they have not made it into travel guides and do not have web presence, they don't receive as many visitors as they might receive otherwise. I volunteered to create simple web pages for them and I'm even willing pay for the hosting for a while in some cases. I checked web hosting services such as Godaddy.com but I find them too expensive for what I need. In some cases these are people who are barely surviving with their businesses and $4 a month is quite a lot in a place where $120 a month is considered a pretty decent salary and very few can actually get jobs that would earn it. The web sites I want to put together with the pictures and info I collected are very simple and hence require very little space. Does anybody know of cheap (or free if possible) web hosting services that could help me with this initiative? Any advice, tips I should consider besides info on the hosting itself? Thanks a lot in advance. Josep M.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: How about Googlepages? It can also provide email using the domain name (not sure if there is a charge for that). brian
Comment 2: I'd avoid free hosts - any free host is going to plaster your pages with adverts for other people's businesses rather than the ones you're trying to promote. The cheapest one I know of, which I use myself and which I know is reliable, is www.fast2host.com .  They're UK-based, and their basic package is GBP25/year, plus domain names at about GBP8 each.  They give you 200MB of web space on the basic package, plus ten email addresses.  They also include PHP, MySQL and ODBC on the basic package as well, in case you need them. HTH Chris
Comment 3: Josep, If you are talking about static content on a site that you will administer (i.e. you won't give the account login to anyone else), I will give you an account with Cpanel on one of my servers if you are interested. Email me at steve [at] kentuckyclassroom.com if you are interested. I'll be offline after today for a few days. Steve
Comment 4: Thanks to everybody who responded. Here and off-line. Thanks for your generous offer, Steve. I'll contact you privately. JM
Comment 5: Josep, I realise you may already have a solution from Steve, but you may find the idea extension interesting nonetheless: If you were to have a single domain-name and put up each of these businesses as sub-domains, or just as seperate pages, then the unit cost per business is much reduced. Each business can indeed get Gmail accounts which is useful and negates any limitations on the number of e-mails offered by some hosting packages. Taking the idea a step further- is there an opportunity here for a type of co-op to develop? Customers of one client may be interested in the wares of others also? i.e. hostels and crafts- if a craft biz sells something thru the web.. could they recommend the hostel? Could the hostel recommend the local goods as souvenirs or to send home to friends/relatives? Could they get involved with the Fair Trade Movement? Having a Googlepages site (as Brian suggested) is an excellent idea- there are in fact NO adverising banners, the interface is quite simple so the clients may take over maintenance themselves... lastly even having a second site (i.e. googlepages) with the same businesses listed and links to the main site (if seperate) will help with getting listed in Google. Good luck. Seán.
Comment 6: Thanks a lot for all your suggestions Séan. All of them very useful. I had not considered getting a domain name because that added up to the price. But you are totally right that if you have to build more than one site, then it turns out to be cheaper. Josep M.
Comment 7: Josep, It sounds like you have stumbled onto a great opportunity to help local businesses thrive in areas of the world that are not at economically sound.  It would be great to create a free online community to enable all of these local businesses the ability to create their own profiles advertising their services.  As a software developer/architect, I would be more than happy to talk to you about ideas to make this work on what could be a larger scale than originally anticipated (I dream big).  Let's get in touch if you're interested.  Non profit ventures like this are always appealing to me.  I even have a empty server that I can provide hosting on for free if we come up with a good idea. Milan Indru Malkani
Comment 8: I agree with you that having a space devoted to these kinds of projects would be a good idea. You'll have to send me e-mail or let me know where I can contact you because I don't see any e-mail address in your profile. JM
Comment 9: Josep be sure to check out dreamhost. They offer unlimited addon domains, and after the first year, which is 30 bucks with a coupon, it's about 80 bucks, so less than 10 a month. This gives you just about everyrthing you could need, from mysql , to moodle hosting (for onesies and twosies), wikis, etc... Combine this with free things from google, flickr, etc... and you can offer a lot of cool stuff to just about anyone! d.i.

Forum Post: 
Post title: On the criteria to accept new Certified Integrations
Post description: Dear Moodlers, Carles here, technology partner manager at Moodle HQ. My role is to support tools that integrate or want to integrate better with Moodle. On this chapter, I run the Certified Integrations program, where we vet potential Moodle partners on the usability of their integration with us, on their business consistency and, if there is code, on the code quality. The result is a small set of tools that we have reviewed and labelled Certified Integrations: https://moodle.com/certified-integrations Obviously, Moodle is used together with both open source and commercial programs, so the program is happy to promote other open source tools, like BigBlueButton and Myddleware, but accepts commercial partners as well. My question would be the following: Which should be in your opinion the criteria of acceptance of products to the program? Should we limit tools, for example, produced by competitors? Should we ban the big names that tend to use their market position and have very aggressive user terms? Or should we stick to the code quality and leave other matters to you, users? In general, as this post bears as title, which should be the criteria of acceptability for Certified Intergrations? Thanks for your interest and insights, I'll love to read any comments on this. 🤓 Best, Carles
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Several of your Certified Integrations partners have sponsored MoodleMoots, got a list of attendees, then aggressively sent the attendees spam for ever more. That sucks. Whatever else you do, please stop that.
Comment 2: Hi Tim, Thank you for your message, even though it is not related to the asking. All sponsors of the Moodlemoot Global (Certified Integrations or not) receive the list of participants that have opted in commercial communications. I understand all companies should have an unsubscribe option below their commercial messages, so I'll be happy to raise it with anyone that doesn't conform to this. Simply reach out to me in Matrix (@carles.aguilo:moodle.com) or at technology-partners@moodle.com Cheers, Carles

Forum Post: 
Post title: Would Moodle be adapted for a private school?
Post description: Hi, I'm a dad of a 13 year old studying at ENSR and was wondering if Moodle could be a good solution for e-learning as sometimes I take him with me on overseas? In that way I could demand the school to start using it on a general basis? Do you know any other private schools that use Moodle? Thanks! Philip
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Philip, Moodle is among the most popular of many learning management system (LMS) software. LMS doesn't necessarily mean distance learning, but it can lend itself very well to that. Anyone can use Moodle, but initially it's just an empty platform. In general, the school chooses a particular LMS and the teachers develop their course on this platform. Note that this involves a lot of work on the part of the school to manage the platform and a lot of work on the part of the teachers to develop their courses or even just a few activities on an LMS. This is a significant change for a school and its teachers. All students must have access to a computer and course activities must be redesigned to be done on the computer. That said, computer-based education and, to some extent, distance education seem to be the way of the future.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Help with Moodle. How to change guest view and student views.
Post description: Hello, I am currently working on a moodle site and have made a look and feel for how guests that see the site. But then when a student logs in its the same view so i try to hide some of the parts of the site that are supposed to be guests only but moodle then treats guests like students when you selecte "hide from students". What I am trying to do is have the landing page that guess have show up then when students log in they have a different page that they see and not the same as what guest would, any help would be appreciated, Thank you.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: What I have on my installation is a front page with information and links for visitors and a login block.  When a student logs in, I have moodle redirect them to the " My Moodle " page (new in 1.6).  In order for students to get back to the main page, they either have to enter the address manually or logout.  This should be what you're looking for.  The "My Moodle" page can also be configured with " Sticky Blocks ."

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can I covertly enroll in the course as a student so I can play devil's advocate?
Post description: Any possibility?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I assume you're the teacher and you want a second identity as a student for posting to forums. If it's a face-to-face course, you obviously can't get away with it, but in an online course, just create a new user account and enroll the user in your course. When you want to play devil's advocate, logout and log back in as them. If you have moodle/user:loginas ("Login as other users") permission , you can more conveniently go to the user's profile page and click the Login as button, then post (this way, you don't termiante your normal session).
Comment 2: Thanks!

Post title: Exploring the Educational Digital Divide
Post description: Following on from the recent ALT Conference, the EXTEND project team would like to invite you to participate in an online asynchronous discussion in which we will explore the Educational Digital Divide. Funded by JISC-Emerge Benefits Realisation, the discussion begins on Monday 29 September 2008, with topics and questions including: · What does the digital Divide mean to you? · Who has the hardware, software and bandwidth? · Digital Divide as a duality - link to Perpetual Divide · Gender as a lens on the Digital Divide · Silver surfers and Digital Natives However, you’re not restricted to the above topics - with multimedia resources to inspire you and plenty of opportunity to explore your ideas, we are expecting this to be a lively and interesting discussion. The event will be hosted on the HELP (Higher Education Learning Professionals) network, which you can join by visiting http://www.cabweb.net/portal/course/view.php?id=7 - this will take you to a login page where you can create an account in 2 easy steps and enter the discussion. Please do join us for what we expect to be a lively and thought-provoking event! Helen Keegan, Frances Bell and Cristina Costa

Forum Post: 
Post title: The evolution of edx, xMOOC and cMOOC-a coming together
Post description: Hi found this paper today (ref & ab below).  I asked about the hybridity of x/c MOOCs sometime ago (Feb-2014) and got no answer...I thought it made sense at the time to think along those lines. So it seems....it did make sense-the formula sounds like it will be (my interpretation): edx accomodates x & c MOOCs-(cMOOCs-developed by grads) so both will run under the one roof-interesting times. Sanders et al., (2014) 'A new approach to developing interactive software modules through graduate education' Journal of Science Education & Technology 23, 3, pp431-440. Abstract Educational technology has attained significant importance as a
mechanism for supporting experiential learning of science concepts.
However, the growth of this mechanism is limited by the significant time
and technical expertise needed to develop such products, particularly
in specialized fields of science. We sought to test whether interactive,
educational, online software modules can be developed effectively by
students as a curriculum component of an advanced science course. We
discuss a set of 15 such modules developed by Harvard University
graduate students to demonstrate various concepts related to astronomy
and physics. Their successful development of these modules demonstrates
that online software tools for education and outreach on specialized
topics can be produced while simultaneously fulfilling project-based
learning objectives. We describe a set of technologies suitable for
module development and present in detail four examples of modules
developed by the students. We offer recommendations for incorporating
educational software development within a graduate curriculum and
conclude by discussing the relevance of this novel approach to new
online learning environments like edX. D

Post title: Auto enrolment expiry from individual courses
Post description: Hi, I'm wondering if Moodle provides a functionality wherein students could be assigned access to specific courses for a specific time duration . I could not find this functionality till now. I think Moodle controls access based on users, not on courses. Which means that either a user can access all enrolled courses, or none of them. Can't be selective here. Please help!!! Thanks in advace for any/all helps... Saurabh

Post title: Logs in Moodle
Post description: Is there a way of extracting the logs in Moodle from a course and putting into PDF.  I would like to be able to email a log from a course that students are working on for the teacher to see the progress.  Could a pdf feature be added to the next Moodle update ?.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Nathan, Have you explored any of the open-source PDF printer drivers, eg pdfcreator, http://www.pdfforge.org/products/pdfcreator . Navigate to the screen you're interested in and just send to print on the virtual PDF printer. Another solution would be to give the teachers access to the appropriate log page - the new roles architecture should make that possible even if you don't want them to have editing rights on the course.
Comment 2: Miles has given you a direct and useful answer.  I would like to direct you to a discussion that I have found very useful in dealing with log data http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=19488#94476 I am just thinking that if I was one of your teachers, I am not sure I would welcome a log file that might be huge (even bigger in PDF?) by email but this thread would show them how to downoad as many log records as they wish (to Excel say). BTW a little tip to retain the date sequence of these records in Excel when sorting and manipulating them is to a sequence number column (since the date is in text format and not sortable).

Post title: Moodle versus Angel
Post description: Our school is considering changing course management software vendors. We are currently using WebCT Vista, and many people are pretty unhappy with the platform. (I know, because I'm one of those people.) The two alternatives being considered are Moodle (using a Moodle partner) or Angel. I use Moodle, but I know nothing about Angel other than the fact that it is closed source. Can anybody tell me how they compare? Are there any advantages to Angel, or did anybody have any problems? Their claim to fame is that they are really easy to use. Does this mean stripped down and limited in features? I would really like some feedback from anybody who has used both systems. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This would be a good forum for you to explore.
Comment 2: Blackboard has acquired ANGEL Learning by Elena Ivanova - Thursday, 7 May 2009, 04:52 AM Have you heard? They have announced this today. I've found those news to be rather interesting %) Reply Rate... Coolest thing ever! Very cool Cool Fairly cool Not very cool Not cool I do not know how true it is but Elena Ivanova posted on 05/07/09 that Angel was acquired BlackBoard. You might want to look into this before proceeding with Angel. WebCT was also taken over by BlackBoard.
Comment 3: Hi Paul, I was on my college's CMS (aka VLE/LMS) study group. A fair number of Angel vs. [anyother cms/vle/lms here] studies exist. Google for them. Angel came off our list fairly early, because it was an okay CMS but had a small base and looked to be gobbled up by the Blackboard folks who had hit it with a copyright infringement law suit.

Forum Post: 
Post title: ? a job market place for developing Moodle courses
Post description: I want to convert a paper based distance learning course to web based. This is a currently a private, bedroom based, enterprise, operated through a very small educational charity. Colleagues use Moodle so I have tried to learn it - but the advice is to get an expert to do the groundwork and build from there. It has to work first time. Does the Moodle community have a job exchange, to put potential suppliers and users in contact? I am based in the UK, Manchester and London. If you are interested, please contact me. Velson Horie c.v.horie@hotmail.co.uk
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Velson, You can also get good ideas about how you want your site to look by going on other sites and find out how that is organized. A lot of sites will let you use a guest account. You are welcome to have a look at our site: www.ucopenaccess.org If you want to have an account on our site that is fine too, it is free.
Comment 2: No such marketplace specifically geared at Moodle exists but there are a lot of sites out there that put suppliers and users in contact for this kind of work. I currently am doing some research and content production work myself via oDesk . I looked at a lot of sites like it, but oDesk was the only one I felt completely comfortable with. It's very transparent-it gives you a lot of information about the people you can hire beforehand and it allows you to monitor their work through randomly taken screenshots of their computer to make sure that they are doing what they are supposed to be doing. For the people doing the work, it provides payment guarantee for hourly work, which is nice, because I have read on other sites often the users are often just looking to get someone from overseas to do work and then not pay them. There's no upfront registration fees-they just take 10% from the users on top of the rate set by the suppliers, which is quite reasonable considering the services and features they provide. I suggest checking it out .
Comment 3: Hi. If I understand correctly, do you look for an expert to setup one (or more) courses for you, or, are you interested in training, provided by experts, for how to setup courses? If it is the first case, I wouldn't suggest it to you, since an one-to-one training for a collaborative educational tool wouldn't show you most of the pathways. If it's the second case, I would suggest you the Moodlerooms online courses , since, together with other colleagues, in a group pathway,  you'll get your final svope which is creation of moodle courses, for some fee. Of course, you can go into documentation in moodle.org (that's for free) and start reading, join the forums, asking and responding, visit various sites for taking ideas and finally, learn by yourself (as all of us here). It's up to you.

Post description: Trying to do the statutory mandatory training at my nhs hospital. The hospital tells me there have been loads and loads of problems with lots and lots of nhs trusts and moodle. Some courses show they are done upto months later in this year but it still shows a red light. Some courses say valid to a few YEARS ahead but it still shows a red light  !!! Worst thing is that the moodle has a phone number but when you call it says it doesn't accept calls. There is an email but no-one replies. What is the point of even putting a telephone number or email there?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello there. First of all, just to point out that the Moodle site you are posting on here is the general site where people discuss and download Moodle , not the help desk specific to your own NHS Moodle site. Presumably the site is hosted by a company and you should have contact details for them? However, people are happy to offer free voluntary support in the Help forums.  Secondly,I am not aware of a green/amber/red light in standard Moodle, so you might have some customisation there - but let's see what light others can shed.

Post title: Quiz Scores, Feedback, Etc not Available to Students 1.8
Post description: We recently upgraded from 1.6 to the latest stable version of 1.8 (on Jan. 09) and are having the following problem with our quiz module. Students can review a quiz immediately after taking it and are able to see scores, feedback, general feedback, etc; however, after that initial review, they can no longer access it. The "Attempt #1" text becomes black instead of blue, and does not allow access to the review page This is the case no matter what is checked in the "Students May Review" area in quiz settings. My thought is that there is something overriding these setting, making them null. This is true for quizzes made in the 1.6 version that were migrated and it is true for every new quiz that we create using our upgraded system.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Confusion: Messages and mail
Post description: I am looking for an option to send off an e-mail to all or some of the participants in a course of mine, and I am unable to locate such a thing.  Is it included in Moodle? Secondly, there seems to be an option of sending off a message to a partcipant, but it does not work it seems (a window opens, but when the send button is clicked, the program seems to transfer infor to or from the server , but that process does not seem to end).  Are there any options in the settings that have to be set for this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You may send email in several ways.  If you want to use a forum to generate email, you can set that up and force all members to be subscribed forever.  Then, every time you post (or anyone else posts, if you allow replies and/or discussions) each person subscribed to the forum will get a copy. The second way to send email is to set up something like the quickmail block.  If you install it as is, I believe teachers can use it to send email to students.  If you add the recommended changes (search for quickmail and you will find the instructions in the discussions), you can make the block available for students as well.  Only students can't send attachments even though an instructor may do so. I am  not sure about your messaging problem.  If you log in as admin, there is a setting in the configuration files under "permissions" where you set messaging to yes or no.  Perhaps you have yours set to "no"? We chose to use messaging and the quickmail block.  Some instructors also use the forced subscribe forum for course announcements.  So you may wish to use a combination of tools. Remember, users who set their email to digest will not receive the messages immediately.  They will receive once each day, and as admin, you can set the time.
Comment 2: Thank you for your very informative answer.  I'll look into both Quickmail and the setting you mentioned. Tom

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodlemoot UK & Ireland 2020
Post description: I was looking through the upcoming events on moodle.com recently and found an entry for Moodlemoot UK & Ireland 2020 . The entry links to the moodlemoot.ie website rather than moodlemoot.org/mootieuk , which is still showing this years event. I was just curious if there was a reason for this? Up until recently I've been keeping an eye on moodlemoot.org for any updates for next years Moot.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ross and thanks for your interest in keeping up to date with all our moodlemoots! Our HQ team is in the process of streamlining the MoodleMoot.org website into Moodle.com . This enables us to promote all our events as well as our latest offerings on our corporate website from 2020. The latest MoodleMoot UK & Ireland 2020 is now an official moot which is run by a member of our community (ie, Gavin Henrick), as opposed to an HQ-run moot.
Comment 2: Yes, the moodle.com now has a great event listing where each of the Moots will be listed - but the external individual moodlemoots - like Moodlemoot UK & Ireland 2020 are mostly on their own sites - moot are mostly spread across a few sites - portal, registration, abstract proposals. As it happens, moodlemoot.ie was used 3 times in the last decade for other Moodlemoots too. So after fours years in the UK, this year we are back to Dublin and then will be heading to UK again. If you have any questions about the UK & Ireland Moot - please get in touch.

Post title: Fwd: Call for Proposals: Illinois Online Virtual Conference
Post description: (forwarded text follows) The Curriculum, Technology, and Education Reform (CTER) program in the Department of Educational Psychology will be hosting a hybrid online/on-campus conference in conjunction with the 5th annual Illinois Online Conference (IOC) for Teaching and Learning ( http://www.ilonlineconf.org/ ). This conference will be held February 14-16, 2007. Live presentations will be held from 5pm to 8pm on campus at the College of Education, and broadcast live via Elluminate . We encourage you to submit proposals for this conference. This will be an excellent opportunity for you to share your best practices in using technology for teaching and learning in front of an international audience, and you can choose to do it here at the College of Education or from your workplace/home via Elluminate. You may submit your proposals here . The deadline for the proposals is December 6, 2006. This will also be an opportunity for instructors who would like to participate in a live (in person or online) presentation session with their class. If you'd like to take advantage of this opportunity, please contact us for more information at scagnoli@uiuc.edu .
