Forum Post: 
Post title: Patents Kill Innovation !
Post description: Hi all, I received this today posted in another forum I subscribe to 'down under ' Just thought it might be worth passing on : Firstly posted in the Business Uses forum ( no interest) I thought it was important to all of us ! (kick me if I am wrong !) or of course simply ignore the post ! Urgent: Freedom for Learning Innovations! Dear Learning & Training Colleagues: I am appealing to you for immediate help to stop a disruptive set of lawsuits that threaten the heart and soul of the e-Learning innovation process.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have attached a file containing half a dozen of the patents owned by this company for anybody who is interested. They seem to have about 25 to 30 patents all in the online education field. The fact that two patent attorneys are allowed to start up this kind of company that seems to invite litigation, knowing that they have an advantage where fees are concerned as they are themselves patent attorneys, strikes me as a staggering conflict of interest. It is tantamount to extortion. However, in the US, the patent system is "first to invent", which means that the patent goes to the person who came up with the idea first, so if enough prior art can be turned up then it should be possible (troublesome, and expensive) to invalidate the patents. Personally speaking though, I do not think that patents that so obviously refer to software, no matter how heavily disguised, should ever be allowed.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Financing a project
Post description: A very good afternoon to you all and thank you for all your interesting posts to date and the work you do to make Moodle the wonderful tool it is. I posted about this to the "Forum" forum but received only one reply. I apologize in advance for cross posting, but I wonder if anyone here might have ideas / comments on what I believe is a very important aspect of Moodle. I've had a look but couldn't seem to find anything. My question is: Is there a way to have the forum display changed? My students inevitably click the person's name who started the forum post - it's in the middle of the screen, and it kind of makes sense to click that. No matter how often I tell students, it is the one thing that continually sends students on the wrong path. They click the person's name, then try and send messages rather than post replies. This, to me, is a major design fault and I wonder is there any way I can change it. I know forum has been around for a long time. I've only had smaller classes in the past (have used Moodle since 1.2) but have always had troubles. I now have a course with over a thousand students from 6 different countries and we are having the same problem in all 6 countries so it doesn't seem to be limited to one culture (as I initially thought it might be.) I'd be very interested in others thoughts on this and if there is a way to change the layout. I wonder if others think the same way as I do regarding the design of the forum? Should I start a tracker item? Do others think it is a fundamental design flaw? My ideal forum interface would look something like this Your post (or something else, but not "Discussion") Follow button Group Replies Last post made by An example title (click anywhere in this section and it will take you to that forum discussion) started by Joe Bloggs on (date) (institution name here?) (NO link to student profile) Click here to follow this topic only 3 6 Marla Doe – see it here (clickable) Another cool title Started by Minnie Do on (date) (institution name here?) (no link to student profile) Following (eg only) 2 2 Joe Bloggs– see it here (clickable) Forum has been in Moodle from the beginning and it is a crucial part thereof but I really feel it, of all things, is in a dire need of a facelift. Would be interested in others' ideas. I have some money that I could put toward making this happen if a programmer is out there. I'd also love to have a report along the lines of a page that shows the following and can be separated into groups and be both course wide and per forum: Student name Country Number of posts (if possible, set dates here – between ~ & ~) Number of replies Total forum views Total number of words First post Last post Send reminder Link to complete report Joe Bloggs Japan 1 7 18 542 Oct 1 Nov 12 (click to send) link Marla Doe Colombia 2 8 21 625 Oct 1 Nov 14 (click to send) link Minnie Do Japan 1 1 8 35 Oct 10 Oct 27 Sent (date here) (click to resend) link Many thanks again to everyone that puts so much time into Moodle - wish I had the tools to do this myself! Hope to hear others' thoughts on this.

Post title: Using registration form for students from a different/other website.
Post description: Let's say we have an existing website, is it possible to put ONLY Moodle registration form in it and store all the data in our moodle database .
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Christian, There is an easy presentation aspect (how it looks to the user) and a difficult security aspect (how you handle unforeseen attacks and exploits of the registration process). Writing code to put IDs directly into the database is meddling with the difficult stuff, and will sentence you to continually retesting and maintaining security. Using one of the existing authentication options (see MoodleDocs ) is much less work and lower risk. It's much easier to reshape the Login page and to place it on a different website. There has been some discussion of this in this forum . Cheers Russell
Comment 2: Sir, I think we are well aware about the security, what am I trying to point out is can I make or implement certain Forms (eg. registration form) with authentication (if possible) outside moodle but would update the moodle database. Forum Post: 
Post title: How much storage is enough?
Post description: Hello everyone, I have used Moodle for years in a few classes with a few students each and always loved it. Our administration finally seems inclined to give it a try for the whole school. We clearly need to upgrade hosting, but I am not sure how by how much, given that this project is on a whole different scale. And of course the expense of it will not be well taken by the business office. Could I bother you to give me some thoughts? I realize that there is not one answer, but how much storage do you estimate would be needed for 500 students? 10GB, 15 GB, 20GB? Also, has anybody hosted Moodle in the cloud as a pay as you go service? Thanks in advance, Javier
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: How much storage is enough... perhaps 10GB more than you are using at the time, and therein lies the problem. Before you can give an estimate you need to know what those 500 students are going to be doing. For example we recently had an assignment run with 500 students. It was a video assignment, they recorded a presentation and uploaded it to Moodle. That one assignment gobbled up 20Gb in a couple of days. The answer is not to try and guess a hard number but set up something which is flexible that allows you to expand over time in line with demand, but there is a cost associated with that too. As for "the cloud", there are plenty of people (Moodle Partners included) who will provide that for you, but keep in mind you can move to that kind of setup whenever you want, by that I mean you could migrate an internal Moodle site to external hosting if you needed to. I think a lot of Moodle hosts use services like Digitial Ocean or Rackspace. Rackspace are very good but also expensive. Digital Ocean seem pretty good but you have to do more yourself. Also consider how you are going to recover that space later on, i.e. auto clear down / delete courses. To get an idea of prices just ask a few Moodle Partners for quotes. When you do that it would be worth asking: What their policy is on adding plugins, some providers charge silly money to add new plugins. Whether your install is on its own code base or multi tenancy (multiple customers on one code base) The latter can be cheaper but may constrain you around plugins / themes, upgrades will be automatic but you may not always want to upgrade.... To give you an idea of prices there is a non Moodle Partner who provide 50Gb for 500 students for $125 per month fully managed using Multi Tenancy (less control over themes and plugins).

Forum Post: 
Post title: best way to downlad lots of files
Post description: Hi, All, I am getting ready to move lader.org to a new host and want to back up everything before I do that. I have tried downloading the entire public_html folder to my hard drive via ftp , but am having no luck. Surely, there is there a better way to do this, right? A simple telnet command or something? Maybe I should use a program like this one: http://www.httrack.com/index.php Thanks, Art
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yeah! httrack allows you to download the whole site so it is suitable with your purpose.
Comment 2: What's the problem with FTP, to me it would seem the most convinient way to download lots of files. Web site downloaders like httrack don't download it "as it is" but "as the surfer sees it", so if you have pictures or files there that are not linked anywhere, you loose them. You also loose all of the server side code (if any, obviously) and so on.
Comment 3: Hi, I am using Filezilla and it keeps disconnecting after twent or thirty minutes. I am trying to download 1.1 Gigs and I guess it is too much. -- Art
Comment 4: Art,
Someone once referred me to a command WGET. I use it because it has a mirroring option to only download the files that have been changed recently. I've never downloaded over 1 gigs in 1 go, but this command at least has the advantage that it skips files which have already been downloaded, so if things go wrong, you can at least repeat the process.

There is a windows version of WGET. WGET is a unix console command so it takes a little to understand
all the options.

I've entered the following commands in a notepad document: 
```text
 
wget -o log.txt -np -m ftp://username:password@
www.olvrode.be/private/moodledata
```
 and saved it with extension .cmd

Now whenever I click on this file
all the recently changed files are downloaded to my pc
I believe it could work for you to if you just replace the location, username and password stuff.

Another thought: if you have shell access you could zip directories before downloading them.
Comment 5: Hi Art, I do use Filezilla also!. It's a great program. There is a  queue  mode, you can set to download only modified files, or files newer than existing ones (just as the wget command, also a good option). You  can "resume" a broken queue. Perhaps disconnecting is not due to filezilla. Go to Options and make sure you have enabled teh "keep alive" feature. You may try to increase timeout time to a couple of minutes, and set automatic reconnect, in addition. - Enrique -
Comment 6: Art, I haven't used FileZilla. Enrique said that it has a feature to resume a broken download queue, but couldn't find a mention of this from FileZilla documentation. I don't think the keep alive -feature helps here, but doesn't hurt to try. It's designed to not to disconnect when idling, downloading lot's of stuff sends messages to the ftp server "all the time".
Comment 7: Do you have shell access on the new host? Just use FTP from the command line! ftp oldhost.com cd somedirectory get somefile.tar.gz I would archive the whole directory on the old host first, for example: tar cvzf somefile.tar.gz somedirectory Then unpack it on the newhost: tar xvzf somefile.tar.gz
Comment 8: If you have this kind of access to the two boxes you could as well use rsync . Most probably faster and certainly simpler.

Post title: We need your views: plugins directory workshop on 09 Jan 2023
Post description: Dear Moodlers, At Moodle HQ, we are trying to improve the Community Sites . One of the sections that we feel has the most room for improvement is the plugins directory , so we are doing some specific work on it. In order to understand the needs and desires of users as we make these improvements, we would like to invite you to a virtual chat about the plugin directory in the form of a workshop. The workshop will be held on 9 January 2023 at 19:00 UTC . Other workshops are being held in other time zones and languages as well to try to capture as much information as possible. We imagine that most of the attendees will be Moodle administrators or course creators, but everyone is welcome. The aim is to understand what you would like us to improve in the directory from the point of view of the user looking for and installing plugins. There will be other sessions dedicated to the plugin creators/ developers experience, at a later date. Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Frontpage
Post description: Who customizes the frontpage at your institution?  It seems like a no-brainer that it would be the Moodle administrator, but our Communications & Marketing Department has expressed a strong desire to get involved.  If you all could take this poll, it would really help make my case stronger when it comes to what the standard is out there.  Thanks! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dHVlaXcxa080UTkwZjV0SmJ4bmZhYlE6MQ
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I disagree that this is a no-brainer Erica. While at school, I was moodle admin and webmaster and therefore did content as well as techie side, in a bigger institution such as the university I am now working at, those roles are split. There is a marketing/communications department who approve the look of the site in the first place and also approve that significant messages going out on the external website are all 'on message', and a slightly lesser degree of active interest in the intranet (more of an overview to ensure everything is ok, but they don't necessarily approve every single posting that goes up through the web-team) but they take very little notice of most of what goes on our moodle as that is entirely inward facing and the content is teaching and learning focussed. As the moodle developer, I am setting up the moodle 2 system that we are moving to and I anticipate having very little responsibility for the actual content on the front page once it goes live - beyond having constructed the theme and the look and feel of the page. Richard
Comment 2: I would not expect the adminstrator to decide what the front page should look like (except in a very small organisation). They may do the technical implementation of what is needed, or they might help someone else to do it themselves. Also, you really don't want to be the one dealing with the politics of who gets space for 'their' link on the front page. On the other hand, you do want to make sure about technical things, like ensuring that the CSS used in the theme is maintainable and works on all browsers, and that the choice of blocks does not cause performance problems.
Comment 3: There's an implication in your question and Tim and Richard's responses that your Moodle has a "public face." Ours does not. Only the login page can be reached by the unwashed, er, by people not enrolled in a course. In our circumstance, a bunch of educational admins decided what we wanted on our front page, which was a list of courses in which the user is enrolled. In the case of a public face, I'd say the admin's job is as T & R described, except also to remind the hucksters that user access is the primary purpose.
Comment 4: We also do not have our students use the official Moodle front page.  They arrive from our other website, and are immediately directed either to the "My Courses" page or to their specific course.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Newbie...any suggestions?
Post description: Hi all! I'm new to moodle and I was just wondering if any had suggestions to share. It seems like a cool site to use with teaching as that is what I plan on doing in the near future. Any suggestions as to how to incorporate this site into my teaching plans would be great! Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Kelsey, There is so much to Moodle that it can be ovewhelming. A simple process we learned to follow with our Moodle training is to teach teachers to first do only the basics with Moodle, such as upload course essentials, like syllabus, work, resources, etc. and try Moodle with traditional teaching in a "blended" model.  Some time later ( maybe weeks, or more) we introduce more interactive parts of Moodle such a discussions, glossary, quizzes, etc.  and let staff / students gradually utilize this functionality and make moodle more/more interactive.   This avoids overwhelming staff and students with too much functionality and avoids un-realisitc expectations and even burnout from trying to do too much too soon.   "less" is often "more" valuable when exploring a tool as rich as Moodle.  Hope I didn't mis-interpret your question. Mark Hilliard Minneapolis, MN USA
Comment 2: There are a few books which I've found fantastic in using Moodle - they are aimed at 1.9 rather than Moodle 2, but many of the hints and tips are still great, even if the exact details are slightly different in some cases. The best of the bunch for me has been Mary Cooch's Moodle for Teaching 7-14 Year Olds - Beginner's Guide although there are many others to choose from if you look a the Books and Manuals section of this site. Richard

Forum Post: 
Post title: Tracking Progress
Post description: I have a list of 10 - 15 events or items that i need each student to complete before they are considered complete for the term. This is pass/fail situation. The number of events cans vary per student. As an example - I want the student or instructor to enter in each time they witness a particular ailment while treating a patient, the section of the clinic it occurred with a time and date stamp. At various points in the academic year the instructor should be able to run a report by student to see who has not participated or witness a particular ailment. I know could set up a quiz with each ailment and just put 0's in all scores and then put a 1 in when they completed each task but knowing how many they did would be valuable data as well. HELP!!!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You could set up separate groups, add a forum, and each incident is recorded as a forum post.  Date stamped and train students to add the other required information. There are then options to use the gradebook. Or you could look at installng ForumNG which has some cool features that may help. AFAIK there is no simple way to gather/process this sort of information, except maybe a database .

Forum Post: Post title: CK-ERP (Open Source ERP / CRM / MRP) v.0.22.1 released (with Moodle connector) Post description: Hi, folks, I have posted a new release, v.0.22.1, of CK-ERP, at SourceForge.Net, http://sourceforge.net/projects/ck-erp . This release features connectors for Moodle, Atutor, vTiger, XRMS, WordPress, b2evolution and e107. Nine modules have Spanish screen translations added. Special thank is due to Guillermo Patterer from Fiberair for providing the Spanish translation. CK-ERP is an open source accounting/MRP/ERP/CRM system that runs on top of multiple middlewares. It comprises 22 modules - Administration, i18n, Contact Management, Customer Relationship, Customer Self Service, Vendor Relationship, Ledger, Bank Reconciliation, MRP, Warehouse, Inventory, Service, AP, AR, PO, SO, Quotation, POS for Cashier, POS for Manager, HR, Staff Self Service and Payroll. Operating platform can either be LAMP or LAPP. It provides accounting and back office functionalities to SMEs and utilizes the underlying middleware to administer accounts/groups. Please report error and suggestion to the discussion group / mailing list, CK-ERP-en(at)googlegroups.com or CK-ERP-zh_CN(at)googlegroups.com . General history and expected development is available at the discussion group's Archive. Supported MiddleWares: eGroupWare, Horde-GroupWare; Zencart, CRELoaded, osCommerce; Drupal, Joomla, Mambo, e107, XOOPS, Xaraya; Moodle, Atutor; vTiger, XRMS; WordPress, b2evolution; TikiWiki; phpBB. Information/Demo Websites: http://ck-erp.org http://ck-erp.net Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Congratulations CK ,and many Thanks !! from Max Zuniga in Canada Comment 2: You're welcome. CK Comment 3: Hi, folks, I am afraid there is an oversight in writing up Step 6A within CK-ERP's Installation Manual, in relation to installing CK-ERP within Moodle. Below is the corrected Step 6A, Step 6A (for Moodle users only) - Login as Moodle Administrator - Turn editing on - Blocks -> Add (HTML) -> Block Title: CK-ERP; Content (please make sure the editor is toggled to allow raw html source input): CK-ERP -> Save changes - Site Administration -> Users -> Permissions -> Define roles -> Add a new role -> Name: ck-erp-user -> Add a new role - Site Administration -> Users -> Permissions -> Assign roles -> ck-erp-user -> Make sure [Current context : Site] -> move admin user (along with other appropriate users) from [potential users] to [existing users] - AT THIS POINT, DO NOT CLICK ON THE [CK-ERP] BLOCK LINK. Instead use your browser to visit directly http://(domainname or localhost)/(moodle root)/admin/ck-admin/index.php - Complete the Test Environment installation as described in Step 10 to step 16 The added steps are to make use of the newly added 'role' feature to ensure only administrative staff (ie excluding teachers and students) is able to access the embedded CK-ERP application. Cheers, CK Comment 4: In response to a user request, I have produced an alternate CK-ERP entry block design (when running within a Moodle environment). You could review the new design at, http://ck-erp.org/moodle Cheers, CK Label:

Post title: Embedding video presentations in Moodle
Post description: Have you been thinking in embedding real PowerPoint-based video presentations in Moodel. PresentationTube provides a desktop presentation recorder and video sharing network to help instructors, students, virtual presenters, and business professionals record, upload and share quality, accessible, and interactive video presentations. PresentationTube Recorder integrates a variety of presentation aids and synchronizes presenter's audio and video, PowerPoint slides, whiteboard, drawing board, and Web content. PresentationTube presentations provide a scrollable slide thumbnail allowing the user to move to the respective video content and control both the time and progress of video presentation. A video presentation allows interactivity also via Facebook social plug-in and self-assessment quizzes, allowing learners to be heard and involved. PresentationTube video presentations are accessible via desktop and mobile devices and can be used in flipped classrooms, home revisions, e-learning and blended learning environments, distance education settings, virtual conferences, and business orientations. No need for developing new materials or third-party software. PresentationTube is free and videos are hosted on high-speed media streaming servers to provide a rich experience with no ads, no banners, and unlimited bandwidth and storage space.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Please answer ONE question??  Project for a college course on online program implementation
Post description: Hi All, I am looking for someone in K-12 Moodling that can talk about program implementation, converting courses from face-to-face to online, accessibility issues, etc. I promise that it will be very short and can be via email. this interview is an assignment for the Master's program in Online Teaching and Learning at California State University-East Bay. They use Blackboard, but I am using Moodle for special needs students for my capstone project. So . . . I'm turning to my fellow K-12 Moodlers for help! So is anybody out there, with all the free time they have as educators, willing to answer some questions for me? I have been using Moodle for almost eight years. Let me know by reply, as I need to have this done in the next week and a half. Here are some of the questions I would ask: 1. How long has your online program used Moodle, did you switch from another CMS? If so, why did you switch to Moodle? 2. Is your program a major transfer of classes from facd-to-face to online? If so, how did you train traditional classroom teachers to transfer their classes to online. 3. Do you have official professional development courses to train teachers on how to use Moodle, transfer courses, give tech support? If so, do you hold face-to-face workshops or do you use Moodle? 4. What kind of tech support is available at your institution? In your opinion, is it effective for the teachers? For the students? 5. How involved are your parents involved in your online learning program? Do you have parent accounts? 6. How do you ensure that your courses are as accessible as possible for disabled students? Do you follow Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)? 7. How do you host your online program? If hosted locally, do you have proper server space, memory, and broadband access for your online program? Who is in charge of the server? 8. How do you assess the effectiveness of a particular course? The entire program? 9. What is the workload of an online instructor vs. a traditional face-to-face instructor? Do they receive more or less compensation? Is tenure affected by whether an instructor teaches online or not? 10. Do you have a blended or online only program? 11. Are your courses using media-rich content? If not, why? If so, do you have problems with compatibility? 12. Do you integrate third party Web 2.0 tools in your program? If not, why? 13. Who owns the course content in your program, the institution or the instructor? 14. How does your institution monitor fair-use, plagiarism and copyright infringement. 15. What provisions/accommodations do you make for LD students? Sincerely, Jamey Barber jbarbercsueb@gmail.com
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jamey, Just a comment on question 13 (I am not a K-12 teacher).  In our school neither the institution nor the instructor owns the content. 90% is open content, owned by the educational community as a whole. 10% is licensed courseware owned by a publisher. So I recommend rephrasing it to: 13. Who owns the course content in your program, the institution, the instructor, a publisher, or the public as open content? Incidentally, I recommend that all institutions build policies and contracts that state all content created by staff is created for the general public and is owned by the public. As more people share Moodle courses via many Moodle Hubs (ver 2.0), this will be an important policy.

Post title: MoodleMoot UK-Ireland 2018
Post description: Just bought my ticket and reserved my hotel room, I managed to find somewhere really close this time with private parking. I'm hoping to do a few days Skiing at Glencoe the preceding weekend, so will have my car with me. Who else is going? Really pleased to see that the change in location to Glasgow has also resulted in a drop in the ticket price and my hotel is cheaper. I'm also happy to see that we're university based this year. I much prefer that to the soulless conference centre/hotel used for the London events. I'm hoping this means a return to lecture hall tiered seating for the conference sessions, which is so much better than the "dining room" arrangement. Note to the organisers (Gavin etc), the huge (2.7MB) image of Strathclyde Uni on the booking page means that (a) When you PDF the booking page the PDF is very large and (b) when you click through each page of the booking process you get landed on the image with nothing else visible, so you have to scroll right down a lot to get to the actual form you need to deal with. One request for 2019! Can you please try and get the dates confirmed much earlier, March/April is a really busy period for me and while MoodleMoot is normally the week before Easter, that hasn't always been the case and there are other things going on around then which I would like to do, but can't commit to until the MoodleMoot dates are out. Unfortunately, the announcement usually comes too late, so I miss out on other activities . I appreciate that there is a lot to organise, but as a committee member for another large software conference, we usually managed to confirm a lot further in advance, one year we managed 12 months notice!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tim. I'll be there. I'm looking forward to seeing Glasgow again. Perhaps our social night will involve a small Ceilidh (fingers crossed!) -Jess
Comment 2: Brownie points for spelling it right Jess ???????

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle hosting/administration support
Post description: We are currently using an accredited provider to Moodle to host our site and provide the main site administration support. I have been administering my programs on Moodle for some time and am wondering at what stage I should consider not using the external provider. I have fair knowledge of the site but is the site administration role very complex and how will I know if I will cope with taking this over? I need to make the most cost effective decision so has anyone been in this position or can you give me any advice?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: http://moodle.com/partners/
Comment 2: Some Moodle partners offer training programs (which can be online if you can't get to face to face ones) specifically for administrators. Perhaps it might be worth your while enrolling on one of those?
Comment 3: Hi Teresa, I think this would depend on the size and scope of the site that needs admining and whether you are thinking of just admining the front end or want to get your hands on the back end web server and database setup. I run a Moodle with 4-5000 FE & HE students across a wide curriculum of subjects. I have quite modest support requests from staff but then our Moodle has been allowed to languish for several years and expectations here could be higher. If you already feel comfortable with running a course, pure front end admin is actually quite easy and should feel familiar after you've oriented yourself but you will still need back end technical support and at least someone who can lead you if you feel out of your depth - these forums are very useful for those times. Unless you already have the skill set, you will need someone to handle the backend stuff for you. After 2 years of doing this I still need that technical back up myself. Most of the problems we have as an institution are not with Moodle but with the supporting infrastructure. I'd recommend starting by asking for an admin account from your host and familiarise yourself with the new menus and options it gives you. Hope that helps, Sam.
Comment 4: Hi Teresa, We were on a hosted site for another open-source LMS as part of a consortium.  The cost was increasing every year, we knew we had to make a change. I setup test servers with both LMSs installed.  My OS of choice is Ubuntu.  The reason why we went with Moodle over the other was the ease of management, features, and support community found here. If you are not familiar with Linux, I would not go this route.   i cannot say anything about the Windows version, since I am not familiar with it. If you are, setup a test server while you still have the hosted version, so you can see the "inner workings" To this day I have our working Moodle server, a test server with the same version I run on the working, and another test server with the latest version of Moodle.  I do not upgrade until I am comfortable with the latest version, and I know it is functioning. Good Luck!
Comment 5: If I understand you correctly its just admin, not maintenance of the code / upgrades, you are going to stay with the same host I take it? If so, admin is not too bad as long as you stay away from some of the server settings, and in later versions of Moodle dont go installing / upgrading random plugins you have not tested before hand. The best approach is probably to take it a step at a time, ask for access if you dont have it and try to deal with some of the issues that arise. Another option would be to get some cheap hosting with a "one click install" of Moodle where you can experiment without making a mess of your production system!

Post title: Moodle adaptation
Post description: Not sure if this is the right place to post this but here goes... My client would like to use Moodle but has some extra requests that maybe some of you developers out there could help with. They want an assessment system where they can create questions and group them i.e. Question Group 1 = Questions on Linux, Question Group 2 = Questions on Moodle etc...  Then For each project that comes along, they can create a New Test for the project that consists of any number of 'Question Groups' plus some one-off questions.   This project could be serving groups of 10 to 200 people and we need these people to be able to logon, take the test and the system to output a Spreadsheet with the results of the project - i.e. all the students results. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Graham, There doesn't seem to be anything exceptional about what you are doing. Your "Question groups" would be Question categories in the Moodle Question bank . Quizzes are created by drawing questions from the Question bank. Quiz results can be downloaded in Excel, ODS, or text format. Maybe you do have some special requirements, but we would need to hear more.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using Moodle in an Elementary Classroom
Post description: Hi everyone,

I'm a first year elementary teacher who loves to implement technology. I've used Moodle in college and thought it was a great program that could be used in an elementary school setting. Yet, I believe that I would be the only person in my school using it. Would I need to have the school or the district put it on a server or could I run it individually and go from there?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi BJ, Technically it's quite easy to do. Whether it would be permitted by your school and district, I don't know. You'll have to ask them. There are lots of ethical and security issues with online sites open to children. Cheers, Glenys
Comment 2: Ok. Let's say they allow me to use it but I can't put it on the server. Will I have to find my own server and web host ? Could all of that be done on my home PC?
Comment 3: Hi BJ, Yes, you will have to find a web host (that is, you can use your own PC as a server but have to be quite techie to know how to do that). If you do a search for "web hosts" you will find a number of discussions on this topic. Cheers, Glenys

Post title: OXJAM CHARITY EVENT
Post description: I am looking for bands to play at an OXJAM (part of oxfam) event in West London - Ealing below are the details. It will be on the 16th Oct in The Lodge Tavern . The whole idea is to find bands/artists that are willing to do famous song covers but also to perform original songs that they've written. There will be at least 6 bands/artists involved who will be performing a mix of these songs. The genre of the music isn't essential but should be already playing in gigs and pubs already. New talent can be involved but would prefer someone who has a following already. There will be a mashup of 2 bands who will perform the cover song together so a constant rehearse and meet up of all the bands is necessary. There will be a battle of the bands competitions consisting of 3 rounds (6 bands to start – all pair in 3 in the first round) , 2nd round(4  bands go through out of the 3 pairs) 3rd round (2 bands) then last round is the winner where they get to play original music. I am specifically looking for artists who able to do cover songs but have the opportunity to sing their own music. If interested please email me on yohanns3456@hotmail.co.uk thank you

Abstract Submission Deadline Extended until 22 June 2008

Conference on eLearning and eResearch in the Arab World,
Part of
The 5th Congress of

 World (SRO5),
Organized by
Arab Science and Technology Foundation (ASTF)

26-30 October 2008
Fez-Morocco

Conference Objectives
The conference will feature speakers, papers and posters from the
 international eLearning eResearch community, which focus on:
• Raising awareness for eLearning and eResearch 
activities
 in Arab
 countries,

 and eResearch activities,

 and eResearch initiatives,
• Prospects, trends and challenges of eLearning and eResearch in the
 Arab world,
• Presenting success stories of eLearning and eResearch in the Arab
 world.

Conference Scopes
• eLearning and eResearch Applications in Life Sciences, Materials,

 Arts, and Humanities,

 for Science and Industry,

All Abstracts should strictly comply with the style and format as

Forum Post: 
Post title: Thoughts on activity and course completion
Post description: Maybe this is the wrong place to ask this...but I'm curious and don't really see a better place. With Moodle 2.0, we got activity and course completion.  And they rock.  My (work) life is so much simpler now (and by simpler, I mean my external reports no longer take hours to run and my core-hack student transcript that took 15 minutes per student is no longer necessary). But here's my question...why don't we have a forum to specifically post questions about course completion and activity completion?  Okay, so activity completion could be covered by the specific activity...but course completion questions don't really fit anywhere.  Courses and course formats doesn't seem to be right place.  Maybe I'm the only one with questions/concerns?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Would the 'Teaching with Moodle' forum be an appropriate place?
Comment 2: Maybe...but it isn't really about teaching...it is about how stuff works and making sure people get credit when you're done teaching. I kind of think it needs it's own forum in Other components.
Comment 3: The point is "Moodle in English" has some 80 odd(?) forums and this has been a long standing complaint of users as well as the moderators. See one such "big" discussion: "Ideas needed: moodle.org improvements" https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=196302 . Since then the administrators managed to delete a couple of forums. OK, there were some (high profile) exceptions where new forums appeared without warning. But that is a different topic. In any case, suggestions on moodle.org itself belong to the "Moodle community sites" forum: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=7135 .

Forum Post: 
Post title: What hosting to use for my needs?
Post description: I have been using moodle for the past 6 months for my flight school and created over 2000 online questions.  I'm thinking about branching out and starting a side business creating online testing solutions for other flight schools and possibly other types of businesses.  What host would you recommend to support this endeavour?  I would like to be able to manage all the different businesses from one panel and have flexibility both in cost and expanding the amount of server resources that I need when and if the business grows.  I live in the U.S. Thanks so much!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The usual place for questions on Moodle hosting is "Hardware and Performance" http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=596 Run a search in that forum first.
Comment 2: Matthew, We've had a Moodle install at Rackspacecloud.com for a while and I tried Turnkeylinux.org.  Rackspace is flexible and not that expensive (I believe a virtual server with 256 ram starts at around 10 dollars a month); the benefit is that it's very scalable (resizing servers takes just a few minutes).  A downside is you'll need significantly more server side expertise (which my partner handled). For Turnkey (which uses Amazon's web services and storage) it was about 30 dollars a month minimum for service (but it's also scalable; setup was very easy with the Turnkeylinux tutorials provided). Personally I'm using Bluehost.com which is around 80 dollars a year (but you can have unlimited domains and it's all cPanel setup).  I'm pretty satisfied with my service for a Wordpress blog , I also have a Moodle setup, but it's not receiving any traffic (it's demo purposes only).  But the blog receives about 1000 visits a day and load times seem to be good. Best of luck...let us know which way you go with the hosting.
Comment 3: I would also recommend look into ExamView as a powerfull test platform with many alternatiives; Moodle, Web, classroom and classroom clickers (Interesponse software part of Examview)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Which is the most used question format in Moodle ?
Post description: Can you please tell me which is the best format and also the mostly used format in Moodle ? I personally like Aiken format for multiple questions But I was researching about the widely used format !!! Ayone knows which one is it ? Replies and Help will be appreciated !!!! Thanks Gaurav Kalia
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: ExamView is my choice because you can use the same question bank/ test in many different venues, e.g., in class with clickers; over the internet or LAN and LMS systems. If you decide to use ExamView, there are some issues with importing into Moodle but that fix is easy-- see forum; upload zipped question by the file button on left to designated folder, modify exam import page (Exam View (Blackboard) and then point to it from the quiz/exam import.
Comment 2: I personally like the GIFT format because I can make sure the question names, category, etc are all addedduring the import. Cheers Teresa
Comment 3: I guess GIFT is really all I know. With our question writing day coming up I wondered if there was a visual editor of some kind for creating GIFT files.
Comment 4: If you want to get questions into Moodle quickly by authoring them offline, use GIFT or Aiken. They are easy to type. If you want to transfer questions from one Moodle to another, use Moodle XML format. That can represent all the question options.

Post description: Hi Moodle gurus, We at Kenfuse.com are looking to set up compelling courseware for tech students following MIT's opencourseware guidelines. Post title: Just compiled a short list of open source software for elearning
Post description: Hi Moodlers, I've compiled a list of the most popular and useful open source software packages for elearning. I'm probably preaching to the converted here... http://blog.matbury.com/2011/10/19/open-source-software-for-elearning/
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Matt.  Where's bigbluebutton in your list?  If what I've heard about it is true, it should be a major player in elearning.
Comment 2: I use bigbluebutton (BBB) it on my site to try and convince the administration to use Moodle; I have a hosted site apart from the institution I work at. They've been trying to make a decision about an LMS for some time... any how, things like BigBlueButton and Openmeeting are standard plugins with Moodle 2.1.2 (many more plugins std). The catch is, you must point to the server where BBB and/or OM are installed or located. Recap, plugins already installed to enable Moodle functionality-- vendor opensource software (both BBB and OM opensource) installed and pointed to (on plugin settings in Moodle). I'm in Malaysia on +8 timezone but could arrange a demo; I believe you can go to bigbluebutton.org and see/use the demo from there. BBB is awesome with it's presentation view, whiteboard, chat (all & private), video sharing and conference/listen (VOIP); the VOIP I believe is a Freeswitch technology and requires some thinking/server to dial in and have a ID, etc. There appears to be little "overhead"; I did a demo using a Celcom Broadband and the other guy Streamyx and it worked fine! Openmeeting is BBB on steroids (16, 50, 150 people modes) for conferences, meetings and webinars... Hope this helps?
Comment 3: This is excellent Matt.
Comment 4: Hi Matt. Great post. I added you to my bloglist at http://moodurian.blogspot.com . I've okay to be converted more than once. Frankie Kam

Post description: I'm creating a proposal for a StackOverflow-like Q&A website for Moodle users, administrators and developers. As you could imagine, I'm not suggesting to replace the existing Moodle.org, but to provide a new free tool to the Moodle community which could help in obtaining more focused and structured support and in growing the community itself. Forum Post: 
Post title: Shouldn't Moodle be a Topic in Meetup.com?
Post description: Hi, I would love the opportunity to hang out with other Moodlers from time-to-time. I have found Meetup.com a great way to find local meetings of niche groups. I currently attend a Meetup organized webmaster group and always learn something new. I could never find a Moodle meetup group on Meetup.com; therefore, I was considering sponsoring a meetup. While looking over the new group setup form I noticed that Moodle is not an available topic. I find this odd due to the huge Moodle user base. Do you guys think that Meetup.com organized local Moodle meetings would be something worth pursuing. I don't see why it wouldn't work, as long as there is a significant local user base. I think we need to start by getting Meetup.com to add Moodle as an available topic. I could pursue this but Moodle Headquarters may yield more clout than I do. Once they are aware of the popularity of Moodle I suspect this would be a "no-brainer". What do you guys think?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The main question I'd have is why use Meetup.com instead of any of the other ways to plan events? In fact, lots can be done within Moodle itself and it could be easier to get people together if they're already registered. But maybe Meetup.com added interesting features since I last used it. I wouldn't be opposed to using it, I'm just wondering what the advantage is.
Comment 2: Alexandre, I agree that promoting an "event" would be best done on Moodle, but what I am talking about is small local groups of 10-20. Over the last several years, when I checked the event calendar I have never seen any Moodle event of any kind within 3,000 miles of me. I have found Meetup.com to be very effective at organizing small local meetings. While using the Moodle site to promote small local Moodle meetings is "singing to the choir" promoting a meeting with Meetup.com would expose Moodle to many others that never heard of it. You do have a point about using existing Moodle resources. The more I think about it, maybe the best solution would be to use and possibly integrate both. Maybe Meetup.com could set up an RSS feed so that every Moodle meetup organized with Meetup.com could be displayed in the events area automatically. I think leveraging the strengths of both resources might be a powerful combination.
Comment 3: Not to belabour the point but I'd say that Facebook is probably as good as Meetup.com in terms of exposure to Moodle. And there could be a neat mashup to integrate these events in Moodle. Also, for increased exposure to such events, social media could pick them up (Edublogs, podcasts, Twitter, FriendFeed...). Again, not to denigrate Meetup. I just have some difficulty understanding the importance of having Moodle as a topic. Sorry if I'm thick.
Comment 4: I don't know - I think he has a good point about Meetup. Meetup still attracts people who want to meet "live" and in person, whereas  Facebook is so often about collecting virtual friends you're never going to chat with in person. I like the Meetup idea.

Forum Post: 
Post title: You're Invited to a free Moodle forum!
Post description: Our free, one-hour Moodle Users' Forums are back! In these online sessions we bring you a speaker or Moodle topic, and offer you a chance to ask Moodle questions, share ideas with fellow teachers, and pick up tips and tricks that will have you teaching online with the best of 'em. Join us for the December session: December 8, 2010 | 3:30-4:30PM ET Special guest Dr. Ray Pastore, Assistant Professor of Instructional Technology at Watson School of Education, University of North Carolina Wilmington (UNCW) shares: Mobile Learning: How to use and develop mobile apps for the classroom Are you interested in developing mobile apps or having your students develop mobile apps in the classroom? If so, then this presentation is for you! During this presentation we will discuss cases of mobile learning use and demonstrate how to develop mobile apps using Google’s easy-to-use App Inventor tool. Post title: Jog Your Memory, Remember Everything, JogLab
Post description: Dear Moodle using, technology loving educators/learners, I hope this is OK for this forum, if it's not please feel free to remove it. I’ve just finished creating www.JogLab.com , a completely free web-based teaching and learning tool that makes remembering stuff quick, simple and fun ( quick video tutorial on main page ). I’d LOVE any advice/ volunteers to help spread the word about this tool; JogLab needs thousands of daily ‘hits’ to cover running costs but I believe many learners/ teachers will find it useful once they know of its existence. I don’t have a great deal of time so I’d be really grateful for any advice or help you might give on any aspect of JogLab/ promotion suggestions etc. These are my ideas so far: · Emailing teachers and asking them to forward a poster (this one: http://www.joglab.com/resources/JogYourMemory.RememberEverything.JogLab.doc ) to their learning/ teaching contacts. Are there any email lists that are appropriate? · Asking teachers who like JogLab to post a link to JogLab on newsgroups they use ( on site functionality exists to do this on Facebook etc.) · Asking all educators/ learners to give feedback, propose areas of collaboration, contacts or ideas for promotion ( danTHECAT@joglab.com (put THECAT out)). · Asking (and please consider this an ask!) for volunteers (special skill or time) to help spread the word or help out (please email volunteersTHECAT@joglab.com (put THECAT out)) Hopefully JogLab.com will have a lasting impact for many types of learner and make teaching even more fun. Please email me if you can be of any help or would like a colour printed poster sent to you or are interested in a JogLab t-shirt. Any constructive comments/ support/ help very gratefully received. Thanks a million, Dan Weaver Email danTHECAT@joglab.com (put THECAT out) Web: www.JogLab.com , http://danofweaver.googlepages.com

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz moderation
Post description: I am getting repeated requests from teachers asking about how to send quizzes for pre-moderation, and quiz results for post moderation, so they can use quiz for online exams. I am wondering which forum is best to discuss this as I think it is probably something needed by many higher education institutes and it might be that a tool could be developed to assist with the proccess of moderation of exams. If we can get a discussion going, then we might be able to scope what is required. The request seems to be that for pre-exam moderation you need to export a view of the quiz that shows all the questions with the right and wrong answers, as well as all the feedback and score related to each question. For post-exam moderation there needs to be a way to pick out three participants results (top, middle, bottom) and export them to give to the moderator. It might be that the best export method is to .pdf into pre-exam moderation file and a post-exam moderation file. Is anyone else interested in a tool like this? What would be important to your learning institute? I have discussed with someone from another institute, they call the "moderator" the "examiner" so the terms might need some further thought. Also she suggests it would be good for the person receiving the file to be able to pretend to take the exam so they see it as the student would (particularly if questions and/or answers are randomised). Looking forward to hearing from others.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Supermemo | Spaced repetition
Post description: Just curious is anyone has looked at implementing anything like spaced repetition ( which is AKA distributed practice) etc in Moodle. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SuperMemo https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_practice https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spaced_repetition A quote: Spaced repetition is a learning technique that incorporates increasing intervals of time between subsequent review of previously learned material in order to exploit the psychological spacing effect . Alternative names include spaced rehearsal , expanding rehearsal , graduated intervals , repetition spacing , repetition scheduling , spaced retrieval and expanded retrieval . [1] http://digitalpromise.org/2015/01/22/ask-the-cognitive-scientist-distributed-practice/ -Derek
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've just had a few more days working with some 13 year old learners.  I've seen the german vocab and french vocab training, computer based practice.  I'm now interested in this in the science area. This is an old program http://www.flashcardlearner.com/articles/what-is-spaced-repetition/ based around the flash card model.  The trouble I've had is like Rutherford said: "Physics is impossible, until you understand it, then it is trivial".  Looking a the topic of solids, liquids and gases (ie Particle theory of Matter) I am sure some carefully chosen testing regimes could help. I have tried a few questions in the regular Moodle quiz bank, but it's not quite enough, I'm not sure the best way to set it up.  Plus I'm not sure I am even clear what I want. Maybe this:  38 themes.  Serve up 15 questions each evening on the themes, on 15 themes, not random, but in a specified order.  When they student gets a question in each theme right 3X, that theme is checked off for (say) 5 days before being reintroduced. -Derek
Comment 2: I've found another buzz word:   "adaptive learning" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_learning Quite a recent article from Educause: http://er.educause.edu/articles/2016/10/adaptive-learning-systems-surviving-the-storm Interestingly enough Bill and Melinda have pumped some $$ into this at least once: http://er.educause.edu/articles/2016/3/adaptive-learning-platforms-creating-a-path-for-success Sadly, I think this has ended up with this, yet another  "proprietary education technology" : Every student learns differently. That’s why at CTU, we connect you to a personalized learning system called intellipath™; our proprietary education technology that personalizes course material completely around you. http://www.coloradotech.edu/online-degree-programs/intellipath I've found some interesting student feedback online to a nursing exam training programme.  "I sorted out my practice for the Level 5 nursing exam online with only 200 questions"  Sounded very much like the Keller programme put online. https://www.elsevier.com/education It's called 'evolve'. My question remains: with small or no resources, how can I set up a range of question banks.  Then to have the quiz engine select questions from each category (in order) and then 'tick off' a category when X number of questions are got correct by the student. -Derek
Comment 3: You could look at this - https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_adaptivequiz Not sure it does exactly what you want, but maybe could be tweaked?
Comment 4: Also, https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_qpractice - does not implement spaced repetition, at least not yet, but that could be added. https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_flashcard might also be relevant.
Comment 5: I maintain  the Question Practice module that Tim mentions and I had thought about developing that type of functionality but it has never come to the top of my "things to do now" list.
Comment 6: I have been using Anki as a student recently and its power is quite amazing. To me it is completely different  to  Moodle - Anki decks are learner designed and  the learner sets their own goals while Moodle is teacher based. I can't see how how ( or why) you would want to integrate them.
Comment 7: For foreign language, Pimsleur follows this method. The way I envisioned implementing this in Moodle is to put my questions into cateogries " Lesson 1", "Lesson 2", etc.  Then use the review quiz plugin (don't remember the exact name) to create all encompassing quizzes for review. I was also going to have 20 question quizzes.  10 would be new material.  5 from the last 5 lessons, and the last 5 from any lesson before that.  I have not tried to setup a quiz yet, but from what I have read, the add random functionality that is build into the Moodle core can handle it. I also think that as a person works with Moodle their question bank will be better at handling incorporating previous material into new questions.  Although, I am thinking in terms of reading lessons, listening skills, and foreign language. Also, from what I read about the Pimsleur method, spaced repetition is not based on if the student gets a certain answer correct or incorrect.  It is based on introducing a topic, reviewing it 5 minutes later.  Reviewing it an hour later, review it the next day, reviewing it in 3 days, reviewing it the next week, reviewing it in 2 weeks, reviewing it the next month, randomly throwing the material in. The whole point is to increase the number of times  that a student is exposed to a certain word.  At first it will be "that sounds familiar", then it is more recognition, until finally it is truly knowing the word that it is a part of the student.  For some student that can happen in 5 exposures to the word, while for other students they may need 40 exposures to the word. Melissa

Post title: Adding moodle to a website
Post description: Hi I've used moodle as a student as part of my PGCE course, and now I want to create my own moodle site for the students I am teaching.  The site I use to use had a proper web address and a log in. I am completely new to website creating so installed a moodle package with easy php.  I created a moodle site but it is only an intranet site, how do I change this to being an internet site my students can access from home? Many thanks Andrew Wilson
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Andrew, I was in the same position as you a few years ago. (I teach in a secondary school in N Wales) If you are keen to set this up yourself you should use the extensive documentation in Moodle Docs to help you ... 1. choose a service provider and package (ask someone with a moodle site who they use!) 2. create MySQL database 3. upload the moodle files 4. install Or alternatively you could ask your LEA if they have plans to set up their own installations or use a moodle partner to take the hassle out of it and let you concentrate on preparing the course materials.
Comment 2: Andrew, make sure you read all the information related to securing your Moodle site if you have deployed an all in one package like easy php or xampp. These packages are just fine for running Moodle locally on your desktop but should never be put into a production environment (even an intranet) without first securing the database and making sure the moodledata folder is located outside the public folder. There have been reports of people ignoring these warnings and then thinking Moodle is insecure because they experienced problems.
Comment 3: Anyone that is using Moodle as a website, would you please share the url?  Thanks so much!
Comment 4: Hi Paula, We don’t use moodle as a website and in my opinion it is not a good choice, there are couple of modules may be helpful here (pls check on the module sections !!) We have tried all including integration with other tools but there are lots of functionality issues. I would recommend using a CMS for website ( we use joomla) or just HTML pages and link to your moodle. I know this is no what you are looking for just my 2 cents…. Joe K

If you have any idea about 'new' (post 2004) E-Learning technologies that could be implemented in these three existing areas, could you let us know? This would help push our research in the right direction. Many thanks

Post title: Moodle Moot Albuquerque Materials
Post description: Many thanks to everyone who attended, worked, helped, presented and in any other way was invovled with the Moot in Albquerque. It was great to see and talk with people from the Moodle community that I have not seen in a while, and to meet many new Moodlers. I have all of the presentation audio from the Moodle Moot. I am also collecting the remainder of the slides and URLs used in the presentations. I will edit the audio (not for content...but to cut out the part where the speaker is giving their presentation, and to mix together the audio that featured more than one speaker) and convert them MP3 over the next week. During that time I will convert the slides to PDF. The finished files will be compiled and hosted on our site when they are ready. I will send out an email message to all of the attendees with a link, as well as post a message to the Moodle Moot Albuquerque forum , the general forum and anywhere else someone requests that I post the link. I recently posted a very similar message to the Moodle Moot Albuquerque Discussion forum, and thought that this would be useful to be posted here. I apologize to those who are enrol(l)ed to both forums. Thanks again to everyone, I will post the finished files as soon as they are ready. jon

Forum Post: 
Post title: This forum post has been removed
Post description: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Andrea, Greetings from Spain! Short answer: Yes. Moodle has online payment integration built in & there are also additional 3rd party payment integration plugins: https://moodle.org/plugins/?q=payment For self-study language learning activities , I recommend exploring the Quiz module: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Quiz_activity & H5P module: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/H5P_activity I use both because each has its advantages & disadvantages according to what I want to achieve. For additional, asynchronous communicative activities between students &/or teacher & students, the forum module is very useful & flexible: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Forum_activity It works particularly well for anytime, anywhere, spontaneous communicative activities when students use the free Moodle mobile app: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Moodle_app It's a bit like having Facebook discussions on your phone but without all that bad stuff that using Facebook entails. In my opinion, 6 is a reasonable size for online synchronous video conferencing (Moodle has a wide range of integrations for video conferencing services: https://moodle.org/plugins/?q=conferencing & now has the BigBlueButton plugin included as standard) but for asynchronous communicative activities, I recommend larger cohorts within each course, e.g. ~30, so that there are more potential respondents to discussions at any one time & so discussions feel more responsive & therefore motivating to the students (forum discussions are a good strategy for increasing student engagement & reducing drop-out rates). It's also often the case that it's difficult to schedule lesson times to suit everyone all the time in small groups & so having larger cohorts gives greater flexibility for accommodating everyone's schedules, i.e. there's always a choice of times.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Hot potatoes
Post description: Ok, My turn for a question. Do you use "Hot potatoes" in your moodles - or stay with pure moodle format ? I suppose the real question is - is there a purest camp that sticks with moodle and nothing else, and a camp that use anything (and everything) ? Personally I like using hotpots as their construction can be very fast (compared to creating a quiz in moodle) The downside being that they do look like they have been "bolted on" to the course and are not fully integrated (still working on merging all of my style sheets etc to minimize this) The reason I ask is that some of the teachers I converse with prefer not to use hotpots (purely for the aesthetic reasons), and others do jump on board and ask me to show them how to use them.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I use Hotpotatoes a lot - I like the fact that they are easier to set up than the (current) Moodle quiz and the fact that you can customise them to look different from your own Moodle is an advantage rather than disadvantage to me. I love their integration with Moodle through Gordon's hotpot module and its successor the Quizport should encourage even more people to have a go with them. I was a bit of a purist at first in terms of integrating outside stuff into Moodle but now I realise that purist can often mean conservative - and I want to make the most of all the learning opportunities around that will work in Moodle.
Comment 2: Good to know there is an integration plugin for Hot Potatoes. I'll try it. I do find Moodle's quiz editor to be clunky and difficult to use. I use Moodle for grading, email-communication with students, discussion forums and for posting assignments. But I do pop out to more powerful Content Management System for page editing and publishing when ever possible. Moodle's page editing features aren't so bad per se. But Moodle's page-to-page navigation is a bit too spartan for me. I like what I get with various other content management systems a lot better. The trick is to hack the CMS so it saves the return address of the Moodle page you jumped away from, so the CMS reader can click back to the right spot in Moodle at any time. Most open source CMS systems can be hacked to work that way, one way or another. It's too bad it takes developer's skills to make that work, because CMS integration is a useful thing. I thought I saw a Drupal plugin for Moodle once. Might have to give that a try at some point.
Comment 3: Hi! I also use Hotpot a lot because kids like them, especially when they can use dragging activity as in vocabulary items. They like colours and I can't set them in moodle background (html or wiki). To me, it doesn't matter which application I use as long as it helps me to achieve what I want kids to learn.

Post title: Starting off-Moodle - I need advice
Post description: Hi All I am Osman , an e-learning student at UTS in Sydney, Australia. - I have begun trying to learn how to use Moodle because I need to (WANT to) use it when I return to my Home country (South Africa) for e-learning.  (Most South Africans are keen on Open Source, etc. I incidently am a curriculum advisor in the education department and my job is to promote e-learning. I have my own website www.wcape.school.za/sadeck/ but have realised that i cannot install Moodle on my own (dont have the technical knowhow - If anyone out there can help me do it GREAT - let me know) I am trying to immerse myself in the Moodle site to get a fix on how it works and operates - All postings have given me an idea of what the community does and is about. I am asking for some advice here - Would the best way for me to really learn Moodle be by having a trest site set up and then work with it to understand  - then i will probably have some questions , comments, postings etc to add to discussions. (At the moment i dont feel confident to converse) Can i link (a moodle site for my job ed section) through my existing site? Would really appreciate some advice (Incidently Moodle is my e-immersion site for my assignments and i am expected to be here IMMERSING!!) Cheers - Osman Sadeck (Ossie)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ossie, Welcome to Moodle. I think you will learn what you are looking for as this is what Moodle is all about, IMHO . "Would the best way for me to really learn Moodle be by having a trest
site set up and then work with it to understand  - then i will probably
have some questions , comments, postings etc to add to discussions. (At
the moment i dont feel confident to converse)" Yes, I believe you learn by using and trial and error. Please ask away, everyone will be willing and eager to help. You might also be surprised how much you can help others as they join the forums. "Can i link (a moodle site for my job ed section) through my existing site?" If I get what you mean, Yes you can. Just make a link on your site to the other site. "Would really appreciate some advice (Incidently Moodle is my
e-immersion site for my assignments and i am expected to be here
IMMERSING!!)"
Comment 2: Hello Bill Thanx for the advice - you and others have offered me hope - I am making the contacts to get me on my way - am taking up the offers to install and see demos---and Yes I will be around Cheers Osman
Comment 3: Osman, If you want the learning experience of installing Moodle yourself, check out the Moodle Documentation for Administration and you will find excellent instructions for installing Moodle.  Even for non-techies, the installation is not that bad. If you want help installing it, I'm willing.  Send me an email and we can discuss your system particulars. Scott
Comment 4: Hello Scott Thanx for the offer - have looked at the administration - tried the steps and found that some files wanted something like 18 hrs to upload  - not even sure if i was uploading to the correst place - will e-mail you with information re offer to install Cheers Osman
Comment 5: Hi Ossie, I have what I call MoodleChris at home and MoodleWork at work which are sandbox or standalone moodles  on  desktop machines.   Sandboxes are absolutely the way to learn in my opinion.   The initially installs I did back in Jan 06 were pretty simple on my Window XP professional OS. My first suggestion is to start really digging to the various forums and documations available here.   After 4 months, I am still rediscovering what is going on in each of the forums as my personal experience with Moodle grows.  Some of our volunteer experts don't look at this social forum, but stick to their speciality. Here is some more about me and my sandboxes.  The only way I can use the production Moodle is via the web.  I think that is running on Red Hat.  I have figured out how to download backup course files from there to my desktop, go into moodle and " upload " them into MoodleChris, then restore.   I played around with back and restore options on MoodleChris before attempting this.   Now I build courses on MoodleChris, do a backup, "download" that backup to my desktop, then get on the internet and upload the file to the production moodle and restore.  Piece of cake. Even figured out what kind of backup I need to do, to minimize the file size, yet achieve the results I want when I do a restore.   Remember that I am building course lessons  and doing quality control on existing course lessons.  I play with other activities in my sandboxes.   However, I can download an entire course with all the files and check it out on my MoodleChris or MoodleWork. Enjoy. Chris
Comment 6: Hi Chris Thanx for the reply - gives me ideas and great hope as well I know I can work with this as this is how I maintain my website and this is how I learnt about the web and edits, etc- I have the entire site on my PC - I work on it and then upload it to the webserver. I can download it off the server and make live changes as well . How did you get to install moodle on a local computer? because it seems that you are doing with moodle what I do with my site - this is what I want if possible. Cheers Osman
Comment 7: Hi Osman, I too am in Sydney (Nth Sydney to be exact) and am happy to help you get "immeresed". Drop me a line via email (see my profile for the addres) and maybe we can organise for you to come to my college for a demo. Let me know if that would be useful to you.
Comment 8: Hi Julian Thanks for the offer - will mail you with arrangements Cheers Osman

Forum Post: 
Post title: First International Conference on Information and Communication Technologies for Education and Training
Post description: TICET 2012 Call for papers Papers can be written in Arabic , French , or English . Information and Communications Technology (ICT) is increasing becoming an important means for education and training due to its ability and flexibility to enrich the education and training. It has become an important topic for adoption and development from officials and decision-makers. The purpose of TICET 2012 conference is to bring together many leading experts and researchers specialized in the Education and Training Technologies (ETT) from worldwide/global/international, to present their researches, studies, expertise and experiences, in order to: 1) Gain awareness of the latest developments and challenges related to ETT. 2) Case studies of the use of ETT in academia and Industry. TICET 2012 conference focuses on the following aspects related to ETT: Studying the past international experiences (in the past), Exploring the current outstanding issues and associated developments (at present), Exploring the prospects and associated initiatives and international projects (in future), Studying the use of ETT in the Arab world (between past, present and future). TICET 2012 conference intends to study the relationship between ETT ( as a means and as a subject ) and the following issues: The development of scientific research, The development of educational curricula and training, Planning and implementation of operational, educational and training policies. More >>> https://sites.google.com/site/errakmia28/1-11

Forum Post: 
Post title: Emotional Intelligence Training on Moodle
Post description: We would like to take this opportunity to inform our fellow Moodlers about our new public online course in Emotional Intelligence training. This course (of course) runs on Moodle. This course has now been under development since July 2004. Our selection of Moodle as the LMS for all our courses has turned out to be a huge bonus to the project. While this is a commercial project we are doing it more from our hearts than from any financial incentive. We hope however that the project will at least pay its own way. We have managed to integrate Moodle as our e-campus into a conventional HTML web site, near seamlessly and with very few problems. At this stage we are using 100% standard Moodle but the plan is to customise certain parts of the program to better suit our needs. We are therefore hoping to be able to offer some code snippets and maybe even some complete modules back to the Moodle community . Since Dan Golemans best selling book on Emotional Intelligence appeared about 10 years ago, the subject has intrigued and frustrated people. Most of the frustration results from the lack of any reliable method for developing Emotional Intelligence. We believe our training courses will address this issue. Also, as far as we are aware, we are the first to ever attempt this type of practical training on line. Our first course will be available from Wed 16 th March and other more advanced courses will be available latter in 2005. We are probably biased but we happen to think that our Introduction To Emotional Intelligence training course at $69.00 USD is very good value for money. The site address is www.fifthstate.com

Post title: Managing of lesson plans / learning goals / ...
Post description: Does anyone know software a teacher can use to manage lesson plans. I'd like to be able to collect my course notes, check which of the learning goals are met by a specific lesson, schedule  lessons, etc... Does not need to be a complete program on its own. Could also be a template for wordprocessor or addin for spreadsheet, a collection of macros, some tips on using them, etc... Can anyone point me to sites which collect (links to) such teacher resources?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle? put your comments in your courselines of Moodle "with eyes closed"?
Comment 2: Hi Jan, I have the same need, something to organize the whole course and something that other teachers can look at to make sense of how I am teaching.   That said, I think Ger is correct in suggesting that you use Moodle itself as a journal of your teaching.  For example, 1.  Notes that are hidden in the week-by-week central page.   Or... 2.  Notes in the Teachers Forum. You probably want more than that, so you may be interested that we addressed this issue at the Australia Moodle Gathering.  Martin presented modules coming up for 1.5 and later that would show progress towards goals by student.  We also pondered individualized goals, negotiated goals, and learner contracts.  In a demonstration on open source tools, I saw CMAP, concept mapping software, which works like Inspiration, making conceptual drawings.  I want to use that to draw visual maps of the lesson process I use in Moodle--combining classroom and online activities .  This might be the kind of metadata that we attach to courses to help allow transfer and exchange with other teachers.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle in the Chemistry Classroom
Post description: This summer the DivChed Committee on Computers in Chemical Education (CCCE) is hosting a ConfChem (online conference) on using Moodle in the Chemistry Classroom. We're seeking teachers or IT personel from all levels and areas that would like to share their Moodle expereience with our chem ed community by "authoring" a digital paper on their topic. Check out the announcement below and contact me if you have any questions or would like to submit a "paper" to conference. Authors and participants do not need to be members of ACS nor is there a fee to participate (you will need to create a free account with CCCE to participate). Announcing the Summer 2013 ConfChem Teaching and Learning Chemistry with Moodle Moodle (Modular Object-Oriented Dynamic Learning Environment) is an open-source Course  Management System (CMS) that can be used to create effective online learning sites. This conference will highlight how instructors at all levels have successfully used Moodle to teach chemistry and in turn made an impact on their students' learning. Papers will highlight the following topics: Innovative ways to use Moodle in the chemistry classroom. Ways to integrate Moodle into your existing curriculum Simple modifications or add-ons to Moodle which add exceptional value to teaching chemistry. Conference participants will also have a chance to demo the resources discussed and set up their own free courses using ChemEd DL’s Moodle server Anyone interested in submitting a paper should contact Linda Fanis (by replying to this post), or Janice Tomasik. Relevant Dates: May 3rd 2013- Deadline for papers May 31st  2013- Beginning of conference
