Post title: Course Policy
Post description: Is there a way that we can enable Course Policies as we do Site Policies. We want to have different policy for different Module, Can anyone help me, please?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Really this should be in the Using Moodle section as this forum is just for social chat but I will make a suggestion anyway. I don't know of any course policy feature but you could make a workaround.  Put an enrolment key on the course. You could upload into site files (it would have to be site files so everyone could see them) your course policy document and at the end of this document you could include the enrolment key for that particular course. Then in the description of the course in course administration>settings you can upload and display the course policy as a link using the hyperlink icon. People would have to open and read it in order to get the enrolment key to enter the course and in so doing would be agreeing to the policy. Well it is just an idea.
Comment 2: Hi Mary, Thanks a lot! Thats a great suggestion; I will try wotk around it! Ashutosh
Comment 3: Hi Mary, I tried but it is not working! My objective is to make user read few guidelines and rules before they enter the course and check the box or say continue if they agree or quit if they are dont. I want to make it bit presentable and professional. Can you assist now, please! Ashutosh
Comment 4: What is not working? I can't see how you can have a box to check - the only suggestion I made was to give them the enrolment key inside the document. I guess you could maybe use a google form where they have to read the policy and agree in a box in the Google form. Then you do the same as before, linking it to the course description. Still not like the site policy but a workaround. Perhaps you would like to repost in the Using Moodle forums or maybe Helen can move this to there for other suggestions?

Post title: Will the US government break Google's monopoly?
Post description: Now Google is digesting a double thrust, Google Just Lost a Big Antitrust Trial. But Now It Has To Face Yet Another.One , what do you think, will the US government break Google's monopoly? And Will the Google Antitrust Ruling Change the Internet? As a Moodler I am also curious to know the future of Moodle Global search , assuming that it is powered by Google.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: A related discussion just ran in the installation forum. See [4.4.2] PDF conversion not working .
Comment 2: In those discussions I got the feeling that people don't know that Google is breaking the law, still believing that it operates in a gray zone. The list of court cases where Google lost is very long. The OP lists two recent ones. Here is a longer article on the first one: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/google-loses-antitrust-trial-in-major-blow-to-tech-giant-191745614.html and the epic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_v._Google_Inc. . Talking of monopoly practices, trending... https://news.slashdot.org/story/24/09/08/066219/british-competition-regulator-says-googles-ad-practices-harmed-competition .
Comment 3: War of dinosaucers! https://www.cnbc.com/2024/10/08/doj-indicates-its-considering-google-breakup-following-monopoly-ruling.html (found in https://yro.slashdot.org/story/24/10/09/0339229/doj-indicates-its-considering-google-breakup-following-monopoly-ruling ) Also on BBC https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c62504lv00do
Comment 4: The machines of justice are rolling, very, very slowly. US Regulators Seek To Break Up Google, Forcing Chrome Sale https://yro.slashdot.org/story/24/11/21/0458216/us-regulators-seek-to-break-up-google-forcing-chrome-sale
Comment 5: There is a saying in Journalism that for any headline that ends in a question mark the answer will be no.
Comment 6: Yeah, that's a cheap trick. "Has the Moon exploded?" will get you lot of readers. But in our case there is this PDF and the BBC has too much experience not to be cheap: Sell Chrome to end search monopoly, Google told .
Comment 7: Selling Chrome may be a radical strategy, but it's unlikely to solve Google's core problem: their dominance of the search market.
Comment 8: Looks like Google has found an easy solution: Linux Foundation Announces Initiative to Support Chromium Ecosystem .
Comment 9: Firefox could be doomed without Google search deal, says executive https://www.theverge.com/news/660548/firefox-google-search-revenue-share-doj-antitrust-remedies What an irony! (found in https://news.slashdot.org/story/25/05/04/0754238/firefox-could-be-doomed-without-google-search-deal-executive-says )
Comment 10: It will not:! See Reflecting on my reaction to U.S. policies . Solution: No big-bang solutions but every step counts. For example, Come and Join Mastodon .
Comment 11: And it hadn't: Google avoids break-up but must share data with rivals https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cp8zdrenm1zo or, if you like the Lunduke's geeky style: Google Dodges All Remedies in Search Engine Monopoly Case https://rumble.com/v6yfiiy-google-dodges-all-remedies-in-search-engine-monopoly-case.html?e9s=src_v1_ucp_a

Forum Post: 
Post title: Unique way to help Hurricane Katrina victims
Post description: I wanted to come up with a way to personally reach out and touch the victims of Hurricane Katrina.  My solution:  get as many people as possible to write personal but anonymous letters of encouragement and support to give to those in shelters.  Many tens of thousands are housed within 200 miles of my home. The result: www.letterofhope.com .  The site has a pdf file containing everything you need to write a letter, send it to "Letter of Hope," and, hopefully get a personal reply from the storm victim who receives it.  I can produce a group package with an organization's name and city on the letterhead. Within 3 days of operation, I have received commitments for over 2,000 letters from individuals, companies, churches, and schools.  I have also received commitments from social and religious organizations to deliver letters that will cover over 38,000 evacuees. I need the MOODLE community's help.  Please consider writing a "Letter of Hope."  If you represent a business, school, church, social club or other organization, go to "How Can I Help!" on the main menu to see how to request a customized group package.  Also, please email everyone you know and tell them about this project.  "Word of email" is the best and most effective way for me to get the word out. MOODLErs in outside the US can participate!  I have a physician in London who is organizing a letter writing campaign! Thank you for anything that you can do to assist these people who have lost so much. Please feel free to contact me either by replying to this post, or by email:  help@letterofhope.com.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can we have a "My Forum" , "Favorites Forum" or Personal Forum?
Post description: What I mean is that frequently we come across that Forum posting that just solves the problem that has kept you up for two nights -- like how to activate the main menu in a new 1.5 installation, or just something you think you would like to keep and read later -- and so I think it would be great if I could just click on a save button. The save button would bring me to a page where I could create a new category or save it in an old category. Let's say I'm mainly interested in two forums or just a couple of threads, I could re-create those and save it in the appropriate one. The Forums are awfully big and having some way to "edit" them individually seems like a good idea. Having the messages come to you as e-mails (in order to save them) is possible but a little overwhelming -- I've tried it. Also, we can make these personal forums public, so that if I know someone is interested in flash, for example, and I haven't been following the forums for awhile, I might check to see what he has collected. Perhaps we could also great smaller, more intimate groups. Got the idea from photo sites that let you create your own album. You spend a lot of time looking for the right picture but you are not ready to buy, so you save the picture (just the link obviously) in your own album for future reference. An idea?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The pragmatist in me suggests that your browser bookmarks/favourites are probably the best way to achieve this for your own use. Simply bookmark the forum, discussion or post with a brief note about why you think it's important and you should be able to retrieve it later with no trouble at all (the better your browser the easier this will be). The techn-utopian in me thinks that some folksonomic categorisation / shared bookmarks tagging system built into the Moodle forums would be ideal for this kind of task. However most Moodle sites are not as public or as well trafficed as Moodle.org so the benefit of adding this functionality would probably be limited for most Moodle users. However, combining these thoughts, and remembering that Moodle.org is available on the open web, I'm wondering how succesful it would be to link to various specific posts via del.icio.us, furl or some other social bookmarking tool that allows tagging of URLs (which is what basically everything in Moodle.org is when you get right down to it). The new Technorati redisign lists lots of stuff for the tag:moodle including moodle photos from Flickr and moodle links from furl , and from delicous So hooking up with some external service and allowing people to use that system to categorise, rate and link the contents of Moodle.org would seem to be a way forward.
Comment 2: Thanks for the reply and for the new words that I have learned. Achieving this for my use, as you understood, was not really the point. I was thinking of the benefits of having a large group of people organizing the information on the forums in different or individual ways. On this photo site I really like seeing how others have thought of using the same photos, or when you find someone that likes the same things you do, you check in to see what they have added recently. Wouldn't it be fairly easy to add a "save" button and then a choice as to where to save? What might be difficult is what to do next. These "groupings" shouldn't be administered and they would have to kept separate from the established groups. How would they be organized, listed, and made available to everyone? The question is if something interesting could develop for all Moodle users.
Comment 3: I maked someone a moderator so he could change things too^^ but... he did'nt saw under on my forum ''administration panel'' so how change that?? ---------------------------------- vijendra jain ---------------------------------- Online Dating

Forum Post: 
Post title: Data integration
Post description: I recently listened to a presentation on 'analytics' for student retention and predicting success. One of the arguments was that LMSs are extremely bad in yielding usable data for these purposes, Moodle was singled out as the worst in terms of providing reasonably clean data that can be used for such purposes. Is this true? Is the Moodle community doing anything about this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well it probably depends on what you take "providing reasonably clean data that can be used for such purposes" to mean. It is still far too early in the learning analytics technology (hype?) cycle for there to be any published standards for how LMSs should expose data. In about 5 years time (if learning analytics takes off) then there will be such a thing and the question will be easy to answer. Until then, we are stuck with ad-hoc solutions. At the lowest level, Moodle tracks excellent, high-quality data about what users are doing in the database . That is mainly in the mdl_log table, but the gradebook and activity and course completion tables are also excellent sources of data. The Moodle database is not very complex, and if you are a developer, it is really quite easy to pull the required data out. And Moodle now has many hooks (web-services, course and admin reports) where you can expose that data in whatever form you want. You can also just let your learning analytics program pull data directly from (a mirror of) the Moodle DB. At this early stage in the learning anlytics came, that is probably as good as you are going to get.

Post title: Free 2GB "moodler.com" Email Accounts for moodlers
Post description: Hi Everyone, In the spirit of giving back to the moodle community, I would like to share free moodler.com email accounts as a unique and fun way for us to show our moodler spirit. These 2GB email accounts are powered by Google. I had signed up with Google for their offering of hosted email for domains and now am able to offer a limited number of accounts to any moodler that may be interested. The email interface is very similar to Google's regular GMail web pages and has GMAIL features like Chat and searching. You can also access your moodler.com email through email clients like Outlook. Your email address would be chosen_name@moodler.com . There is no commercial intent, by me, with this offering. Like GMail, Google does place some text ads on the web interface of your email web pages. I do not receive any revenue whatsoever even if you happen to click any of the Google text ads. This is how Google is able to offer this free service to domains. I hope that this can be a fun tool for those that sign up. I currently have a limited amount of available slots, as determined by Google, so please limit your requests to one account. To sign up, please go to: http://moodler.com . Thanks. Rich

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle research... Studies that document benefits?
Post description: Hello, all. I am a masters student, and I am doing research for a presentation on Moodle. I wondered whether anyone could direct me to studies that have been done regarding the benefits of using Moodle (ie., increased parental awareness and involvement, improved test scores, etc.). Thanks, Marcia
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My post-bacc students are required to do a literature search and regularly produce an appropriate bibliography..... Though I wouldn't put much store in most of it. I find google scholars to be a tool I often recommend during discussions of how to do a "21st century" lit search, as well as advanced search features on google and other indexing engines. A portal like ebsco connection can be handy and you should check with your institutions library about such resources.
Comment 2: Since you use the words parental involvement and test scores I assume you are talking k12 (primary-secondary school). I don't know whether you are coming at Moodle from an IT or pedagogical point of view, but if pedagogy is your angle you might take a look at the research both on "knowledge building" and "21 Century learning." Some names in Knowledge Building are Scardemalia, M., Bereiter, C., Zhang, J. These tend to use a program called "knowledge forum" rather than moodle, but their conclusions about collaborative learning, student to student (vs. student to teacher) communication, and treating knowledge as something that can be stored outside ourselves and collectively advanced is compelling.

Post title: Pennsylvania Workshop Interest
Post description: While looking for training options for myself, I notice that there weren't many, if any workshops on the East Coast. I have asked my administrators if we could host some here. I have been talking with a Moodle Partner about coming to our school (public High School) to offer Moodle workshops for teachers/administrators. I am collecting data to determine if there is interest.  The teacher training would be 2 days and would cost about $300-$400.  The adminstration training would be 1 day and would cost about the same.  We do not have any timeframe in mind, presently.  We are gathering data to determine the feasiblity of this project. If you would be interested, please email me and let me know if you are interested in the Teacher or Administration training and if you prefer during the school year or the summer. cathy.dipiano@dallastown.net Thank you! Cathy
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think we would want to get involved at some point with the traing. I sent an email to you. Thanks
Comment 2: If the taining is $300-$400 for each participant, you may want to shop around. A big price tag doesn't always equate to superior quality. Steve
Comment 3: Do you know of cheaper companies, because I've looked around and can't really find anything cheaper.  This Moodle Partner, I've been talking to has worked with a friend of mine at a private school, so I know they are good. I had offers from individuals, but they have about the same knowledge level as I do - I'm looking to grow and learn more.  I figured a Moodle Partner would be a good solution. If you have any suggestions, please let me know.
Comment 4: It is always best to work with a Moodle partner, along with guaranteeing a high standard of Moodle knowledge, the partners also provide the funding to keep Moodle development going, by contributing back to Martin D. to support his team at Moodle headquarters. This support is required for Moodle to continue to develop, so even if partner's cost a bit more than others, it is worth it in the long run.
Comment 5: No suggestions...just an "Unbiased" opinion. I do a lot of professional development in public schools and not many that I work with could afford that price tag and still do all the other PD's they need to do throughout the year. Quite frankly, it's no more difficult to teach 30 students than it is to teach 10 or 15 students. 30 students at $400 each is $12,000...seems a little extreme to me...just my opinion. I'm just assuming you are not going to get many takers at that price...I could be wrong. Good luck. Steve

from these pupils. The rationale for not doing this with KS4 is that they are taking the
Applied GCSE course, so their evidence still needs to printed, fairly
obvious... Anyway, e-portfolio through Moodle or other online CMS or V/MLE for me has several advantages: 1.  Reduction in printing costs 2.  A reduction in working time for teacher when marking.  I'm much more efficient working onscreen than with bundles of paper. 3.  Integration with other methods of communication.  Our kids now
communicate via text, chat room and message board as much as they do in
any other fashion.  It makes sense for work (not just ICT work) to be
submitted and edited in the same fashion. 4.  Ease of storage and retrieval for the student.  Granted there are
limitations in terms of learning where file and folder structure is
concerned to a degree if the students work mainly through the Journal
(now assignment in 1.5) system as my pupils do, but it saves valuable
time for less able students when the teacher knows exactly where to find the previous lesson 's work for continuation. 5.  As above, ease of access to work in progress for the teacher. 6.  Access to work and lesson content from home. 7.  Easy moderation for the department, without the need for face-to-face meeting time.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you seen the e-portfolio discussion in the developers forum? Someone appears to be working on a moodle mod
Comment 2: I am accepting work/presentations for 21st Century Science from the students by using Moodle.. www.21stcenturyscience.org.uk/support/ One bonus is additional security...how many times have students 'lost' their work?  Here we have a facility for another copy of their work online...and an ability to download a copy for teachers storage, offline. 24/7 access to their work is a real advantage when trying to develop and extend school/home links. I tend to download all the submissions for a certain assignment and make a copy onto a CD.  Not sure whether OCR , or other exam boards have the facility to accept coursework in this format yet...
Comment 3: Last year I set up a moodle course for OCR ICT GCSE that led pupils through their coursework by setting assignments, with deadlines.  OK, it wasn't perfect and was still a "work in progress" when I moved on from the school (who promptly closed down the web presence anyway when I left - duh) but the intention was to be able to produce a progression through the coursework, with evidence, that could then be used for moderation.  There was still work to do on aligning the mark scheme fully, and on the pupils producing their final reports but the facility to provide feedback via the markbook and through other means was invaluable in getting pupils to revisit work and amend it.  The pupils appreciated it too - as with everything we did with moodle, I was always pleasantly surprised to see how positively learners responded if they were given the chance to do so, and it appeared that a few words in their markbook had more impact than actually speaking to them in class (and it's so much more efficient to look at their work the night before and comment on it so that they can start work next lesson straight away - think of the example of a waste of productive time in class where they sit with their hand up for 10 mins while I work my way around solving individual problems). As David states, the advantages of Moodle are obvious and my favourites are: files are backed up off-site as well as on-site; files are available anywhere, anytime (to coin a phrase); progression through the work is obvious and is backed up by entries in the journal and in other places such as dialogue, chat, forum discussions; a Dialogue module allows pupils to ask for specific help; moderators can be given a teacher password to access the course thus saving time, postage etc. OCR seemed quite interested in moderating in this way and I gave them access to the site, even though it was still only a "work in progress" (I'd resurrected it from a backup - the school had killed the site, remember?).  One moderator absolutely loved the principle and could see how its value if it had been completed, while another liked it but failed to grasp the potential of what was essentially an incomplete offering. Used in the right way, and bearing in mind that the moderator is unlikely to be familiar with the system and has associated needs that should be accommodated through a set of instructions or an appropriately-constructed course, my experience is that it is entirely possible to use Moodle to complete and submit coursework. <musing>Surely  it is only a small step to create  e-portfolios after this?  Could it be made possible for the pupil to search the database for all the work they've ever done on the site and back it up to a zipfile or whatever?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Response to "Research on Ecstasy Clouded by Errors" by Belladonna Dioszegi
Post description: Response by Belladonna Dioszegi on "Research on Ecstasy is Clouded by Errors" by Donald G. McNeil Jr. New York Times writer Donald G. McNeil responds to Dr. Ricaurte 's scientific studies on Ecstasy. According to Mr. McNeil's sources, these studies were highly inadequate and inaccurate, where a particular study was even retracted due to a mix up in labels. Many of Dr Ricaurte's mentors, fellow scientists, and examinees are quoted throughout the article, all admitting Dr. Ricaurte's methods and results to be not quite up to par. From postcards showing holes in brains of excessive users to claiming Ecstasy causes the tremors of Parkinsonism, Dr. Ricaurte is proven wrong on every front. The very first paragraph draws the readers in by identifying a well known, costly study preformed on primates to be completely invalid, stating the labels on methamphetamines and Ecstasy were mixed up. “What a comical mistake”, I thought, and continued reading. Mr. McNeil backs up his first statement by proceeding to give examples of other work the Dr. has published and the comments of other professionals and scientists familiar with Ricaurte. All of which either make claims against the Dr.'s results or his sloppy methods. It would seem that everything Dr. Ricaurte has done or said is in some way comical and hard to take seriously. The article concludes with a study on two male patients who took a large amount of Ecstasy, among other drugs. The patients stated they were jet lagged and sedated as the tests were preformed, and that it was a biased exam that seemed bent on proving they had some sort of brain damage. Despite the 4 years of heavy drug use, one man is a graduate in Chemistry at “a leading university”, and the other works at a law firm and “is in line for a federal job”. With not a single sense of praise or credibility included, I am left to wonder how a man supposedly so incompetent could be taken seriously; or is this portrayal of Dr. Ricaurte unfair and more belittling than he deserves? Based on my own lack of knowledge on Dr. Ricaurte, and Mr. McNeil's known credibility, I am immediately enticed to take McNeil's word for it, at first. Then the five pages of Dr. Ricaurte's petty claims and quotes of others down talking him, it starts to feel like just a negative buildup against Dr. Ricaurte, and becomes hard to take seriously. For the man to be a ranking scientist, how can all of his methods be less than desirable? Mr. McNeil makes no effort to a counterargument, giving Dr. Ricaurte no saving grace. The information provided seems accurate, but I would have preferred it to include some positive aspects in the Dr.'s research, so I could better form my own opinion on him. Despite the one-sided opinions portrayed, the article is well written and an intriguing read. I particularly found the short paragraph explaining the medical use of Ecstasy to be interesting. It was often used to help patients with trauma or anxiety talk about the event or their upsetting experience with ease, without the sleep inducing effects a sedative would create. In 1985, when Ecstasy was outlawed, this productive use for the drug ceased to be practiced for fear of prosecution.

Forum Post: 
Post title: EdTech producing refuse?
Post description: For whatever its worth: Over 4 million Gen Zers are jobless—and experts blame colleges for ‘worthless degrees’ and a system of broken promises for the rising number NEETs https://fortune.com/2025/03/25/gen-z-neet-not-in-education-employment-training-higher-ed-worthless-degrees-college/ (found in https://news.slashdot.org/story/25/03/26/211250/over-4-million-gen-zers-are-jobless ) I don't know how long the marketing battalions can beat the drum.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am curious as to which degrees are "worthless" and on what metric. Visvanath, you post some very good conversation starters.
Comment 2: Oh, thanks for the compliment! "Conversation starters". That is what they are. Not that I don't have my own thoughts on these. But I don't want to bathe everybody in my thoughts. What are your and others' thoughts?
Comment 3: NEETs (Not in Education, Employment, or Training) should consider moving to countries where job opportunities are abundant. Many nations are experiencing labor shortages and actively seeking foreign workers. Given the current global employment landscape, NEETs may find job opportunities in the following countries: Canada - Seeking workers in healthcare, IT, and skilled trades. Germany - High demand for engineers, healthcare professionals, and IT specialists. Australia - Job shortages in construction, healthcare, and agriculture. Japan - Labor demand in construction, hospitality, and agriculture. New Zealand - Skilled worker visas available in healthcare and engineering. Spain - Increasing employment opportunities for foreigners. United Kingdom - High demand for healthcare, engineering, and IT professionals. And many more opportunities exist: gooverseas.com playroll.com visasupdate.com apnews.com insidermonkey.com etc.
Comment 4: I emigrated to Canada. I met a number of other immigrants there with professional qualifications and experience. None of them were working in their profession. One, a vet, out of desperation, started to restudy his profession, from scratch, in Canada or order to restart his career there. Higher education in Canada is expensive but that was the only way he could find to do it and that'll leave him saddled with a huge debt by the time he graduates. So many of the immigrants I met couldn't afford to re-study what they already knew. I met an engineer who was driving for Uber. I met a dental hygienist who was unemployed. I met a lighting engineer/designer who couldn't find work.My aunt emigrated to Canada many years ago too. She was a highly qualified and experienced paediatric theatre nurse with the UK's NHS (think near surgeon-level training). She had to re-study too. Additionally, in the 2010s,
Canada had a 7-year backlog of applications for work visas, i.e.
emigrating to Canada for a guaranteed professional job. They decided
that after 7 years, most applicants' circumstances had probably changed
so much that the applications we no longer valid... so they cancelled
them and made everyone re-apply. There's a joke in Toronto that your taxi driver is probably more highly qualified than you. What a waste of talent and maybe that's why so many countries have skilled labour shortages despite having high levels of immigration? Finally, when the COVID-19 confinement hit in 2020 and students had to stay at home, you'd think educational institutions would need more elearning and Online & Distance Education (ODE) specialists, right? No. They started firing those people instead so that inexperienced tutors and lecturers had to perform the rapid "pivot" to online. We now have hundreds of "experts" in ODE who think it's simply uploading reading materials and giving video tutorials on Zoom. I no longer live in Canada. /end of rant
Comment 5: During the brexit debates of the mid teens in the UK it amused me that those in favour were keen on an "Australian points based system", as my Australian citizenship came at the end of that process.. It was an imprecise and blunt instrument. Anyone who has had a few jobs would know that you rarely end up doing the job as described in the job advert.
Comment 6: Sounds like a "slow news" story, i.e. when journalists are told to think up attention grabbing ideas for articles to keep the ad revenue coming in. Did they look into what those so called NEETs are actually doing? Are they actually working in the gig economy, i.e. "off the books"? There's nothing new about graduates and professionals doing unskilled labour because the economy is doing badly.
Comment 7: Claim: You can Google "the most useless degrees", and you'll find that the list is long. If you search for "the most useful degrees", engineering will likely be at the top, followed by medicine and business administration. Our technological world needs people who can calculate the length of a hypotenuse. However, young people don’t want to do math—most of them don’t even know what a hypotenuse is. If you show an integral sign to a student, they might faint. Business administration students don’t know the slope of a line on a graph, let alone students in other fields. Sorry, but the world needs more engineers—not so many art historians and language experts. Counterclaim: While it is true that STEM degrees, particularly engineering and medicine, are often ranked among the most "useful" in terms of job prospects, dismissing other fields as "worthless" is an oversimplification. The economy is not solely driven by engineers and doctors—society also needs educators, communicators, analysts, and creative professionals. Moreover, the issue of youth unemployment is more complex than simply blaming degree choices. Factors such as labor market conditions, automation, economic downturns, and even the rising costs of education contribute significantly. Many STEM graduates also struggle to find jobs if they lack experience or if demand fluctuates in their field. Rather than discouraging students from pursuing their interests, a better approach would be to reform education systems to better align with job market needs. This includes improving career guidance, integrating practical skills into all degree programs, and promoting interdisciplinary knowledge—because even engineers benefit from good communication skills, and businesses need people who understand human culture, language, and behavior. I understand where you're coming from—there is certainly a strong demand for engineers, doctors, and other STEM professionals, and many students struggle with math, which can limit their career options. However, I think the issue is more nuanced. The job market does favor certain degrees over others, but rather than saying some fields are "worthless," it might be more accurate to say that universities need to do a better job of preparing students for the realities of employment. For example, even in the humanities, students could benefit from more practical skills like data analysis, project management, or digital tools to increase their employability. That being said, I do agree that too many students avoid math-heavy fields, and that’s a problem. But perhaps the solution isn’t just to push everyone into STEM but to make math and logical thinking more approachable from an early age.
Comment 8: "That being said, I do agree that too many students avoid math-heavy fields, and that’s a problem." Students can be helped study maths by using good tools for practicing, one example that springs to mind is the Moodle STACK question type, which I will be presenting next Tuesday April 1st for the Moodle Academy , read more here https://moodle.academy/calendar/view.php?view=day&course=1&time=1743494400#event_26872 End of shameless plug.
Comment 9: As an older gentleman, what strikes me is the number of students now earning degrees. Educated in rural New Zealand, half my classmates would have left before 3 years of secondary education. Only half those that sat the external exam at the end of the third year passed and that was considered enough to get a job in an office, bank or insurance. Undoubtedly they were immature and lacking skills at 16 but many have been very successful in their careers. Those jobs now require a degree and tens of thousands in student debt. Less than 10% of those entering the school with me went on to University. The problem isn't just a Western one. I spend several years teaching in a Chinese polytech where I was told to pass every single student - even those who never turned up. The students were at the lower end academically in a system that ranks both students and educational establishments and the 3 year diploma they received had little value. Some were shoved into an English class, and there seemed to be no way students with little ability or interest in learning a foreign language could change to a course that better suited them.

Post title: Recommendation letter for my work
Post description: Hi everyone, I have been contributing to open source projects for quite a while now. I have a plugin I developed ~5 years ago and is still in use by over 200 sites. ( https://moodle.org/plugins/block_export_quiz ) Since I have no way of contacting the actual users of the plugin, would folks in the community be open to write me a recommendation letter stating the importance of the work that I did for the community and the impact it might have had? I can connect with you regarding more details if you are willing to write a recommendation letter. Also please let me know if there is a way I can see who is actually using it and if there is a way to contact them as well. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello, Ashish! 😊 To obtain those recommendation letters you need, you can create an informational banner that highlights the importance of your plugin and requests recommendation letters. This way, only the administrators of the sites using your plugin will be able to see it. Eduardo Kraus Teacher and programmer
Comment 2: Hi Eduardo, Thank you for the suggestion. I have some concerns about the turnaround time for deploying another version and the number of admins who might actually see the banner and take initiative. Do you know if you or any other Moodlers—who can speak to the importance and impact of my work based on the stats—might be willing to write me a recommendation letter?
Comment 3: Hello Ashish. Perhaps you might like to update your block for the latest version of Moodle, which is 4.5, and LTS version, and then you might get some more comments in the plugins directory which might be helpful for your recommendation?
Comment 4: Hello, Ashish! I’ve been in a similar situation a few times while working on my themes and plugins, such as Boost Magnific and Magnific . From my experience, the feedback I receive via email and Moodle chat has been incredible! 📨 Many ideas and improvements for the SuperVideo plugin came directly from users through issues they opened. I always try to respond quickly, which encourages more people to collaborate and provide feedback, further enriching the project! 💡 Eduardo Kraus Teacher and programmer
Comment 5: You could put something on your Git repo readme asking for various forms of feedback. Perhaps solicit comments on Linkedin.
Comment 6: When we hire somebody, the *first* thing I do is to go and find their Github repo. That can be quite revealing. If you do good work and it's all in there (including how you react to Issues) then clearly point to it on your application. It makes a big difference. In your case, you may want to think about what "Updated 5 years ago" says about you. Really the same thing that Mary said, above. I know I'm being blunt but you asked...

Post title: Use of computers in class: non-users beat poorly organised users

"The students who sporadically used computers — bringing them irregularly or not actively participating in computer-facilitated classroom activities when using them —were outperformed by all others, including those who never brought a computer to class,” said CSU physics professor Zdeslav Hrepic . . ." Hmm.  In the study the consistent computer/software users in the end performed about a grade better thn computer non-users.

Post title: Bug found when creating forums
Post description: When creating a forum, if I choose the type of forum as "A single simple discussion", and save the forum, I get and error saying "Unable to get course module instance". But if I select "Standard forum for general use", save the forum and then change the type to "A simple discussion" it works fine.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This is not a good place to report bugs - it is very unlikely that a developer will see it. The correct thing to do is: If possible, try the latest version of Moodle, and make sure that the problem has not already been fixed. (This may not be possible for you, in which case don't worry.) If not, search in the Moodle bug tracker ( http://tracker.moodle.org/ ) to see if anyone has already reported the problem. If so, then stop. (Or, if you have useful extra information to add, you could add it to the existing bug report.) If the problem has not already been reported, create a new bug report. If possible include: The exact version of Moodle you are using. Exactly what sequence of actions you did to trigger the bug (Steps to reproduce), What actually happened, and what you expected to happen. Actually, your description above, although brief, is a pretty good bug report. Just missing the version information. For more information about the Moodle bug tracker, see Tracker . Thank you for taking the time to report the problem you encountered.

Forum Post: 
Post title: New Curriculum Mapping Block in development
Post description: Greetings, The purpose of this post is to inform the Moodle community that we are close to completing a new Moodle block that is designed to facilitate the design of competency based curricula. This work has been funded through a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation grant and is about two years in the making. The tools will support several functions: * Design of curriculums maps relating Competencies (a.k.a. educational goals), Professional Abilities (a.k.a. learning objectives), Learning Activities , and Assessments. * Submission of learning activities (a.k.a. lesson plans) by educators with associated searchable metadata . * Review of submitted materials by an editorial team, with support for revision cycles. * Searching and browsing of curriculum maps and their related learning object repositories. * Rating of learning objects by editorial staff and/or public browsers via a star rating system. * Checking out materials from the learning object repositories via a shopping cart model. * Packaging of selected curricula items, with a dynamically created curriculum description including links to learning activities and assessments. * Tracking of downloads and follow up surveying of users.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, This is a very impressive initiative. I especially like the goal-oriented, curriculum-based framework you are attempting. That is good for my institution needs, but individuals with spontaneous, flexible learning styles may not be as excited. At Sapporo Gakuin University we released the Sharing Cart last week and soon the internal Repository (in April). In addition, six months ago, the Project Course Format was released for teachers developed project-based content (sharing packages of mixed types of resources/activities). All of these may be of interest to you and your project. They are intended to meet the need for sharing Moodle-based activities and resources. The Moodle 2.0 Repository API however seems to be aimed at connecting external banks of activities, not necessarily Moodle based. The beauty of the Sharing Cart is its ability to act as a window to transfer Moodle items between sites. What we miss is the connection to competancies, so I am eager to study your plans. Do you have some links to proposals, requirements papers, screenshots? Will you be offering this Curriculum Mapping Block as GPL? Since others may be interested, you might post some of these links onto the Moodle Docs , too. Thanks, Don
Comment 2: We do plan to release the Curriculum Mapping Block as GPL. We are applying a new CSS to our demonstration site at the moment. Once that is completed I will post a link here so that anybody can try out the public view. Thanks for the links to the tools you have developed. We'll take a look and see if there might be some linkages. Our tool is designed to support curriculum designers, regardless of what LMS is used to deliver courses. When designing a curriculum map, you can upload any type of document as a learning object, or point to the URL of a learning resource that resides anywhere. So while there will be some advantages if an institution already uses Moodle, the tool will provide the bulk of its functionality with any other LMS in place as well. John Jackson
Comment 3: Do you know when this Block will be released? We have a lot of interest in our region on this. Any assistance would be appreciated. Ray Miller
Comment 4: This plugin/extension sounds like exactly what we need. Has it been released yet? What's the current status?
Comment 5: Since we are now a year later, I would suspect that this block is now available. But I didn't find it on the Moodle plugins page. Can you tell me what the status is, or where I could find it?
Comment 6: Gert: I think John is no longer 'enrolled' in this forum and may not receive this. But this link may be helpful to follow up on this. http://www.medicine.virginia.edu/education/medical-students/ome/edtech/edtechstaff-page I did find this link as well: http://www.editlib.org/view/32702 but the whole article is passworded.

Forum Post: 
Post title: More questions about Blackboard patent
Post description: I guess I seem to keep bringing this up, but I have to work with Blackboard, so I get to read their communications every week.  It's starting to resemble what I imagine a plastered and stoned lawyer would sound like.  Anyway, now they have a FAQ up: http://www.blackboard.com/patent/FAQ2 This part doesn't sit right with me: "For example, claim 1 in the Blackboard patent describes a course based-system
with user computers where each user is “capable of having predefined
characteristics indicative of multiple predetermined roles in the system.” 
Consequently, a system must provide for “multiple predetermined roles” for each
user according to the claim and, likewise, every other element (or its
equivalent) of claim 1 must be embodied in the system in question for claim 1 to
be infringed.  This detailed element-by-element analysis is necessary to
evaluate the scope of the patent. Be wary of any analysis of this or any other
patent which does not involve an element-by-element discussion of the claims as
each element is a limitation on the scope of a patent. " So, in order for someone to infringe on this patent, they have to meet the 34 elements (if I read correctly) that are dependent on claim 1 to be in violation?  So, Blackboard wrote a patent that someone amazingly fits their top competitors?  Seems a little scarey to me. Or how about this: "The inherent complexity of patent law is no doubt a leading cause of confusion
about the Blackboard patent. "
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: "The inherent complexity of patent law is no doubt a leading cause of confusion about the Blackboard patent." As was observed on one of the blogs recently, under most patent systems (including those of the United States and the European Union), a valid patent requires that the invention be sufficiently disclosed that a person with "ordinary skill in the art" can understand and reproduce the invention. Now Blackboard appears to be arguing that a very large number of experts in the ed tech field have "misunderstood" its patent. That would seem to be a de facto admission that the patent is unenforceable.
Comment 2: No, I think you may have misunderstood - but the wording on FAQ2 is a bit obscure so I don't blame you.... The bit you quoted says that every element of a CLAIM must be included in order for the CLAIM to be violated. It doesn't say that every CLAIM of a PATENT must be included in order for the PATENT to be violated! So the whole paragraph of Claim 1 must be considered, rather than (for example) part A or part B.
Comment 3: Hmm.... okay.  I see.  But part B (in the link you provided) is not that clear either.  It seems to me, that if someone violates part A, part B is just kind of the no-duh part, technical detail part.  If you deliver online classes, then of course you use a server , over a network, etc. Great link, btw .  I need to spend more time on that site. So, it seems like reading what Blackboard said, and what you have said and linked to, Blackboard still has the ability to twist words and sue anyone they want, at least on this claim.  Even though they say they can't.  Sounds suspicious to me...
Comment 4: Okay - I think I see this clearer now.  Basically, Claims 1 and 36 are the main claims, with claims 2-35 beign supportive of/dependent on Claim 1 in some way, and claims 37-44 being the same for 36. " The other claims are dependent claims because
they depend on either claim 1 or claim 36. They cannot be infringed if
claim 1 and 36 are not infringed" So, I am reading through all of these claims.  Here is my element-by-element discussion of the claims: Blackboard has patented the modern concept of a learning management system, claiming that they are the historical root of the ideas that led it to where it is today.  Almost any LMS today could be fit into this patent, even with a fairly incompetent lawyer. " Be wary of any analysis of this or any other
patent which does not involve an element-by-element discussion of the
claims as each element is a limitation on the scope of a patent." Ummm.... Hello?  noedupatents.org?  There is your element-by-element discussion of the claims and - surprise! - it comes to the same conclusions as the rest of us "uneducated simpletons" came to when we first read about this patent! Is anyone else getting tired of hearing Michael Chasen use the word "embarassed"?  Could he please use a more sincere word?
Comment 5: I am not sure about the appropriateness of my posting here.  However I will be happy to draw your attention to the recent interview by Richard Stallman on the sidelines of the 4th International GPLv3 Conference held at Bangalore. http://www.hindu.com/seta/2006/08/31/stories/2006083100441500.htm Nagarajan

Post title: Remuneration
Post description: Hi All, I am new to Moodle and need to employ an administrator to run the program and the teachers. Is this the correct place to get a "feel" for what I should be paying? If not, I apologise upfront, otherwise Id love to get some advice.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There's a massive variation in pay from what I've seen. It depends on exactly what skills you require. It will also depend on local supply and demand wherever you happen to be.
Comment 2: Thank you, that makes sense.
Comment 3: Joseph, Moodle can be deployed in different ways. If you are going to set it up on your own server , I think you need a systems admin profile to look after the platform, updates, plugins, security, user accounts, enrolment processes, connections with other systems (email, student management system, etc.), and so on, and you need an EdTech teaching profile to look after and advise your teachers. There are many options. You would be best advised to contact a Moodle Partner in your region and get some local advice from them. See https://moodle.com/partners/

Post title: Is Moodle Right for Me?
Post description: I'm trying to put together a learning management system for the company I work for. What I need is a system where students can take self-directed courses, and then, based on the courses they have completed/passed, they can browse and apply for paid projects. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes you can Craig Moodle allows you to set up courses in any number of ways including self-directed, particularly with the lesson module or conditional activities to direct a student's path as/if needed. You can also set up enrolment keys to limit access to courses along with paypal or other plugins to enable payment for courses HTH Richard
Comment 2: What we're looking for is the ability to list projects on our site. In essence, the students would be working for us on a per-project basis. Forum Post: 
Post title: Uploading PDF files to a heading under the resource sectin
Post description: Has anyone come across a problem when trying to upload a PDF or word document using the update resource command on an existing resource. I can do it no problem on the home page, but the minute i try to do it under one of my page heading sections , it only gives me the option to upload mages or write text
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi there. Where exactly are you trying to display your pdf? If you mean "add a resource" then "link to a file or website" you just click on the pen/hand icon to edit it, then go to under the location box - upload your pdf into the files storage area there and then choose your pdf and it will replace whatever is already there. Were you wanting to add it somewhere else? That too is perfectly possible - I just need to know where you want to put it.
Comment 2: Hi Mary, thanks for your response, our webpage is http://www.steplearn.net/malpaschurchinfants/ , under the childrens zone resource page, i have an entry for Eco Schools under which i have posted some PDFs, but I didn't really want them showing there, I wanted viewers to be able to click on the Eco schools link, then open a new document allowing them to choose which files they view and or download Many thanks, hope this makes sense Sharan
Comment 3: Do you mean the webpage that says "Eco schools"? Simply upload the pdfs into your site files on the front page (site admin>front page>site files ) and then update your Eco schools webpage and type some text to link to the pdf -then select the text and click the chain icon at the top of the html (text) editor. When you get the browse box then browse the sitefiles for your pdf file and choose that. In target choose "new window" and you should get what you want. I hope that is what you meant
Comment 4: Hi, I'm following Mary around. Everything Mary says is correct, except, you want to consider "In target choose 'new window' and you should get what you want" a little more carefully. Setting each link to each pdf to open a new window may complicate saving and/or printing the pdf. Experiment with your first link. You may NOT want to open a window for each.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle vs. Blackboard
Post description: Hi, Does any one have an idea about the cost of using blackboard? Regards,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There are a wide range of prices depending upon the number of users. But as a rough ball park figure, perhaps, $30,000 to $50,000 per university per year AFAIK http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=3017&parent=13256 Tim
Comment 2: Thank you. We are having the first Open Source conference in Palestine in two weeks. I think the audience will be interested to know how much one can save!
Comment 3: For a small college with approximately 1000 students it could be as little as $10,000-$15,000 USD. The rate of change, however, is perhaps more interesting at about $2,500 USD per year.
Comment 4: You will require more computer hardware per student for a Blackboard installation. However this will probably not add much to your costs as hardware is relatively cheap.
Comment 5: You will require more computer hardware per student for a Blackboard installation. I'm on a Blackboard campus and support a lot of Blackboard users...I, and a few other use Moodle. I haven't experienced the need for additional hardware for either system. I'd be interested to learn what additional hardware is needed? Is it "user" hardware or " server /network" hardware? Steve
Comment 6: You need a notebook to make notes about the intended learning arrangement in BB, because it does not support that. The look-a-like Dokeos introduces now the concept of the learning-line to fill this BB-design gap.
Comment 7: I agree that BB's design is more like a CMS. It's very compartmeltalized and the organization is no where near as clear and seemless as Moodle...that is a good selling point and one that can be supported. But the person starting this thread was asking for informaiton about BB and Moodle to share with people at a conference and the statement was made that BB requires more hardware per student. That is the first time I have heard this and it doesn't mesh with my experience. I would hate for someone to use this as a "selling point" with no specifics for support.
Comment 8: I have heard from our sysadmin that Blackboard 7 would requires about 1.5x more powerful machine than our present one due to database structural changes. At present, Moodle 1.5 vs. BB 6 seem about comparable in load. At the higher end (20k users plus), where you are trying to cluster MS SQL /Win servers, hardware (&software license costs) starts to get much more expensive.

Forum Post: 
Post title: moodle forum allowing yahoo etc email?
Post description: This moodle forum does not allow Yahoo email addresses when registering. So I had to use my company email. I can see a reason for this, to avoid ' spam ', but because I subscribe to forum discussions my company email inbox is flooded with forum messages, which is a problem when I travel and check email on a mobile phone or other mobile device. For this reason I use my Yahoo email when subscribing to foirums and discussion groups - it lets me deal with direct work issues that require immediate attention on my company email, and look at discussions that are interesting but not urgent using the Yahoo email. Unfortunately the decision in this forum to not allow Yahoo addresses means I am stuck with a flooded email inbox or have to unsubscrbe (which I don't really want to do, but will have to). Wouldn't it be reasonable to allow Yahoo email addresses? I subscribe to a lot of specialised discussion groups and none disallow Yahoo addresses. Chris
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Although not a perfect solution, you can use a Gmail account here. Even better, you can buy your own domain and use that for emails and never have to deal with this sort of thing again. In fact, you're lucky because your name is currently available (chrisbore.com). It's not free like Yahoo, but it's not expensive, either. You can register a domain at GoDaddy for $7-8 with coupon and hosting can be found for as little as $5 a month (e.g. Dreamhost.com). HTH - Sol
Comment 2: Thank you. As it happens, my email address is also my name which is my domain (bores.com) so that does not get round the problem for me. But I have now made my gmail address the one I use here. I don't check that for forums usually but at least it will keep my own email inbox free. Chris ================ Chris Bore www.bores.com

Post title: Network manager / learning technologist
Post description: Whilst I'm looking after the strategic side of ICT at whole school (ie
prep and senior) level in my new job as head of Alton Convent Prep , there's no way that I have time
to do the fun, hands-on stuff anymore (except perhaps for a
webserver...), and so Senior + Prep schools are now looking for a network manager now to take care of the day to day management and maintenance stuff, and contribute
to some of the strategic decision making. Here's the blurb: Alton Convent
School is seeking to appoint a network manager,
to take responsibility for the day to day management and maintenance of the
school’s computer networks, to provide technical support to staff and pupils,
assist with hands-on training, and contribute to decisions on the development
of ICT within the school. Applicants must be committed to prioritizing the
needs of learning, teaching, administration and management over technological
aspects, and seeking the best possible return on investment. Some experience
with SIMS and/or Open Source applications and approaches would be additional
recommendations, as would recent experience of the education sector. For
candidates with vision and creativity this post offers considerable scope to
explore innovative ways of delivering cutting-edge provision for ICT. Now, this isn't a Moodle job per se , but when we start looking at setting up a VLE, I think I know which one we'll pick... That said, I'm sure there are folks around here who could do this, or might know someone who could. Anyhow, I've uploaded the details and would be happy to chat with anyone interested in applying. Salary is 'dependant on qualifications and experience' but we're thinking about £20K+. The school has c460 on roll, and around 70-80 computers at the moment. Alton is a (rather nice) market town in Hampshire, SE England.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Activity Idea - Badges attached to assessment performance
Post description: I wasn't sure where else to post this, but I was wondering if such a thing exists already and/or if anyone else would be interested in such a thing. I use a mix of Edmodo and Moodle in my classroom. Edmodo for the social aspect and Moodle for all my class content and progression. I am currently able to award badges in Edmodo manually, however, I think it would great if I could affix a badge to any Moodle assessment that receives a grade and it would automatically reward the badge onto their Moodle profile. For instance, I would set a Moodle Quiz to award BADGE A to the student if he/she received a 95% on the test. The badge would just be a 50x50 pixel image which would bounce over to the student's profile upon meeting that requirement. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Hyle, Interesting idea. I included an activity report page in the SWF Activity Module ( http://code.google.com/p/swf-activity-module/ ) that gives a graphic display of grades, time spent, number of attempts, along with feedback comments and thumbnails of any saved images (e.g. from Concept Map and Avatar Camera apps). It's designed to give a quick and easy way for learners to check how they've been doing on SWF activities , see where they're doing well and where they should spend more time. Setting up some kind of side block that generates reports on learners' quiz attempts and awards badges should be fairly simple and easy to do. Probably, the most time consuming part of it would be deciding on how you'd like it to look and behave.

Post title: Looking for LCMS solution
Post description: I have been researching the possibilities of CMS systems for almost two months now . I have tried Drupal , Jommla , Wordpress , Plone .... I have overlooked Moodle because it is a LMS systems and a bit huge for the purpose I want to use it. I need the following features : Multi - lingual support browser language detection cookie for user choice of language intelligent switching when switching language on page A , the system should switch to page B which is the translation , not to front page Premium content support connection to payment gateway ( paypal , Google Checkout ...) automatic role granting after payment ability to mark part of pages , or at least full pages , downloads , etc .. as premium only ( full courses would be also acceptable , but not ideal ) ability to show ads for non - paying users but not for paying users subscriptions support ( limited time access to a set of courses ) unlimited access support ( unlimited time access to a certain course ) Google Adsense , Analytics , Sitemaps support Code syntax highlight support. Does Moodle support these features ? If yes , could you please point me to some documentation ( the size of moodle really scares me)?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Greetings, Šimon! I cannot answer all your questions, but I can tell you that you can selectively disable many of the moodle features through the admin settings. For example, we have a moodle instance that we use for a moodle portfolio. Certainly, in a portfolio situation, you don't need many of the instructional features that are built into moodle--no quizzes, assignments, etc. So we just went into the admin settings and turned off what we didn't need. The capabilities are still there, so you can always go back in and turn them on again should you so desire. So don't let "complexity" weigh too heavily on your choice. I would think other factors far more important. atw

Forum Post: 
Post title: How do you make an information plan? Help wanted
Post description: Hi guys, have this problem, so I thought, I have over 1000 international Moodle pals and friends who could help and advise. Because you guys should have come along this problem already and probably solved it. Background: My department has to come up with an information plan for next year in which we: - Have a total budget for ICT investments. - Define all areas where there will be some projects and changes - Have all applications we currently use included - Have all business requirements of all our business departements covered - We have to say something about the technical architecture (infrastructure, desktops etc.) The goal is to have this plan signed off by Management team at start of the year and implement it during the year 2005. Questions: how did you guys take care of this? Do you have a plan like that in your organisation? Any examples and templates or helpfull links? Thanks in andvance! Runy
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I always ask: What are we supposed achieve with the ICT investments for the next year? If I cannot get that answer I usually try to find a new job as soon as possible. I get this every year and I roughly estimate what's needed to replace different tech stuff, user needs, how they have improved using ICT, and some amount of money for the not foreseen. In my opinion it is knowing your fellow workers and organization that matters and not what to fill out in a spreadsheet! A boss usually wants to know what are the consequences for a) a reduced budget b) a normal budget c) an increased budget

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle and iSAMS
Post description: Hi all, I work at an Independent school here in the UK and we use a system called iSAMS for our student and course administration. I have spent the past few months developing a system to synchronise all courses and course enrolments from this system to Moodle. I thought that people using iSAMS may well find it useful, but there is no real reason why it could not be adapted fairly easily for any other Student Management System which runs on a Microsoft SQL Server . It is a three part blog post, and you can read each one here: Part 1 - http://bit.ly/U4ACdo Part 2 - http://bit.ly/1rFbVDl Part 3 - http://bit.ly/14WUsgD Happy reading! Jon
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you looked at moodles web services? We use those to duplicate courses for the new academic year and enrol students on those courses. Previous years students still have access to old courses to refer back to. Quite a lot of work went into that, perhaps more than a school would want to take on but it works well for us as you can do a lot with web services, adding your own if you need to.
Comment 2: Hi Jez, II haven't looked at Moodle Web Services TBH aside from enabling the Mobile web service... iSAMS does offer an API for remote systems to access its data but it is a subscription basis which the school would have to buy into. I think that it uses XML to send the data out to other systems; but without a subscription to the API I cannot even look at the documentation to see if Moodle Web Services would be compatible! I will speak with iSAMS to see if I can access the documentation without paying up; as using the official APIs would seem a more robust long term route to take. The only downside in doing so for iSAMS schools is that they would have to license this access to be able to integrate with Moodle. My current solution allows basic integration at no additional cost. Thanks, Jon
Comment 3: OK... So I have got access to the iSAMS developer portal and their documentation and it appears as if their API will let me create a batch web service which can refresh its data at a set time frame and output its data to me as XML ... I guess then it should be possible to get those various XML files and have them processed by Moodle... Certainly this would save having to query the database directly; however I still feel that the direct to DB approach is going to have to be easier; although I am probably just highlighting where my skills lack in that statement more than anything else!

Forum Post: 
Post title: CK-ERP v.0.31.1 released with Moodle 2.2.2 connector
Post description: Hi, folks, I have posted a new release, v.0.31.1, of CK-ERP, at SourceForge.Net, http://sourceforge.net/projects/ck-erp . New features include, Support for My sql i, Support for Sqlite3 Portuguese, Korean, Japanese, Hindi, Indonesian, Vietnamese, Russian translation Updated Chinese, Spanish, French, German translation Relaxation of restriction on display language must be the same as installation language As far as I can determine, a Moodle+CK-ERP environment is most useful to teachers, school administrators and other educational professionals. While Moodle supports the front-end elearning process, CK-ERP provides facilities to manage backoffice routines of a school, eg, procurement of supplies and ledger bookkeeping. All these happen within the familiar Moodle environment. CK-ERP is an open source educational / accounting / MRP / ERP / CRM system that runs on top of multiple middlewares. It comprises 32 modules - Contact Management, Customer Relationship Management, Customer Self Service, Vendor Relationship Management, Material Requirement Planning, Warehouse, Inventory, Service, Accounting Ledger, Bank Reconciliation, Accounts Payable, Accounts Receivable, Purchase Order, Sales Order, Quotation, POS for Cashier, POS for Manager, Human Resources, Staff Self Service, Payroll, Administration, Internationalization, Access Control, Data Import, Teacher, Counsellor, Student, Applicant, Family, Registrar, Edu Administration and Volunteer Management. Please report error and suggestion to the discussion group / mailing list, CK-ERP-en(at)googlegroups.com or CK-ERP-zh_CN(at)googlegroups.com . General history and expected development is available at the discussion group's Archive. Demo and info site: http://ck-erp.org Download site: http://sourceforge.net/projects/ck-erp Cheers, Wu Chiu Kay, aka CK Wu, aka CK (CK is the preferred alias) Hong Kong

Peace - Anthony

Forum Post: 
Post title: GED and equivalency testing in the 3rd world
Post description: I just came back from two weeks in Belize. Mostly pleasure. But some business too. I spoke with the headmaster of a four room k-8 school deep in the rainforest, 180 miles from the coast. In Belize, students who want to finish high school have to travel to a boarding school. Because--for the most part--there are no local high schools. That headmaster wants to expand his constituency to adult education. Few Belizeians finish high school. And many now wish they had. But they want an accredited diploma of some sort. They aren't interested in education for its own sake. They want better jobs. Employers want certified credentials of some sort. And that's a problem. Because well-regarded programs with good curricula and teachers who interact with the students can cost as much as $2000 per student per year. And the Belizeians who need better education don't have that kind of money.

Post title: Research Interview
Post description: Hello All, I would like to interview someone (educator, instructional designer, developer...) that has used or developed an educational AI-assisted plugin for Moodle. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Pick me, pick me https://github.com/marcusgreen/moodle-qtype_aitext
Comment 2: Thank you Marcus, What AI tool(s) are/is or may be available in Moodle that will increase teacher engagement? What AI tools are or may be available in Moodle that will help increase student behavioral engagement? What AI tools are or may be available in Moodle that will help increase student cognitive engagement? What AI tools are or may be available in Moodle that will help increase student emotional engagement?
Comment 3: Angel - I am sure it would help Marcus and others who might respond if you can first tell us what your own research has already found - doubtless you have done that in advance of posting here.
Comment 4: Thanks! 1. AI educational content creator tool 2.  AI drop-out detection or log in recording,  tool 3. AI expert tool example like in a given case applying the PESTLE (Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Legal, and Environmental) example  in LAMB another AI learning assistant https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0920548924001090 4. Emotionally responsive AI chatbot 5. AI chatbot tool for image generation in a forum 6. instructor built math games example Nvidia GameGan, An AI educational game building tool 7. Ollama cheaper than maybe not Deepseek? 8. I can answer but my professor wants an expert in LMS (Moodle AI has training for teachers like this link...)
Comment 5: Hi Angel Morris, I've developed some amazing tools myself to enhance the Moodle experience, and I'm happy to share my two cents! To increase teacher engagement, I created the local_geniai , a plugin that brings an intelligent chatbot , capable of acting as a virtual assistant, answering platform-related questions, helping with course setup, and even providing personalized pedagogical suggestions. It also has a virtual tutor . In partnership with Sil, GeniAI also includes a content generator for H5P, making it easier to create interactive activities . When it comes to student behavioral engagement, the video platform OttFlix is an excellent solution! With it, you can create immersive and engaging experiences by combining interactive videos with AI-generated automatic subtitles. After generating the subtitles, OttFlix goes further and transforms the video into an Interactive Video , allowing the creation of Mind Maps , personalized quizzes , Interactive Books , and many other H5P solutions that encourage active student participation. It’s a great way to keep students engaged by offering different ways to interact with content, while the teacher can track student performance in real time. In terms of emotional engagement, AI can assist through sentiment analysis and personalized feedback . Some tools can be used to monitor student participation and even identify when a student may be facing emotional difficulties, suggesting interventions and appropriate support. However, I don’t know of anything specifically available for this yet. Social engagement can be enhanced with the use of AI to foster collaboration . Chatbots and virtual tutors can encourage forum discussions, promote group activities, and even help form study groups based on complementary interests and skills, just like the GeniAI already does. And regarding gamification , there are many ways to implement it in Moodle, such as using H5P activities generated by GeniAI to bring a playful touch to learning. The future of Moodle with AI is all about increasing personalization and interactivity! Eduardo Kraus Innovation and new products
Comment 6: Thanks Eduardo, Are there additional fees to use GeniAI? Is there an instructional pdf or video on how to use GeniAI ? Or can your company deploy Moodle and the plugins? Or can I just watch this to get a general understanding? How long have you been in development, teaching, etc?
Comment 7: Hi Angel Morris, Are there any additional fees for using GeniAI? — No. Only the fees charged by OpenAI. Is there any PDF or instructional video on how to use GeniAI? — Not yet, as Sil and I are still finalizing it, along with the GeniAI Academy. — However, in Portuguese, Sil has a course available at: ToDraw - GeniAI Course . Comment 11: This is what Gemini or Dave Bergmann Senior Writer, AI Models, IBM said, A "mixture of experts" (MoE) is a machine learning technique where multiple specialized models, called "experts," work together to solve a problem by dividing the task into smaller, more manageable sub-domains, with a "gating network" selecting the most relevant expert for each input data point, ultimately combining their predictions for a more accurate result; essentially, it's a way to leverage the strengths of different models to achieve better performance across a wider range of scenarios.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Australia 2020 Summit; Promoting Moodle
Post description: I know advertising isn't allowed but I'm sure you won't mind if I mention this Moodle promotion. It's an email to the Aussie PM's office (and a few others), after reading the interim report for the Australia 2020 Summit . I'd be interested in whether anyone thinks it's worth giving it a big(ger) push. (and if I've got my facts right). Well the Summit is over and we have ideas about WHAT needs to be done. Now the challenge is HOW to go about it. Most of the pieces are in place, but scattered all around. So let me point at the two of the most obvious pieces. The first is the initiative by edna - education network Australia. It’s called me.edu.au. http://me.edu.au/ This IS the basis of a citizen’s learning account. It’s still in beta and edna will probably not have considered its wider application. But with a little encouragement it could provide a way for every citizen to have a log in to many interactive .edu.au and gov.au services. It just starts as a log in to edna's network. The second is a piece of software that could, with a little work, act as a good learning environment- i.e. the online forums. This Aussie invention is used as a courseware host in many .edu institutions around the world. With a little tweaking it could provide a good introduction to a citizen’s online learning. More importantly it will encourage teachers and students to get involved and learn it while communicating. It’s called a Moodle. http://moodle.org/sites/ Most of the things we would all like to see For Australia in 2020, and the infrastructure that it will demand, are now down to how fast people government departments might pick up the interactive and open culture. Wikipedia is the best example. 15 people are responsible for a network of information, which is contributed to, and demanded by, around 40 million people per month (take all numbers with a pound of salt). Progress needn’t be as daunting as you might think. Australia has a lot of very bright people here who would like to contribute, if we could just get conversations like this onto a well organised group of forums and help them find one another. This can be done very quickly, as many of them would like to get involved but have never been given the means or opportunity. Thank you for the Summit ; you’ve set the old media stage. Now the new interactive one must be set. So could I ask you to respond to this little message as though I, like many others, have been working for years on understanding how lots of the pieces and people could come together ? (once we had a government with the right attitudes). Thankfully, now we have a government with the right attitudes.
