Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle for users before enrolling in courses
Post description: Moodle is undoubtedly an accomplished learning system. My problem is that I need to promote courses and my learning establishment BEFORE leading users into enrolling for courses. How can I do this? Basically I need public access to the following content 1- Numerous pages with articles about learning models etc. 2- About us pages 3- Privacy policy and mission statement pages 4- A full fledged FAQ section with categories 5- Contact page for personalized inquiries I consider this sort of content as essential to public access before I expect anyone to sign up for a course. Basically I need to 'sell' the establishment beforehand.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: When I was first given the task of researching Moodle I did so from a Learning Centre (Library) point of view because that was my function in college and I found the language of Moodle confusing, Learning Centres at least in our college do not have 'courses' we run sessions, we provide information, we do books but, we don't teach - not in a traditional sense. So I was determined not to refer to 'courses' but I'd call them something else. It was only later that I realised 'course' is just a word. The content of a 'course' can be anything you want it to be. When a course is set up in Moodle there are two basic options Add resources Add activities Adding resources creates a filing cabinet, adding activities creates a learning environment. In your situation I would use the 'add resource' option, allow guest access or set up a new role to allow a degree of inter-action. The topic based format would seem to be best - although the adaptations to Moodle that can be made using the 'flexible-page' format should be considered. To take your points in turn (although each point could be considered as a separate 'course' there will be some cross-over) 1- Numerous pages with articles about learning models etc. Topics set up using labels to break up the content to give an appearance of structure, links off-site 2- About us pages Links to your establishment, documents prepared by you or your students 3- Privacy policy and mission statement pages More topics, another course, a directory of files 4- A full fledged FAQ section with categories A glossary - yes I know that's a Moodle activity but it's purpose built for the job 5- Contact page for personalized inquiries This could be just a listing in a topic, or it could be a forum, or a glossary, or a chat room and yes forums, gloassaries and chat rooms are activities but with Moodle it is so difficult (and really not to be recommended) to separate the resources from the activities. The possibilites are endless. Ian

Forum Post: 
Post title: Copying Courses
Post description: We are using Moodle to create a course matrix of procedures and questionnaires for in this case Course is = to Craft: Example Boilermaker, Pipefitter, Carpenter, etc. are courses that we have set up in Moodle for this matrix. Many of the crafts/courses in our current Moodle configuration have the same procedural and questionnaire requirements. It would be convenient to create one course that has all of the content that we require and to be able to copy it and re-name the course and all of its supporting files and hyperlinked images as a new course. We would then go into the "copied" courses and remove all of the supporting files and hyperlinked images that are not needed per individual craft. Is there any way to do this???
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think what you are talking about is "remix" making onother course with what you have. Moodle remix = YES import from other courses. John
Comment 2: I am a newbie...What is Moodles remix or a "YES" import? I need a step by step... Thanks!!! Alicia
Comment 3: John and everyone else I found my answer: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=37841 Thanks! Alicia
Comment 4: Hi Alicia, Great that you have found the info you needed. Moodle Docs is a invaluable source of info as well http://docs.moodle.org This link is a howto to your question. http://docs.moodle.org/en/Import_course_data John
Comment 5: Hi Alicia, We do the same process you are proposing. So, yes, that is a good procedure in Moodle. However, we do not bother to go back and remove all the supporting files. Is that really necessary? If you have your own server , hard disks are cheap. One question is whether your experience with Moodle is short or long? There are some things I could recommend to make the job easier, but we have been doing this for six years now. Some things you may consider: Import will move ALL course files (it is an all-or-nothing option to set) Import can selectively remove activities and resources, but the course files Using site files instead of course files might be a better strategy for saving disk space However using site files to hold your common files would require some advanced setup (make and apply new roles for example) The Sharing Cart (a contributed block) may be useful for duplicating and moving single activities and resources Hope this helps. Any more questions? Don

Forum Post: 
Post title: Community Moodle Feedback
Post description: Hello Moodle Users, My name is Mark, I am currently in my final year studying for a computer sciences degree. I have chosen to do my final year dissertation on VLE's (Virtual Learning Environments). To begin my project I want to critically analyse what is already out there (moodle being one of the main VLE's), so what I ask for is general feedback from Moodle users. This can be disadvantages you have stumbled across, advantages and even your views on how 'you' would make the system better as a whole. I would normally have done this as a questionnaire, however I do not know of any institutions round my area dealing with moodle. It is important I can gather this information from users who have currently used this system day out and in and have had many experience with it. As it is also important to gather it from first time users, as they may have more critique to add. So please add any feedback and views on moodle, I have already got a few views however lacking the real community voice. Remember this is just general feedback so just bullet point whatever you think is good, bad or what you think you could do to make it better. From this information I can further assess Moodle with reliable and honest information and not just my opinion. Many thanks, Mark
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I suspect what you are doing is too big for what you need. There are a LOT of possible VLE's Check out this forum: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?f=485 And the links in Moodle Buzz. http://moodle.org/mod/data/view.php?d=19
Comment 2: Hello Derek, To tell the truth all I want to do is focus on Moodle, gather peoples opinions and find out what is missing. I will then implement this missing part as my final year project... I am not going to implement a VLE itself but rather something that is missing from the chosen VLE (moodle) for example VOIP. Please email me more information of this proposal you have: M.Wilkinson2@gmail.com Thanks, Mark P.S. add-ons like dialogue, journal, blog, tagging, annotating. e-portfolio and file sharing add-ons. This is important information!
Comment 3: Mark I applaud your very valiant effort to take a bite out of this very important topic, VLE. One feedback has already pointed out that this subject is big (huge in fact)-- how so? My own experience is as a client, creator, facilitator and server side developer (amateur with intermediate skills). I have no computer science degree but a MBA, 23 years plus in the US Navy before retiring, 4 years as a lecturer after retirement at a Maritime Institution and various skills sets in computers, programming and such--most recently Adobe elearning and WAMP . My main reason for mentioning the above is to help bring a "two sided" coin type look at his issue. For me, VLE, LMS, CMS or what have you-- in order to have the desired affect (attainment of competencies, real learning/synthesis (Bloom stuff), development of life learning skills, betterment of society, etc.) VLE must have a guiding hand that understands the requirements of both facilitators and ICT! THIS I FIND SORELY MISSING! What do I mean by that?; If the "correct" track/ ICT infrastructure is not in place for the facilitators/ course creators-- we get garbage in, garbage out! Problem is, many facilitators (generalizing) have little clue about ICT requirements with reference to (WRT), i.e., LMS, CMS, e-Learning Course building software, security, access, course creator skill sets and even proper learning, teaching style, course structure and development (competency and outcome development, etc.) My experience here is that for more than two years, administrators can't decide weather to adopt a VLE or not; Issues put forth include; privacy of data, concerns about allowing material on the net for others to see and copy, not understanding total cost/benefits, and stake holder req, etc. Facilitators will even expect you do their work for you-- load materials, convert files, etc. Protocols and standards for ICT often times are at odds with "educator progress". SMART classrooms, use of INTRANET, Exam clickers, interactive quizzes, live Internet access and camera feeds present real security issues for ICT but are a must collaborative learning to take place. We're also assuming everyone is enthusiastic about doing VLE. The "old guard" suggesting what's wrong with the way we're doing now syndrome? Even though there may be clear direction from a businesses Strategic Planning for these types of initiatives, the paralysis of analysis often prevails. They cannot implement or follow through. My recommendation here is the Six Sigma type approach; Assemble a "Black belt team of ICT, SME and Execs to quickly and decisively carve out the way; next a Green belt team to flush out and implement, and White belt for daily routines. One more note on the server side-- once the facilitators and course creators start creating-- watch out for file sizes and haphazard file storage directories with little organization-- policies, structure, training and coordination. Again, the facilitators will think you are supposed to guide them, but ICT themselves may be looking for guidance. In one organization I worked at, every day people from ICT came thru the spaces looking at what we were doing, asking about problems/ staying connected and going to some department meetings to get the jump on "unplanned initiatives" that would involve/impact ICT. So, getting back to too big a topic-- something like VLE best practices and somehow theorizing it having positive(significant) effect on the bottom line, human capital development, etc., might be good? How this helps-- look forward to more dialog! Iman

Comment 1: Another Moodle first (I think) that I'm sharing with the Moodle community. To add to the multi-stamp feature for Moodle 2.2 , I've managed to add a "Pseudo-block" that allows the current user to see the number of stamps that he or she has earned. So as soon as the user logs onto Moodle and enters his/her coursepage, he will immediately see the number of stamps and the stamp icons he has earned. A mouseover of each stamp will elicit a text description of the reason for the award. Those currently using David Mudrak's Stamp Collection module for Moodle 2.2 (and their students!) will benefit from this. A picture is worth a thousand words. Post title: Good news from the EFF.org - Privacy Badger plugin for Firefox and Chrome
Post description: EFF has just announced a new privacy protecting plugin for Firefox and Chrome. What is Privacy Badger? Privacy Badger is a browser add-on that stops advertisers and other third-party trackers from secretly tracking where you go and what pages you look at on the web.  If an advertiser seems to be tracking you across multiple websites without your permission , Privacy Badger automatically blocks that advertiser from loading any more content in your browser.  To the advertiser, it's like you suddenly disappeared. Install it now at: https://www.eff.org/privacybadger Why should you care? Here's an excerpt from a news story in the UK publication Private-Eye: Besides safekeeping, such an intrusive industry raises another question: is sensitive personal information now mere merchandise? Most UK data brokers have sense enough to hide their creepier practices, but there are exceptions. Clear Data Ltd, based in Herefordshire, advertises lists of old people ("over 65 and mostly female") waiting to be targeted by quack doctors, boiler room conmen, telephone raffle operators, and pyramid schemers in need of credulous targets. Data Broker Limited, from Cheshire, caters to predatory lenders — "[if you're] offering new loans to people With poor credit history and [county court Judgements against them], Databroker have the largest list related to loans for postal, telephone, mobile, SMS, email and social media campaigns". You can read the rest here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=258810#p1122926 Seems worthwhile to at least try to reduce how much your learners', teachers', and admins' personal information and browsing habits are exposed to such dubious practices.

Post title: Course in elementary statistics for psychology
Post description: Pardon me if I am posting this in the wrong place, but I have to risk it. I have been looking at Moodle for some months, and have used in a very primitive manner in one short courses and like it very much.  Now, I am planning to use Moodle in a series of courses on statistics, data analysis, and methodology at the faculty of psychology at my university.  Therefore, I am trying to locate useful material on the net, especially in respect to sets of questions or item banks that might be useful.  Google is not very useful, at least not in respect to the search terms I have used so far. The textbook I am using at the moment is Howitt & Cramer, "An Introduction to Statistics in Psychology", and it seems that the publisher does not have anything useful to contribute in this respect. So: Does anybody have any useful suggestions or pointers? Tom
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tom Might I suggest that you make use of your students to help with this as part of the learning process?
Comment 2: That certainly is a good idea, and I have actually thought about it. I would like to have a set of questions to start with though. Anyhow, thank you for the suggestion. Tom
Comment 3: Hi Tom, I ran across this site when I taught statistics years ago--it has lots of good ideas and example problems and questions: http://www.ruf.rice.edu/%7Elane/rvls.html
Comment 4: Thank you, I'll look around there. Tom
Comment 5: nice interactive statistics demos/exercises (might be for more advanced students.., but anyway it helped me to understand the first and second errors of hypotesis testing and sth more) http://www.stat.vt.edu/~sundar/java/applets/

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is is possible to directly update/edit a document on Moodle?
Post description: At Present we have to delete the version we have on Moodle and then add the new version that we have updated outside Moodle. Thanks in advance for any help you can offer.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I like that suggestion, Susan. Directly update a .doc, .pdf or .odf file that is posted as a resource. Presently, the best way to directly edit documents is to make a forum--and paste the document text into the forum text area. If you make the document itself directly editable, you would of course have to make settings to say who can update it and whether it should be updated at all. Some resources posted are reference materials, not for editing. Do you know how to post a feature request? Here is an guide. I suggest you go to the Issue Tracker, log in there, and "create a new issue". An issue can be either a "bug" or a "feature request". Explain what you want and why you want it. Explain the problems that this new feature would deal with. Then come back to this forum and post the Issue Number. Then the rest of us can vote on it and optionally choose to watch the comments on the Issue Tracker. It may take months or years to get something going, but if enough people like the idea, it will eventually get put into Moodle. How does that sound? Cheers, Don

Forum Post: 
Post title: Just Considering Moodle
Post description: Hey all, I'm new to the site and my agency is considering usig Moodle as our Learning Management System. Since I'm a bit slow with development work (being a non-techie), I wanted to know how Course work gets into Moodle.  Specifically, does Moodle let users (teachers, et al) create SCORM compliant courses in another software package and add them to the system? I hope this makes sense.  I'm just really beginning my search and didn't find much in the documentation which answered my question.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It does let them create SCORM stuff in another package and import into Moodle but it does much more than that as it enables them to create activities directly within Moodle without the need to make elsewhere and import in - such as self-marking activties, collaborative activities such as forums/wikis and assignments whereby students send in work to be marked and stored online by their teacher. You can alsomake your courses interesting by using multimedia - sound, vision, images, rather than just pages of boring text (well, boring to some people anyway!)
Comment 2: When I was on the demo site, I noticed you could add the modules.  Since our focus wouldn't be in the educational field per se, I didn't know if Moodle would meet our needs. From what you're saying, it sounds as if I would have all that I need to create the courses in Moodle without using the external software package.
Comment 3: Jason - yes; I am sure you could create the courses in Moodl without needing to use any external software packages. However -you say you aren't in the educational field per se but would be creating courses? What kind of courses then? Training courses? CPD? Moodle can do all those!
Comment 4: What do you mean by SCORM stuff? Thanks
Comment 5: Sylvia - check out this link in the Moodle docs for SCORM
Comment 6: SCORM is an industry standard in e-Learning.  I'm not EXACTLY sure what it entails, but my higher-ups insist that whatever LMS we go with supports SCORM.
Comment 7: Fully half of the higherups in educational setting are in the same position as you Jason. Basically * IMHO they think that by creating courses in scorm they will not have to learn to use the delivery system. They are mistaken.
Comment 8: Hello, Welcome to the Moodle. I am new too.
Comment 9: I dunno, E.L. I think they're looking at SCORM as a way to get their content out when they leave an l.m.s. Rather than have it, like content in e-college, all tied up in proprietary, escape-unfriendly situations. We used some SCORM & IMS tools to get our content out of WebCT 4.1, but it didn't very satisfactorily move into Moodle. In the end, we got content in the old fashioned way: copy & paste and build new html pages.
Comment 10: Ben, That's exactly right.  We're looking for flexibility in how we provid our courses. We'd like to use a tool to build SCORM compliant courses (like Toolbook) that we can add to Moodle.  If the angency I work for finds a solution they think is better, we'd like to be able to use the same files for both systems without doing any extra work. Jason
Comment 11: Yes there is the mobility theory but my experience like yours has been that it t'aint necessarily so.
Comment 12: Hi Jason, Moodle can create resources without the need for any other software, but the experience I've had with corporate training is that there tends to be an expectation that training materials will be flash-based content with lots of animations and eye-candy, and this is something that Moodle definitely won't do by itself. This is where specific content tools like (for example) the Articulate suite can be used to create the content and then upload that content into Moodle. In summary - Moodle can create content, but this will really depend on what the expectations of your management group are in terms of what 'content' means to them - get that picture clear and then you can assess whether Moodle's inbuilt tools are good enough for what you need. Hope this helps,

Forum Post: 
Post title: MoodleMoot IE/UK 2024 Dates?
Post description: Are there any thoughts on dates yet?

I missed out on Moots in 2023 (Global and UK) because of date clashes with commitments I'd already made and my diary is rapidly filling up for 2024 so the sooner these come out the better.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've been in touch with Moodle HQ regarding this. Here's the response I received on 22 January: Moodle HQ will not be organising MoodleMootIEUK 2024, but some Moodle Partners are planning to do it this year (probably during the second half of 2024). We recommend you keep an eye on our website moodle.com/events to find out more about the official local MoodleMoots supported by Moodle HQ. Once the details for MoodleMootIEUK 2024 are confirmed, the event will be listed on this site so you will be able to contact the organisers directly. Moodle HQ is actually in the process of discussing the details for the MoodleMootUKIE 2024 with some Moodle Partners, so once the main details for the event are confirmed, we will publish them on the moodle.com/events site.
Comment 2: It would be good to know if any partners are putting on a Moot. If not, I am thinking of extending my Yorkshire Moodle Users Group meetup and turning that into a smaller than a Moot but still ace Moodle event where UK Moodlers can all get together. It'll be in Leeds (not London). But if a UK Moot is happening, then I won't need to. So come on partners, let us know...the community misses UK moots and Mexico is a hard sell for many.
Comment 3: I've created a linkedin group for a community group in Yorkshire if anyone wants to register an interest https://www.linkedin.com/groups/13007780
Comment 4: I've had an update from Moodle HQ regarding the UK & Ireland MoodleMoot. There will not be a MoodleMoot UK & Ireland this year or in 2025, but the MoodleMoot Global event will be held in the UK in September 2025 (exact location and dates to be confirmed). Given that we're well into November I'm not surprised that there will be no MoodleMoot this year. The fact that MoodleMoot Global is going to be held in the UK in 2025 is an exciting development.

Forum Post: 
Post title: End of term/year rollover/archiving
Post description: Hi, What are people doing about end of year with Moodle? I'm thinking really in terms of mechanisms for keeping the last 'n' years of courses for student reference. I'm trying to find out if anybody is doing such a thing and how they go about it. Any 'I heard xyz is doing that' so I can follow it up would help.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Stuff like a freeze flag has been talked about previously. See here https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=321505
Comment 2: Yep - that would be useful but I was talking more about the high level view. For example, I know some sites completely clone their Moodle to an archive version at the end of the year. So they may have several years worth of old moodle sites running on VMs in case somebody still wants them.
Comment 3: Yep, that's what I've done in the past and what I'll be implementing this summer for my new place. Previously they've created a new category on the existing moodle site (2014/15, 2015/16, 2016/17) but that has meant manually duplicating every course into the new year. The planned system will be to freeze enrolments, clone the site to an archive server , run an upgrade to Moodle and plugins on the LIVE server and do any planned maintenance, link the course enrolments back up so that the new cohorts get automatically enrolled from our student record system (external database plugin). We'll keep those archives for x years, then back them up and remove them from the archive server in line with a data retention policy that is currently being discussed.
Comment 4: This is what we do too.. Take a snapshot of live source code and DB , Apply a whole lot of capabilities in bulk to restrict students and teachers doing something , change the my sql i type to a custom one that skips writing to the DB and put it on a different site. I have to admit this is not a 100% solution but it covers most avenues of disallowing users to make any changes. Hittesh

Forum Post: 
Post title: Voiceboards/Voice Recorder in Moodle
Post description: Over in Moodle for Language Teaching, the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology just announced the Gong Project .  It is a voice board / voice recorder for Moodle that features... Basic 'voice board' operation Speed up/slow down voice playback Voice indexing - students can highlight and play back a single word/phrase (English words only) Messages can use any language for text/voice Text and voice editors--delete, trim, insert, replace
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I tried gong before and even went so far as to install it on a server (I ended up removing the installation because it was using the same port as my LAMS installation amongst other reasons). The earlier versions required the user to download an application and install it locally before accessing the server which kind of ruled it out for what I wanted to use it for. The web app. approach makes much more sense and the moodle integration is excellent news. Will take another much closer look. Just a few notes about this (I should really forward this to the guys in Hong Kong first but here goes anyway): The distinction between the various forms of gong is massively confusing (at least it was to me). This really needs to be simplified/clarified. The people writing the page obviously know exactly what they are talking about but there is way too much knowledge that is assumed of the visitor to the page. An approach where everything is explained in the simplest terms and then expanded would be much more helpful (the moodlerooms site does a very good job of this sort of thing). The descriptions are also very generic and when you try to delve in at some sort of depth you don't really find any. I am guessing they are in need of some feedback so I will give some once I have looked into the newer versions. Cheers, James Phillips

Post title: Any sign of dates for MoodleMoot IE/UK 2019
Post description: I think I ask this every year, any news on dates? I'm guessing sometime in April but there have been variations from that pattern. I've got people pestering me to commit to dates for other activities Spring 2019, which I'm having to put off until I have MoodleMoot dates. It would be really great if the dates came out well in advance this time.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't have the dates to hand before the last 3 but they have been in the week before Easter, the last 2 years has been the Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. 2016 was Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday of that week but heading north out of London on the Thursday night was horrendous so I assume it was changed to give the extra day before the bank holiday for people to sort travel, etc. So, I would guess at 15th, 16th and 17th but then Easter is very late next year so who knows!
Comment 2: John, those dates are my theory as well, based on the past pattern, though I'm hoping that we're both wrong since they pose a problem for me. However, exact dates aside, could the MoodleMoot UK organisers *please* get the dates announced sooner? People keep trying to fill up my diary, I've got other possible commitments "on hold" waiting for the MoodeMoot dates. Easter is a holiday period and like many people I would like to be able to plan my holidays before everything gets booked up, but it is impossible to do so until MoodleMoot dates are out. For 2019 I already have a one-off invitation only event in N. Wales that's on the 15th April. As a volunteer contributor to the project, I'm loath to miss it. Right now my plan is to skip the first day of MoodleMoot and travel in the evening. I'm hoping MoodleMoot isn't too far from N. Wales this time, since I have to be back there by the evening of the 18th for further confirmed commitments. On side note, I'm a director of PyCon UK 2019 (5 days, 700+ attendees and 100% volunteer run) we already have the 2019 dates published on our website (13th to 17th September if anybody is interested). I'm firmly of the opinion that getting the dates and location for MoodleMoot UK out much earlier would have a positive impact on attendance numbers, it works for us at PyCon UK. There are many other smaller events I'm involved with or attend that already have 2019 dates out that are well past April.
Comment 3: Hello both. Your guess is accurate - the UK and Ireland MoodleMoot 2019 will be from 15th to the 17th April in Manchester. More details and links to follow shortly.

Post title: The most important thing I have ever learnt in my life
Post description: The most important think I have ever learnt in my life is just to " listen ". Most people think they already do, so did I, but most of the time we are just " hearing ". To listen is to think about what others say, being able to change our own thinking. That is really important. The most important thing to succeed in business is to listen to the customer. They are realising nowadays that this is the best way to manage a company and the best marketing strategy, also. The best pedagogical theories in education , such as constructivism , just say that we have to listen to what the student knows, and then help him to improve his knowledge. The less bad political organization today, called democracy, is based on listening to the people and leting them choose who is going to rule the government . The most important method for acting , proposed by Stanislavsky, is a whole process that starts just by listening to everything. It is used by all the actors from the Actor's Studio, many of them being Hollywood stars. Psychology is the art of solving problems by listening to the people and understanding them. To feel happy it is important to listen to ourselves, to our feelings and thinkings and also to listen to others.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thank you.  Well said and a great reminder!
Comment 2: Thanks for that reminder, David. You are 100% correct about the importance of listening. Best regards, Art Lader Aiken High School

Forum Post: 
Post title: National seminar on Open Source: Opportunities in entrepreneurship Ver 2.0
Post description: Open Source software is catching fancy of millions of technocrats around the world. A lot of emphasis is being laid on developing applications based on Open Source, which are either free or are available at nominal costs. This is coming out as a big opportunity to developers and users alike. It is estimated that by 2015, Open Source Market will assume 37% market share of overall development scenario. This needs for deep introspe ction both at micro and macro level so that the true potential of Open Source can be explored and entrepreneurs are prepared with right mindsets. INMANTEC had successfully organized first seminar on “Open Source: Opportunities in Entrepreneurship” on March 13, 2010. This seminar was a huge attraction among open source professionals and budding entrepreneurs. The glimpse of the same can be accessed from here. Keeping the same fervor, INMANTEC is organizing second seminar in this series entitled “Open Source: Opportunities in Entrepreneurship Ver 2.0” on February 15, 2012 at INMANTEC, Ghaziabad. Through this seminar, we wish to address following issues impeding growth of entrepreneurs in Open Source: Entrepreneurship through open source Capital for entrepreneurship venture on open source Marketing of open source products & services Customization of open source software To provide hands on experience in different technologies, we will be conducting workshops on different open source technologies:- Spoken Tutorial [ Free Workshop ]. Open Source OS: Ubuntu ( A Separate session on Ubuntu for Schools. ) Game development using Open Source. Content management using Wordpress Open Source ERP. Moodle 2.0: A Course Management System Android Apps Development. Open Java [ Free Workshop ] Library Automation using NewGenLib For more information please connect to http://inmantec.edu/os2012
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Gaurav, It looks like an interesting seminar. The concept of open source is basically a legal framework of copyright (or copyleft) definitions that enables anyone to use, adapt and redistribute freely and without any restrictions: http://www.opensource.org/osd.html I think it's imperative that anyone embarking on an open source project or uses code from open source projects understands the legal responsibilities and implications before they invest time and effort in them. It's a fundamentally different model. I think a lot of people from more traditional business backgrounds would have difficulties understanding how all this works, I've certainly had some quizzical looks and incredulous responses when I've tried to describe the open source concept.
Comment 2: Hii Matt, This is true that defining open source to traditional business background guys is not an easy thing to do. Thats why i took a different strategy. I am promoting open source with students of information technology and management stream. In addition to it i also networked with a non-profit organization NITEE(Network of ICT entrepreneurs & enterprises. They will help students in developing their project and solve their queries with som ehand holding. How students can get government grants for the same. The seminar will also focus on these points too. Target Audience: Management, Computer Science and Information Technology students. Sessions : Entrepreneurship through open source. Capital for entrepreneurship venture on open source. Marketing of open source products & services. Customization of open source software
Comment 3: Entrepreneurship through open source - I think Wordpress is one of the pioneers in this area. Some may think "a free open platform - what kind of business model is that?".But as it's developer network has grown exponentially, the use of it's CMS being widely used, and sites such as CNN.com using it's blogging functionality - it's proven to be the leader in CMS. Joomla, Magento, Drupal... these all have their uses, but not the same appeal. Using coders myself, it's often easy to "clone" wordpress designs or sites - wandering into the violation of copyright that was mentioned. Either way - sound like a great event, please keep us posted! ( Edited by Helen Foster to remove links; please see our policy on advertising - original submission Wednesday, 26 October 2011, 08:04 AM )

Post title: anonymized Moodle student usage data
Post description: Hello, I am a student at RWTH Aachen, Germany, and I am working on my diploma thesis with the title: ReST: A recommender system for teachers based on educational data mining. I develop a stand alone recommender system for teachers which can be applied to any learning management system like Moodle or L2P (L2P is a LMS based on MS Sharepoint and is used at the RWTH Aachen). The recommender system shall use different data mining techniques on LMS usage data like regression to give teachers some information how their own LMS usage impacts the usage behaviour of the students. Clustering algorithms shall give teachers an overview about different student groups based on their LMS usage. The recommender system uses tools like WEKA and KEEL. Unfortunately my university can only give me usage data of the courses but no marks - without this very important attribute I cannot use (for example subgroup discovery) algorithms to give teachers feedback about their students LMS usage and the students learning success. Therfore I am asking for students' Moodle usage datasets I can analyze in my thesis. The data may not be randomized because I need plausible data. Does anyone know where I can get such data?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Compulsory Student Magement Systems in Australia and Moodle Integration
Post description: I heard that, as of March 1, 2010 all RTO's must implement an AVETTMES compliant student management system. It appears that some companies are seeking to integrate with Moodle. What information is available about the new requirement and about Moodle integration?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, Very interesting topic. But I couldn't find any reference to 'AVETTMES' in google. Could you provide a link to that? Also, I wondered what 'RTO' referred to. Thanks!
Comment 2: Vocational Education is highly regulated in Australia Don. RTO is a registered training organisation. AVETTMISS is, as I understand, a protocol for reporting / communicating with Government. (someone might have a more concise definition). These are the relevant government agencies. Best, John http://www.training.com.au/portal/site/public/menuitem.118e29e68c7b0615af17bfae17a62dbc/ http://www.aqf.edu.au/
Comment 3: Schools typically use a purpose-built application for Student Management (an SMS), more-or-less isolated from their Moodle. It should be easier to output AVETMISS data from the SMS than from Moodle. The SMS is usually part of a complex qualification process for getting demographic-linked subsidies. It needs minimal information about the content of courses because funding does not (yet) depend on qualitative aspects of learner performance. The VLE is part of a mass of teacher/learner interactions, and not oriented around demographics because it is possible to teach well without background information about students. The essential documentary output of an SMS is authorisation for a student ID for specific courses. The essential documentary output of a VLE is a statement of achievement (grades). AVETMISS specs require a lot of fields that are not in Moodle: http://www.ncver.edu.au/statistics/avetmiss60/vetprovider/vetprov_collection_specs60.pdf Data might be stored in existing spare fields and repurposing a few, but only if: 1. All of your Course Creators strictly follow a protocol regarding all of the Course and Assignment identifiers and names, etc. 2. Validation rules are applied to user profile data and course data after it has been created. I had assumed that all RTOs had a Student Administration System with much more (relevant) detail than Moodle (at least for billing purposes!). Are there any RTOs that don't?
Comment 4: I work for an RTO we used Nrolls but recently changed to Frontdesk. I dont really know these days how an RTO could function without having a student management system. Our organisation does not use a LMS so cant comment about Moodle integration but I feel to make is AVETMISS compliant it would need alot of work. cheers Daryl

Forum Post: 
Post title: Links to educational Java and Flash Games packaged as a free course
Post description: Hi all! As part of my efforts to engage students in Moodle and to provide some educational fun and challenge within my Moodle courses, I've packaged a free Moodle 1.9.7 Course entitled "Learning made fun with Games". You can download the course from: http://scm.moodleace.com/course/view.php?id=42 You will have to create your own login account to access the zip file contained within the course. Note: i've given credit to the Names of owners of the Java applets and websites, wherever possible. The course that contains the following games and web links: Moodle Book activity: Great Java Logic & Brain Teaser Games Simon Says Sudoku Wordz! Multiplayer Maths PacMan 15 Puzzle Graviton Tangram Hexxagon Chocobun Lemmings Traffic Jam Mastermind Lunar Lockout Pentominos (these collection of games will provide a healthy brain workout) Interactive ICT games & quizzes file http://www.reviseict.co.uk/games Languages Online - a great resource of games! file - http://www.education.vic.gov.au/languagesonline/default.htm Feel free to use this free course, which is simply a course, that contains one Moodle book activity, several web links, plus two VoiceThreads on games in education. Enjoy, Frankie.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Frankie, I would like to introduce myself - my name is Danit and I work at the Open University in Israel. I happened to stumble upon  this post and I'm very excited - it looks like it's exactly what I was looking for. I tried the following link: http://scm.moodleace.com/course/view.php?id=42 But I got an error message: "The DNS server may be temporarily unavailable, or there could be a network problem" Is there a new URL for this site? Thanks in advance, and all the best, Danit
Comment 2: Shalom, Danit! Yes, my 1-year web host subscription expired. I've moved my Moodle production site to a new domain . You can access the game course here: http://www.moodurian.com/course/view.php?id=3 If you want the Book resource of flash/Java games, click here: http://www.moodurian.com/mod/book/view.php?id=37&chapterid=14 Login as:- Username: studentscm Password: studentscm If you use Moodle 1.9 , you're in for a treat. I've made the whole course as a backup zip file that you can download and then restore as a new Moodle course. Some of the games listed are classics in the genre of puzzles and problem solving. Since I love chess, my all time favourite Java/flash puzzle game on the course is Lunar Lockout , a ThinkFun game that is no longer on the market (shelves). There's also a Javascript ( DHTML ) version of the Lemmings game - that game was the Angry Birds game of the 1990s! Also, as for an excellent game to teach introductory modular and procedural programming to kids, you can't go wrong with lightbot (I've got the swf on my Moodle site). Lastly, if you happen to like innovation and Moodle hacks (almost all for Moodle 1.9, one or two for Moodle 2.2), do drop by my blog at: http://moodurian.blogspot.com . Be warned, many of the 'improvements' and 'innovations' on my blog will render your out-of-the-box Moodle site, virtually impossible to automatically upgrade to the next version. Meaning that core Moodle code is being changed in many of my posts. All the best, have fun with the games section, and please let me know how it works out for you. Regards Frankie Kam, Melaka, Malaysia!
Comment 3: Thank you so much for sharing this with me! I definitely will check out your blog Keep in touch Danit

Post title: Microsoft meter patent
Post description: Another really innovative idea appears to have come out of Microsoft, according to a patent application revealed around Christmas. Their "pay-per-use" PC scheme would presumably have you feeding currency into a computers bill acceptor mechanism so that you can continue to use YOUR computer. Isn't that innovative (as MS understands the term)? This may sound alarmist but I'm betting some version of this hair-brained idea will see the light of day, along with an Internet that is no longer packet neutral, possibly in 2009. Linux on the desktop and the Mac OS are great ways to avoid a Microsoft taxation scheme that may be foisted on consumers soon.

Any issues when trying to browse users list. Is that user present in the list? Forum Post: 
Post title: Video Codec's again
Post description: I don't know a lot, I'm basically just an end user, but this question does affect us regularly. Mozilla's blog , two comments: "To that end, we are developing Daala , a fully open next generation codec." "Cisco has announced today that they are going to release a gratis , high quality, open source H.264 implementation — along with gratis binary modules compiled from that source and hosted by Cisco for download . This move enables any open source project to incorporate Cisco’s H.264 module without paying MPEG LA license fees. From https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2013/10/30/video-interoperability-on-the-web-gets-a-boost-from-ciscos-h-264-codec/ And the Daala site: http://www.xiph.org/daala/ "Daala is the code-name for a new video compression technology. The effort is a collaboration between Mozilla Foundation, Xiph.Org Foundation and other contributors." Not sure at all what this means in practical or real terms, but I was interested. I did think of titling this post "More on the video codec wars" -Derek
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Derek, Re: the Cisco CODEC, it isn't really open source, they're just going to pay the licence holders for the parts of the h.264 specification that they're using and absorb the cost (i.e. pass it on to their clients and customers). It's more than likely a stop-gap measure until an open source solution comes along. However, MPEG LA, the H.264 licence holders, are likely to fight tooth and nail to preserve their market share. I'd expect a lot of litigation along the way and attempts to bankrupt open source CODEC projects that might compete with them. So yeah, "More on the video codec wars" seems like an appropriate title.

Post title: Looking For Consultation on Moodle Security
Post description: Hello, I'm working with a small non-profit arts organization that is developing courses in Moodle. We have had major security problems over the past year. I've tried to solve these problems myself, but I do not have the necessary knowledge or experience. I'm looking for someone who is knowledgeable and experienced in Moodle security issues to provide us with a limited or short-term consultation about how we can protect our site from hackers.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is a jobs database to post such; look under Community dropdown.
Comment 2: If you have not already found it, there is a Security , Security_FAQ and Security_overview . Also the Moodle Administration book by Alex Buchner covers a lot of security best practice. Not that you should not get someone in. That is a good idea. It is just there may be some basic things you can do yourself first.
Comment 3: There is also Moodle administrator online training available from a Moodle partner. While simply fixing your immediate problem may be convenient, having somebody trained that understands Moodle will give you the assurance going forward that your site is secure and that other daily issues are taken care of.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Question formats
Post description: Hi, I would like to have a survey / poll of which of the question formats are commonly used in your Learning Management System using the Moodle platform. Aiken Blackboard Embedded answers (Cloze) Examview Gift format Missing word format Moodle XML format WebCT format Thank you very much for your response.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Could you give some more information on why you want this information. These formats are not sensibly compared, for example Moodle XML would be very frequently used as a way of moving material between instances of Moodle, but WebCT would be both obsolete and used generally on a one off basis when converting between VLE versions.
Comment 2: As Marcus suggests, you seem to be conflating question types with export/import formats and also with VLEs that host those questions. Missing word/Cloze questions would be question types, while XML and Gift would be import/export formats, and Blackboard/WebCT(defunct anyway) would be alternative VLEs that have their own question engines in them, but are neither import/export formats (except in their own way to transfer quiz questions between instances of that particular VLE) nor question types - Blackboard for example has a number of different types (not as many as Moodle, but more than enough to suggest you can't just say 'Im using Blackboard question formats')
Comment 3: The purpose of my survey / poll is to know among the Moodle community, which of the import / export and question type formats are commonly used. It is also for the research purpose to know further and evaluate each question type formats (import / export questions, third party formats and existing formats in Moodle) will it be recommend to use for my future user. Thank you very much for the response and information.
Comment 4: I'm still not sure your request is going to deliver useful information, it is like asking to compare bicycles with soups, both fine in their way but not sensible to compare them in the same survey.
Comment 5: Perhaps construct your survey/poll properly on a moodle site/google forms/survey monkey etc. Ask your questions, properly thought out with properly designed responses, so that the different areas are separate questions in your research and you may get some workable responses and data to use. SOmething like: What question platform do you use Moodle Quiz QMP Blackboard Other ___________________________ What format (if any) do you use for porting questions between quesion platforms GIFT XML Other ____________________________ What question types do you use Multiple choice Multiple choice with multiple answers Short Answer Cloze ... ... Essay That's not a properly designed survey, that's me off the top of my head in 2 minutes, but you need to sort out exactly what you are trying to discover and design your questions appropriately. R
Comment 6: And maybe ask them if they use scorm and if so what type of tool for generating scorm.

Post title: The complexities of video
Post description: There is lots happening in the video world (and some good work here with plug-gable players: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-38158 )  I hope people who know can keep us up with the play as far as Moodle is concerned, maybe provide some clarity about some of the options. Some random mes that arrived last week, from the JSPlayer blog on Flash going away in Chrome on December 6th: https://www.jwplayer.com/blog/deprecation-flash/ ) I quote: In December 6th, Google will release Chrome 55, giving more power to visitors of your site, allowing them to make a choice if they want to enable Flash or not by clicking the Flash object in the page. Previously, Flash became click-to-play when it was below a size threshold ; in Chrome 55, Flash objects will not load if the user dismisses them. Chrome tracks the user’s decision per domain . Chrome is also adding three settings that will make it even easier for users to disable Flash: [Default] Ask before allowing sites to run Flash Allow sites to run Flash without prompting HTML5 by Default – Block sites from running Flash without prompting There are similar settings available in Apple’s Safari 10 for Mac OS, with their default being HTML5 . With regards -Derek

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can anyone recommend a good webhotel for Moodle?
Post description: Hi Can anyone recommend a good webhotel for hosting Moodle 2? I'm in Sweden and our ISP still hasn't gotten round to upgrading their PHP version yet. Cheers
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Based on recent experience I would suggest you try amazon web services rather than a traditional isp
Comment 2: Thanks! But that seems to be orientated towards integrating amazon and amazon products on your website. Can you tell me how you use amazon web services?
Comment 3: A "traditional" ISP host manages a server and gives you access to aspects of a user a/c sufficient to do waht you want. Often this is through a web interface. However, often you are stuck with their server configuration. With Amazon Web Services (with which I have no connection other than using them.). you get to set up your own server and you have full access to it. From their you can install waht you want. There are prebuilt server for your use if you want, including Moodle servers. The fee is pay for what you use in terms of bandwidth and connections. It just seems to me that it is a new way of doing things. I have a Moodle 2.2 which I can turn off and on when I want to do things. When it is off I pay nothing. Last month I paid $7. (That is for very small use.). The main Moodle I use is on a dedicated server and ip address so no ISP fees for hosting. Our colleague is correct, this is not really a help forum. BTW , although it is used for running shops *which I have niot done) it can be used for anything. I did some modelling there due to the immense processor power available.
Comment 4: Finding a hosting provider is a topic for the "Hardware and Performance" forum: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=596 . Go through its recent discussions or refer the docs and other pointers given in the introduction to that forum.

Post title: ICBL 2011: CfP reminder (deadline March 31) - Antigua Guatemala, Guatemala
Post description: Dear Moodle community member: Galileo University, Guatemala is organizing a blended learning conference: ICBL 2011, please find the Call for Papers, also you can submit a moodle workshop proposal or a paper with your e-Learning experiences. Please redistribute within your own group and colleagues. 4th International Conference on Interactive Computer-Aided Blended Learning 2-4 November 2011 in Antigua Guatemala, Guatemala http://icbl.galileo.edu ICBL 2011 Call for Papers (Reminder) This interdisciplinary conference aims to focus on the exchange of relevant trends and research results as well as the presentation of practical experiences gained while developing and testing elements of interactive computer aided blended learning. Therefore pilot projects, applications and products will also be welcome. This conference will be organized by Galileo University (Research and Development Department GES), Guatemala in cooperation with: ·International Association of Online Engineering (IAOE) ·IEEE Foundation ·IEEE Education Society (IEEE EduSoc) ·The International E-Learning Association (IELA)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Random Wishlist: Grade Sliders and Word Viewer
Post description: Well, my "crazy end of semester" (and upcoming move to a strange land, 2,000 miles away from my current location) are preventing me from engaging more fully into Moodle's greatness. But, as I'm grading assignments, I've been taking headnotes about Moodle features. It might be useful for me to just throw them out of my head, even though they're not fully fleshed out (or intelligible). Some things I'd like to have in Moodle, which would make my life much easier. A viewer for Word files. And/or other file types used in assignments. This way, there wouldn't be much of a difference between "online text" and file- upload assignments. (Maybe students could elect to submit either an online text or a file upload!) It'd make things easier for students while allowing teachers to grade assignments in one simple interface. Sounds relatively easy to implement, and there might already be an add-on for this. A system to assign grades using sliders. Think rubrics, but less compartmentalised. My categories are put in decreasing order of importance (from insight to concision). And I do grade by giving relative weight to many of these (not all of them are relevant for every student's assignment). At this point, I basically "see" a series of sliders in my head as I grade. Assignments which are very insightful can easily get a full grade if everything else is at least decent. Assignments which have few other redeeming qualities may still be evaluated for concision. Altogether, my grading scheme is rather algorithmic, but the algorithm is quite difficult for me to explain (and I do realise I'm doing a rather bad job of explaining it now). So, having sliders would be very useful. I know some of the same effects could be achieved with drop-down menus for numeric values but the slider interface would, in itself, make things easier (direct feedback while grading). While I'm at it... A way for graders to separate grading and "releasing" (publishing) grades. You mark and grade an assignment but you only make the grades and feedback available at the end of the grading session. That way, you can "play around" with grading scenarios or simply compare assignments with one another. These are all very clear in my head but I'm having a hard time verbalising them. They would all make my life much easier and I'm sure some colleagues would find value in them. So, I'll surely revisit these issues later on but instead of writing them down as notes and procrastinating about fleshing them out, I decided to RERO . Cheers!
